name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate with Prime Minister Xavier Bettel of Luxembourg on the future of Europe (2018/2622 (RSP)). Before greeting the Prime Minister, before giving him the floor, I remind you that you can request “catch the eye” using the electronic voting device. To introduce your request, enter the voting card and use any of the electronic voting buttons. I proceed immediately to the opening of the system which will remain open throughout Prime Minister Bettel's intervention.

name: Xavier Bettel
text: Prime Minister of Luxembourg. — (FR) Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I am very honoured to be one of the Heads of State and Government of the European Union today who address the European Parliament plenary for to discuss the future of Europe. Addressing you here in Strasbourg is all the more dear to me since this city occupies a special place in the history of European integration. I am fortunate to be part of a generation that has not experienced the Second World War and the post-war years. The European Union has brought to our countries the longest period of peace ever known on our continent. Living in peace may seem commonplace, but believe me, peace is never trivial. Europe is an old continent made up of countries and regions rich in culture and history. The diversity of its heritage makes the beauty of this Europe. And the European political architecture must take account of this diversity. The fact that the European Parliament is meeting in plenary in Strasbourg, one of the three capitals of Europe, alongside Luxembourg and Brussels, is also symbolic in this regard. It was at the Strasbourg European Council in December 1989, a few weeks after the fall of the Berlin Wall, that the leaders of the time, such as Helmut Kohl, François Mitterrand and Hans-Dietrich Genscher, took control of the fate of Europe of the cold war, laying the foundations for European reunification, going hand in hand with the German reunification. I refer to this period in the late 1980s, a time when the world experienced great upheavals. At the said Strasbourg Council, the call was made to start us towards the European Union. This call seems to me always topical, especially at a time when the world is again undergoing great changes. I am thinking in particular of the unpredictability of some of our partners, but also the risk of a loss of European competitiveness in a globalised world. Our continent needs to be more united in order to protect citizens and chart its future. The conclusions of December 1989 still seem to me to be valid. I quote from this excerpt: 'It is in the interest of all European States that the Community should be strengthened and accelerated its march towards the European Union'. Thirty years later, let us speed up again our march towards the European Union. And let's accelerate it especially by taking into account the expectations of our citizens. Let us make our Union stronger and able to respond to the challenges we face today. In this context, citizen dialogue must be cultivated. Citizens' consultations, proposed by President Macron, are valuable opportunities to engage citizens and identify their concerns, hopes and expectations. Luxembourg is among the first countries to accede to this initiative. I myself launched the first consultations on April 20. I call for action by all Member States to meet the expectations of our citizens. But if this unity cannot be found when action is required, I would point out that in the Treaties we also have tools in the Treaties that enable us to move forward to many, namely the possibility of acting within the framework of enhanced cooperation. Just as the fall of the Berlin Wall kicked off to welcome European nations from which we have been artificially separated since the end of the Second World War, the refugee crisis in 2015 and the British referendum held a few months later are events that call for new momentum. I am convinced that the successive events that have taken place in recent years — the Arab Spring, the war in Libya, the refugee crisis, the increasing insecurity in the Sahel region and, above all, the war in Syria, not forgetting the terrorist acts in our cities — mark a turning point which requires a stronger Union's action European. Like our predecessors, we must arm ourselves with courage and take the necessary decisions in the face of these challenges, in order to maintain a Europe politically and economically strong, free and open to the world. In the aftermath of the last global conflict caused by exacerbated nationalisms, my country chosen, together with its neighbours, to be one of the founding countries of the European Union. This historic opportunity has allowed us to have a perspective on Europe which is that of a State which has taken part in the evolution of the European Union over time. For us, the choice of Europe has, at every stage, been dictated by our convictions: the choice of a European State which defines its national sovereignty also through — or even thanks to — its membership in the Union. And I am very proud that the latest polls have shown that Luxembourgers are the ones who love Europe most. Today, paradoxically, populist forces invoke only national sovereignty to ensure the salvation of Europe. It is precisely the European Union that protects our sovereignty more than ever in a globalised world. Mr President, honourable Members, the European Union provides added value to European citizens, in countless instances improving their daily lives. However, one of the greatest challenges the Union faces today is the fact that these advantages resulting from a country's membership of the Union are simply taken for granted. It is therefore not a coincidence, in my view, that so many UK citizens living in my country have been applying for Luxembourg citizenship since the Brexit referendum. Many others have apparently been doing the same in other Member States. These applications for citizenship by British citizens are proof of the huge added value of the public goods and services created by the European Union, which these citizens do not want to abandon: most obviously, the four freedoms. Sehr geehrter Herr President! Unsere Bürger verlangen ein weltoffenes und tolerantes Europa, in dem jede Frau und jeder Mann die gleichen Chancen hat, unabhängig von Religion, Hautfarbe oder sexueller Orientierung. The European Union dazu beitragen können, Germany for the globalen Probleme unserer Zeit zu finden — Probleme, welche die europäischen Nationalstaaten alleine nicht mehr schultern könen. Ich denke yesterday unter anderem an den Klimawandel. The Verhandlungen zum Pariser Klimaschutzabkommen haben gezeigt, dass die EU eine treibende Kraft sein kann bei der Suche nach Lösungen zu globalen Problemen. In general Fragen der Nichtverbreitung von Massenvernichtungswaffen kann die EU eine tragende Rolle einnehmen, wie die letzten Wochen gezeigt haben. Genauso verlangt die sich weltweit ändernde Demografie sowohl global als auch europäische Antworten. Fragen der Migration of 21. Jahrhunderts sind keine nationalen Fragen. Ich bin davon überzeugt, dass die Europäische Union eine, ja sogar die Antwort auf diese globalen Herausforderungen darstellt. Nur eine europäische Antwort kann die Sicherheit und das Allgemeinwohl unserer Bürger auch im 21. Jahrhundert gewährleisten. In addition to the work of Einsatz der Europäischen Commission and Insbesondere von Kommissarin Malmström für einen freien und offenen Welthandel im Einklang mit den Regeln der Welthandelsorganisation begrüßen. Unsere Bürger wollen teilhaben am Wirtschaftswachstum and auch am Wohlstand. The Weltwirtschaftslage ist positiv moment, das Wachstum hat sich in allen EU-Mitgliedstaaten eingefunden. Deshalb ist the richtige Zeitpunkt, um die Wettbewerbsfähigkeit Europas zu stärken. The europäische Binnenmarkt ist in diesem Zusammenhang eine Grundvoraussetzung, damit unsere Unternehmen global wettbewerbsfähig sind und das vor allem auch noch bleiben. The Euro ist wiederum eine Grundvoraussetzung für einen gut funktionierenden EU-Binnenmarkt. Deshalb ist on strategischer Bedeutung, the Vertiefung der europäischen Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion weiterhin voranzutreiben. Freitag haben die Finanzminister der EU, on business in Luxembourg, to the Bank of the Bankenunion, to finance finance and so die richtigen Weichen gestellt zur Vertiefung der Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion, zu der der Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion, sich die Staats- und Regierungschefs im nächsten juni verpflichtet haben. From the Euro and the Binnenmarkt to the city of France, and in gleichem Maße bedingen sich auch die Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion als seiten der gleichen Medaille. The Vertiefung of EU-Binnenmarktes ist deshalb auch weiterhin eines unserer Hauptanliegen. Hierbei denke ich vor allem an die Schaffung eines digitalen EU-Binnenmarktes. En wäre inkohärent, auf der einen Seite eine europäische Umsatzsteuer für Internetunternehmen anzustreben, wenn wir andererseits noch nicht einmal über einen einheitlichen digitalen eu-binnenmarkt verfügen. Ebenfalls sollten wir kurzfristige Zwischenlösungen vermeiden, die dauerhafte Beschlüsse noch schwieriger machen. Um Missverständnissen vorzubeugen: Ich befürworte eine faire Besteuerung der Enjoy the Internetunternehmen. Nur sollte eine solche Besteuerung auch im Einklang mit der Notwendigkeit der Erhaltung und der Verstärkung der globalen Wettbewerbsfähigkeit der EU sein. Deswegen scheint mir hier die Zusammenarbeit mit der OECD sehr wichtig zu sein. Was on the Diskussion zur Besteuerung von digitalen Unternehmen, den sogenannten gafas, auch zu denken gibt, ist der Umstand, dass eine große Anzahl dieser Unternehmen ihren technologischen Ursprung in Ländern außerhalb der EU haben. Wir reden übrigens oft über steuerliche Harmonisierung in der Europäischen Union. Der Binnenmarkt benötigt sicher eine gewisse Harmonisierung, auch im steuerlichen Bereich. Was mich sorgt, ist allerdings der Eindruck, dass das Wort “Steuerharmonisierung” seit Jahren and für Gesprächspartner oft gleichlautend mit dem Wort “Steuererhöhung” ist. Sollten wir im Steuerbereich — wenn wir schon harmonisieren wollen — nicht im Interesse der globalen Wettbewerbsfähigkeit und der Steuerzahler der Europäischen Union auch mal über Steuersenkungen reden können? (Beifall) Und glauben Sie mir, ich rede hier keinem Steuerdumping das Wort, aber die global Wettbewerbsfähigkeit der Europäischen Union liegt mir sehr am Herzen. The augenblickliche Diskussion der Besteuerung von Internetunternehmen zeigt aber auch, dass wir mehr in Innovation and in die Finanzierung von start-ups investeren müssen. Volkswirtschaftlich gesehen sind in einem gemeinsamen and offenen europäischen Binnenmarkt die Defizite der einen die überschüsse der anderen. Ich befürworte keine Vergemeinschaftung der Schulden oder notleidender Kredite, aber ich bin mir in einem gemeinsamen Markt unserer Verantwortung for the Allgemeinwohl auf europäischer Ebene bewusst. Ungleichheiten zwischen den einzelnen Partnern im Binnenmarkt sind auf Dauer der notwendigen volkswirtschaftlichen Stabilität in Europa auch nicht förderlich. Mr President, I would point out that Europe is not limited to its common market. To paraphrase Jacques Delors, “we do not fall in love with the common market”. At the same time, we must also work towards a European social model, which promotes upward social convergence among the Member States. In this regard, I welcome yesterday's plenary vote following the agreement reached last March between Parliament and the Council on the revision of the directive on the posting of workers in the internal market. This is an important step forward in the fight against social dumping. Similarly, I hope that agreement on social legislation for the road transport sector — legislation which allows for upward social convergence while taking into account the specificities of this sector — can be reached before the end of this legislature. I also welcome the proposal of the President of the Commission to create a European Labour Authority with a view to strengthening cross-border cooperation and the fight against fraud and abuse. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, only a strong European economy and monetary union can generate jobs and tax revenues to finance modern European models of social protection. The deepening of economic and monetary union must, however, not be limited to budgetary aspects alone. Strengthening competitiveness and productivity at European level, as well as the establishment of a genuine European Innovation Area, are factors of convergence which, in the long run, I am convinced, will facilitate joint budgetary management. A Europe that is competitive, prosperous and open to the world will be the best guarantee of the protection of the European social model. Any deepening of economic and monetary union will sooner or later also require enlargement of the euro area. The Union Treaties provide for the accession of all Member States to the euro, with the exception of two of them. The adoption of the common currency is therefore an essential legal principle in the implementation of the Treaties. However, we must act without haste, lessons learned from recent years, and ensuring the productivity and competitiveness of all euro area member countries. The next multiannual financial framework must therefore reflect the need for economic convergence by focusing more on innovation, among other things. In this regard, I welcome the Commission's proposals, which provide a good basis for discussion. I am also pleased with the attention given to the Erasmus programme. Mr President, I am fortunate to be part of this “Erasmus generation”: when I was a student at the Faculty of Law in Nancy, I spent an Erasmus stay at the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki. I was able to discover subjects that I did not know before, but this Erasmus stay opened my eyes especially to Europe's contribution to the daily lives of each of us. I can only recommend every student to make an Erasmus stay, because it is really an exchange and experience that is worth it. In the same vein, without wanting to go into detail, I also believe in the added value of the Cohesion Funds. I think it is time to reflect in a spirit of solidarity on the best use that can be made of these funds. I think it is important to ensure that cohesion funds are used even more transparently, in accordance with the rule of law. Mr President, before discussing the expectations of our fellow citizens regarding the Union's external action, allow me a parenthesis about its internal organisation. It is obviously legitimate to discuss this internal organisation, a federal Europe, a Europe of parties and the division of powers between the institutions. I do not hide from you that I am a little puzzled about institutional debates. These discussions, however important they may be, do not enthusiasm our fellow citizens. And if we feel that this is what passionate them outside, we are wrong. Institutional change must be linked to the pursuit of concrete political objectives, which meet the needs of citizens and also to their aspirations. It is precisely this concrete added value that must be the key thread for institutional change. Here, let me say, I have difficulty understanding — and I discussed it again last night with one of your representatives — the position of the “Spitzenkandidaten”, the top candidates, without having any transnational lists. I know your decision, Mr President, but I hope you will come back to that one day. (Applause) For me, we started backwards: we have “Spitzenkandidaten” without transnational lists, whereas the “Spitzenkandidat” should be the “Spitzenkandidat” of a transnational list. Mr President, the citizens that you and I represent expect the Union to contribute to their safety and security from internal and external threats. Our internal challenges in numerous policy domains, it seems to me that the largest crises were imported from outside the European Union. The refugee crisis was triggered by a worsening security situation in the Middle East and the Sahel region, to which the wars in Libya and Syria have contributed. The dramatic events of summer and autumn 2015, when hundreds of thousands of refugees have been fleeing war on a scale not seen in Europe since 1945, are obvious evidence that no European nation state is able to cope with such tragedies on its own. In that respect, I deeply regret the opposition by some EU Member States to carrying their share of the burden in a spirit of solidarity. In the age of globalisation, European solidarity is even more important than it was before. By the way, in any relationship, solidarity is a concept that should not be qualified. We need to stand together in solidarity and not try to introduce concepts like flexible solidarity, which at the end of the day will result in a reciprocal lack of solidarity. (Applause) Denn, wie heißt es doch so schön in Goethes Faust: “Nichts Bessers weiß ich mir an Sonn- und Feiertagen, Alles ein Gespräch von Krieg und Kriegsgeschrei, Wenn hinten, weit, in der Turkei, Die Völker aufeinander schllander agen. Man steht am Fenster, trinkt within Gläschen aus, Und sieht den Fluss hinab die bunten Schiffe gleiten; Dann kehrt man abends froh nach Haus, Und segnet Fried and Friedenszeiten. “Diese faustische Passage illustrated by the Wandel der Zeit. Die Türkei, Syrian, Libyan, der gesamte südliche Mittelmeerraum sowie Russland oder die Ukraine sind in der heutigen globalisierten Welt unsere direkten Nachbarn. Diese Länder sind weder “hinten” noch “weit weg”. Es sind unsere Nachbarn, und nur eine global, einheitlich aufgestellte Außenpolitik der Europäischen Union kann hier auch Einfluss nehmen. Nationalgrenzen verlieren in diesem Zusammenhang ihren Sinn, oder anders ausgedrückt: Eine national luxemburgische Grenze kann nur an den EU-außengrenzen beschützt werden. Die Bürger verlangen zu Recht Taten. Frontex ist von größter Bedeutung — nicht, weil ich the EU-außengrenzen schließen will, sondern weil ein starker europäischer Grenzschutz zur Sicherheit der Europäischen Union und der Wahrung unserer Werte unabdingbar ist. Auch hier begrüße ich die Finanzierungsvorschläge der Kommission. Ich bin überzeugt, dass die europäischen Bürger bereit sind, eine europäisch guaranteerte Sicherheit an den Außengrenzen auch mitzufinanzieren. Sicherheit ist genauso wie die Reisefreiheit und die Freizügigkeit ein gewichtiges europäisches Gut. Reisefreiheit at the Schengen und der Schutz der Außengrenzen bedingen sich gegenseitig. Mehr Europa und größere EU-budgets, welche auch die nationalen Budgets entlasten, sind hier stark vonnöten. Yesterday year dieser Stelle begrüße ich auch ausdrücklich, dass jeder EU-Bürger überall auf der Welt den konsularischen Schutz go anwesenden europäischen Konsulate genießt. Mr President, the 2015 migration crisis showed that the European Union must redouble its efforts, not only to secure its external borders, but also, in general, to strengthen its policies in the external dimension, such as foreign affairs, defence, development cooperation, without forgetting a policy common asylum and immigration issues. Only through the joint implementation of national sovereignties will we also be able to ensure our own sovereignty. Let us have the same courage as our predecessors in 1989, when they started to reunify Europe, and let us jointly ensure our security and that of our borders. I am also convinced that we will all spend less together if we put our efforts together, because of the efficiencies and synergies we can achieve. The same principle applies to the defence. Luxembourg is a country which is fortunate to be surrounded today by friendly countries, from which there is no threat to its security, quite the contrary. In its history, the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg cannot be suspected of wanting to push the Union in a direction other than supporting peace. We believe in the virtues of multilateralism and international law, diplomacy and development cooperation. Like other countries, Luxembourg has also experienced more difficult budgetary periods in recent times. Some immediately said that the budget for cooperation could be reduced. Why want to help outdoors when you still have problems inside? My Government has decided, like the previous government, that even in more difficult times, the budget for cooperation, which is spent on the poorest in the world, is one per cent that is well invested. When we wonder if we are going to eat hot or cold, some mothers wonder what they will be able to eat their children for a week. While we wonder what we are going to do, some would simply like to have a future and prospects. This per cent allows young people who, today or perhaps yesterday, have or did not have a prospect for the future, to have a job and have optimism for tomorrow. So, we defend this development policy, and I regret that at international level, and sometimes at European level, when the red 'Bic' is to be released, the cooperation budget is the first target. It's popular, but believe me, it's not good. (Applause) Mr President, also believe that I am convinced that it is in the interests of the citizens of the Member States of the Union to do more to achieve closer cooperation in the field of external relations. In this context, I am arguing in particular in favour of rapid work of permanent structured cooperation launched on the sidelines of the European Council of 14 December 2017. In the same vein, I believe that cooperation should be deepened in the field of foreign policy. The aim of the European Union must be to speak with a stronger voice for peace, which is a fundamental value, because war is the denial of human rights. Because of its history, Europe must be a bulwark against dictatorship and barbarism. European values, as we have enshrined in the Treaties, are, moreover, the fundamental consensus among the Member States. They are our foundation in our relations with the rest of the world. Finally, I remain firmly convinced that cooperation also remains a bulwark against the root causes of insecurity. A broad concept of European security must include cooperation and development. I have talked about our common values, but I cannot conclude my speech, Mr President, without mentioning the importance I attach to freedom of the press, an essential component of our democracies. In the past year several dozen journalists have been murdered, two of them in our Union itself. This is a situation that concerns me to the highest degree. It is important for the European Union to continue to defend and promote freedom of the press. Mr President, let me — you have seen, I have spoken to you in French, German, English — (The speaker spoke in Luxembourgish) I have just spoken the other language we speak in the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, which is our national language, Luxembourgish, to thank the six Luxembourg MEPs who defend the position of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg in this Europe. We are not the largest Member State, but believe me, we believe in our Europe. In conclusion, let us accelerate our journey towards Europe with confidence and boldness. Our world is changing and the European Union is the best guarantee for our collective sovereignty and the fulfilment of all our citizens. (Applause)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. — (FR) Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen. Once again, I would like to congratulate your President for having taken the initiative to invite a Prime Minister after the other to this plenary in order to discuss major issues in Europe with the colleagues of the European Parliament. That's something which has to be welcomed, because the dialogue between governments and the European Parliament is as important as the dialogue between the Commission and the European Parliament. I'm invited each and every time to respond to the Prime Minister visiting us, and I must repeat myself by saying that the differences are not as deep as they seem. Würde ich in diesem konkreten Fall dem Premierminister Luxemburgs, den ich sehr herzlich hier begrüße, widersprechen, würde ich mir selbst widersprechen müssen, weil er in der Substanz genau das gesagt hat, was die Kommission und auch der President denkt. Es tut gut, zu sehen, dass die luxemburgische Regierung voller Begeisterung hinter den Aktionsplänen der Europäischen Commission steht. Das musste mal deutlich gesagt werden, das ist heute passiert. (Beifall) So I cannot contradict the Prime Minister of my country because, in essence, he told you what the Commission is trying to convey as a message. Therefore, I will be very brief. Yes, within a year the Europeans will have elected a new European Parliament, of which no one, of course, knows the composition of which is yet. It will be different from today's one, which gives me some concerns. Therefore, I would like us to sign up together in fake — and I know Xavier does so with me — against the galloping populism we are witnessing in Europe and in all countries, including my own. But as Luxembourgers are wise men and women, the movement is not a moving movement, but a content and “contentable” movement. Ich würde gerne einige Punkte yesterday erwähnen. Weil wir uns heute in einem Jahr mit einem neuen Europäischen Parlament auseinanderzusetzen haben, denke ich, dass jetzt der Moment gekommen ist, wo die Regierungen auch klar und deutlich Farbe bekennen müssen. Wir haben im Juni einen Europäischen Rat; sleeps wird es um die Vertiefung der europäischen Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion gehen. Hätte gern, dass die Regierungschefs sich etwas deutlicher zu Wort melden, wenn es um diese Vertiefungselemente der europäischen Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion geht. Der luxemburgische Premierminister hat dies heute getan — aber nicht flächendeckend und nicht vollumfänglich. Die Frage ist: Wollen wir — ja oder nein — ein europäisches Einlagensicherungssystem in Etappen einführen? Ich bin überhaupt nicht der Meinung, dass dies hopplahop von heute auf morgen geht, aber man muss sich prinzipiell in diese Richtung bewegen. (Beifall) In Sachen Steuern: Ja, ich bin auch für Steuersenkungen. Man sollte das im Übrigen auch in Luxemburg tun. (Heiterkeit) Ja, ich habe das mehrfach gemacht! Ich habe 19 Jahre gebraucht, um Fehler zu machen, andere haben kürzere Zeit zur Verfügung. Aber in Sachen Steuerpolitik and was die Internetriesen anbelangt, geht es ja nicht um Steuersenkung oder Steuererhöhung, es geht um Steuergerechtigkeit. Es kann nicht so bleiben, dass die Internetriesen 8% Steuern bezahlen, während die kleinen und mittleren Unternehmen im Schnitt 30% bezahlen. Das ist eine ungerechte Steuerlandschaft, and die muss korrigiert werden. (Beifall) With regard to foreign policy, I agree broadly with the Prime Minister. However, I would like governments, following recent events, to agree on a simple principle. In terms of foreign policy, in order to be effective — and Xavier argued for Europe's effectiveness — we must make our decisions by qualified majority. We cannot lead the world if we stay on the principle of unanimity. It will not work. On behalf of the Commission, we have proposed to ask the European Council to decide henceforth, in certain sectors, by qualified majority. If only one Member State goes through Europe's diplomatic route, Europe is blocked and we are ridiculous when we at UN level and in other international fora claim to play a leading role. I demand a qualified majority in matters and I have no doubt for a moment that the Luxembourg Government, for the reasons which Xavier has put forward, will accompany us on this path, which I know is not easy. Mr. Speaker, these are a few things I wanted to add to the Prime Minister's remarks. I would like to say, as a Luxembourger that I am, that I remain and will be forever, that Luxembourg has played a peacemaking role in Europe. It does not have the means to do otherwise, but Europe is part of the Grand Duchy's State reason and I am grateful to the Prime Minister for continuing on this road.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President-in-Office of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats). Welcome to the European Parliament. It's good to have the Luxembourg voice here. Luxembourg is a strong advocate of European integration, founding member, and you can say: a small country, but a great European. This is Luxembourg. And that's why welcome. Luxembourg has also had in the history of the European Union and still has a lot of influence today. You thanked the six MEPs. I would also like to join Jean-Claude Juncker, who is at the head of Europe as President of the Commission. The former leaders, such as one of the founders of Europe, Joseph Bech, and Jacques Santer, of course, have also been strong figures who have taken Europe forward. And Luxembourg, of course, lives Europe: with more than 40% of citizens from other Member States living in Luxembourg, it is probably the most European country we have in Europe today. Therefore, welcome! I would like to highlight one point directly from your speech, which was also taken up by Jean-Claude Juncker: we are talking about tax cuts, and the liberals typically clap here, but we only have tax reduction debates in companies. We are discussing this because there is tax competition, because companies today decide where they pay the lowest taxes, and therefore go to the state where they pay the lowest taxes. But the people who do not make so much use of the mobility of the internal market, the workers and those who pay VAT, who go to supermarkets, unfortunately, cannot benefit from these tax reductions. That is why the point made by Jean-Claude Juncker is absolutely correct: it is not about general tax cuts, but about tax fairness. The question is that corporations pay exactly the same contribution to our state as others. (Applause) I would like to highlight two issues today. Prime Minister, we are discussing with Heads of State or Government every week. That is why I have always set out to accentuate two things in this debate. Today, because you are here as a Luxembourger, I would first like to talk about the rule of law, because you are the home of our European Court of Justice. Walter Hallstein said: European integration was not created by military strength or political pressure, but by a binding legal idea. Europe is a community of law. We should bear in mind the revolutionary idea that the law of the strongest does not apply to the law of the strongest, as has been normal for centuries on this continent, but that the promise is that European citizens will be able to practise and live their lives on the basis of the rule of law. This rule of law also establishes prosperity, is part of our European way of life, and today it is challenged by the long process that we have partly, by the economy that sets its own rules — we were presented on Facebook last week — by the deprivation of responsibility from the rich — keyword Tax avoidance — by the question that sometimes there is weak political backing for legal institutions, and of course the problem of corruption. Law must never follow power, but must always limit power. That is the principle behind this, and we need to look more closely at our rule of law. We may need common thinking about how we train lawyers, a common understanding. We have to consider that the conditionality proposed by the Commission is a right step in the right direction. The rule of law must have a price in the future if it is not respected. And the rule of law must not become a political issue between parties, but must be monitored neutrally, for example by the ECJ. The second issue that I want to pick out today is a topic that you too have raised — a topic that must worry us all very much, namely the work of our media. Freedom of the press in the state, the media, is just as existentially necessary for the future of Europe as the judiciary. That is why we need to look at the drama of the situation. It is unbearable that in the 21st century Daphne Caruana Galizia, Ján Kuciak and yesterday in Ukraine Arkady Babchenko were murdered, apparently in the exercise of their service, namely the task of upholding the free media. We are facing huge challenges. I just want to pick out two. One is the digital challenge. We must prepare ourselves, including our services, to strengthen the state structures in order to take up the fight against fake news and disinformation and against the hatred that we are experiencing there on social media. We are still too under-equipped there, we need to create transparency. I want to know the algorithms that Facebook, Twitter and others use to prioritize messages or gut backwards. And we need to discuss how to ensure diversity of opinion. On television, newspapers and radio, there are laws that regulate that all parties are given a decent place in the election campaign. Why do we not have these laws for digital media today? There too, it must be regulated that everyone has a fair chance of getting in touch with citizens when the election campaign takes place. And we may also need regulations to ensure that citizens are informed by the state in times of crisis. Last but not least, the classic media, publishers are disappearing, they are increasingly losing strength, financial strength, they are being taken over by Russian investors, by others who have political interests and do not have publishing interests. That is why we need to discuss the transparency of media ownership. We need an annual report on media independence — including in Hungary, so that there is no doubt that we need this strengthening in all the states of the European Union. We need common standards and perhaps also consider whether we can strengthen the public media even more. These two points are necessary, they underline the European principle today. But we need to strengthen them again so that the future of Europe is guaranteed. (Applause)

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome. I am Portuguese and I could tell you about a happy story, which is the relationship between our two peoples, but I am here to speak on behalf of the Socialist and Democratic Group. First of all, I would like to tell you that your commitment and Luxembourg's commitment to the European project are highly appreciated. You have just demonstrated it again in a very clear way. Luxembourg is not only at the crossroads of Europe, it is also the cornerstone of European integration. This vocation is known, respected and highly appreciated. I would like to take this opportunity to draw your attention to the state of Europe and its future. It is true that we have had a difficult time, a period of crisis, and today we have a more positive feeling. But what is happening in Italy now shows the fragility of our situation and shows that Europe, as it operates today, has serious failures. This is the situation Italy is experiencing, lacking hope in the future, with a sense of asphyxiation, because we have not been able to manage the migration crisis together and because we have not really overcome the crisis in the euro area. This has resulted in an explosive combination, with regions under great migratory pressure and, at the same time, a very high rise in unemployment. Therefore, Italy is faced with a very difficult choice: to accept Europe as it is, with its shortcomings, or take a step towards the precipice, in other words, exit the eurozone or even the European Union. However, one cannot put a country in front of an impossible choice. The only way out of this impasse is to make Europe work much better for its citizens. That is the issue. Prime Minister, there will soon be a decisive European Council. Everybody knows that. There will be both the reform of European migration policy and the response to the euro area crisis. Therefore, the first question I ask you is whether we can count on you to live up to the situation. Because, in two days, the European Commission will present a proposal aimed at supplementing economic and monetary union on the budgetary pillar. It is certainly good to make progress on the pillar of Banking Union, but that is not enough, because Economic and Monetary Union must be given a real budgetary pillar that supports investment, which supports economic and social convergence. We cannot continue in a situation where, on the one hand, some of the euro area members do not have a real chance to invest in the future and where, on the other, Europe as a whole has a problem of underinvestment in the future. So my question is: can we count on you to make progress on this issue, knowing that we must not only create an embryo of budgetary capacity, but also play with the financial leverage of the European Stability Mechanism, which was to be put in a Community framework? This is our preference. I have another question. While it is true that Europe is facing a situation of underinvestment, it needs an ambitious investment strategy driven by the sustainable development goals and commitment to the social pillar. But this requires a Community budget that is up to the tune. However, we may not have it due to lack of resources. So my last question is: with regard to resources, is it not time to take a step towards own resources which should include not only the Commission's proposals but, in our opinion, a real digital tax? We must make progress on this point. We can no longer accept that our internal market will be used by large companies without tax commitments. Therefore, Prime Minister, we expect you to take a courageous step, because without a Europe that works better, the Italian case risks staining oil. This is our concern.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. It is not as good as Europe is portrayed here. The European patient is ill, and before a doctor recommends therapy, he first makes a diagnosis — and this did not happen this morning. I fear that the recipe for more Europe adopted this morning will give the European patient the rest. The dramatic increase in right-wing populist, far-right parties is also the result of too much Europe. And Brexit — for me the biggest catastrophe in recent years — is also, at least indirectly, a result of too much Europe. It is a good thing that you are going to point out that the British all want to be Luxembourgers now — but, Prime Minister, I would have expected you to point out what this means for Europe, that there is a country here that is as tall as if 9 to 10 other European countries were leaving Europe at once. The state crisis in Italy is also a consequence of too much Europe — at least the euro. You pointed out that the internal market is somehow related to the euro. I'm sorry, this is nonsense. The economic development of non-euro countries over the last 20 years in the EU has been much better than the development of the countries that have the euro. “Buongiorno”, one can only say. There is no country in Europe at all that suffers from a one-size-fit all currency as Italy. Prior to the introduction of the euro, Italy was still a country with a 6% global market share. Today, this share has shrunk to 3%. The country is overindebted and youth unemployment in Italy is an absolute disaster. While Italy is suffering from a currency that is far too strong in its view, German industry is experiencing a huge export surplus due to its view far too weak currency. Prime Minister, you rightly pointed out that, fortunately, you were not influenced by the turmoil of war and post-war — or you did not have to experience them. It was different for me: my father stayed in the war, we were bombed out twice, and I am glad that we have had peace in Europe for over 70 years. But this has nothing to do with the euro. That's because of the democracies! There has never been a democracy that has attacked another. That is what we have to cultivate — but not the euro. Quite apart from the fact that Germany is not in a state of war with the non-euro countries, I would like to point out what the euro is doing at the moment: anti-German slogans are currently being used in Italy. Why? It is quite clear: because here the euro repeatedly forces the potentially largest creditor — Germany — to regulate the potentially largest debtor — Italy. Mrs Merkel was not elected by the Italians. After Greece, Italy is now clearly showing that instead of subordinating different economic cultures to the needs of a single currency, we should ensure that one currency corresponds to different cultures. Instead of constantly trying to tell Italians how to remain competitive in the world market, we should leave it to them to decide whether they do it with labour market reforms, with devaluation or with a combination of both. The last elections in Italy clearly show that more and more Italians see it that way. In response to the question by the two Italian Members of this House, Marco Valli and Marco Zanni, ECB President Mario Draghi referred to this — and I quote now: “In the event of a withdrawal from monetary union, Italy will have to settle all its liabilities with the ECB beforehand.” Italy's exit from monetary union, but at the same time it also suggests a solution to the Italian problem: if you leave monetary union — and I say this as a German — Italy should also receive financial support, and that would be a long overdue balance sheet adjustment for us. Finally, a sick Italy in monetary union is not as good for everyone as a healthy Italy with its own currency.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I remind you that we must conclude the debate at 11.30. Please respect the times assigned to you because the more you speak the less other colleagues speak, thank you. On behalf of the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe the word to Mr Verhofstadt.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr President, first of all I want to say to Mr Henkel that when he says democracy is important, naturally democracy is important, and democracy is important just because of Europe. When there was no European Union, there was authoritarianism, despotism in Europe, fascism in Europe, Nazism in Europe between the two World Wars. And it is since we have the European Union that we have guaranteed democracy in the European Union. That is what we have achieved. That we have achieved. (Applause) And I am very glad that the Prime Minister talked about press freedom and values because at the moment there is a problem in Europe, let's say it: values are threatened. We are outraged at the assassination of journalists in Malta or Slovakia, but then we must be consistent, Manfred, we must dare to react against states such as Mr Orbán's Hungary, such as Kaczynski's Poland and Malta and its corrupt political system. We must dare say that it's enough, that it's not that, to be European! That is where the source of our problems lies. We must have the courage to say so, to stop the Orbans of this world, the Kaczynski of this world and those who think that a corrupt system, like Malta, is a good system to fuel a country's income. Thank you for this vision, Mr Bettel, which we hear from time to time, but not enough, in this chamber. Above all, thank you for the role Luxembourg plays, because whenever we need to find a compromise to find, Luxembourg is there, together with my country and others, to try to find solutions to move forward, while sometimes it is the big countries that pose problems, let us say so too. Mr Henkel spoke about Italy. It is not that the Italian crisis is exceptional. In any case, this is not the first time that there has been a crisis in Italy, Mr Henkel, it already existed before the euro, the political crisis in Italy. There are also political crises in other countries. See Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany. The formation of a government in these countries has nevertheless taken some time in the past more or less recent. The real problem I want to stress here is that whenever a political crisis affects an important Member State of our euro area, it immediately turns into a crisis throughout the euro area. Interest rate differentials are widening, deficits are rising, banks are struggling, and ultimately the economy and confidence collapse. Why? Why, when there is a problem in one of the Member States of the euro area, especially if it is a large Member State, why are there problems at the euro area level in general? But for the simple reason that our single currency, our monetary union is unfinished! That is the reality, Mr Henkel: monetary union is unfinished. Indeed, the euro is the only currency in the world behind which there is only a monetary authority, the European Central Bank, but no political authority and no budgetary authority. This is the real problem! It is from this point of view, Mr Henkel, that we must analyse the Italian crisis. The reality is that we manage monetary union with an intergovernmental contract between the 19 euro area Member States, and when there are political problems in one of these Member States, all other euro area Member States are automatically affected. We must therefore break this logic, and to break this logic, we must not go back, Mr Henkel, we must go ahead! And moving forward, this means that we must implement and put into practice what all the reports of the OECD, the IMF, the European Central Bank, the European Commission and the European Parliament recommend, namely that a government for the euro area, fiscal capacity for the euro area, a finance minister for the euro area must be implemented and put into practice. and that there is a need for a full banking union and a parliament. And that is my second message, Mr Henkel: why we don't have it; it is absolutely needed now, and I ask Prime Minister Bettel and the President of the Commission to make that the first priority. That does not mean that the Member States do not have to do their homework. What you are saying is true. Between 1970 and 1996, in fact the competitiveness of Italy was as good as that of Germany, and their export figures were as good as those of Germany. But it is not because they entered the euro, because they did not make the reforms that were necessary, because in the past they could do devaluations of their own currency — and that is no longer possible. Are you defending devaluation as the way to avoid reforms in a country? Who is paying? Mr Henkel has no problem with it — his income is sufficiently high, he has no problem — but ordinary people with pensions, with savings: their income is reduced and they are paying the price for devaluations. So that is not the solution. The solution is reform, and what Italy has to do is what France has started to do — reforms, reforms — and then Italy will be saved. That also means solidarity in the European Union, from north to south. Germany has to accept the proposals of Emmanuel Macron and of the Commission on the reform of the eurozone. Mr Scholz, your Minister of Finance, has to follow Mr Schulz and not Mr Schäuble, if I can say it in one sentence, and there also has to be solidarity from the south with the north. If tomorrow there is a trade war with Trump, we have to be behind German industry, even German cars. When I was young I preferred Alfa Romeo, I have to tell you, to BMW, but nevertheless I think we have to stand in solidarity. That is my message, and that is also the message, dear Xavier, that we want to hear from the Council. Start — this is the most important thing — the reform of the governance of the eurozone, certainly now that the problems have also started in Italy. (Applause)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr Prime Minister, welcome to this House. The Grand Duchy of Luxembourg has always shown a strong commitment to the European Union, and the speech you have just delivered here confirms this commitment. In particular, we share your idea that peace is not trivial and that it is never definitively achieved. We really share the idea that the definition of our sovereignty is increasingly being built through and through the European Union. We also share this idea of a free, strong and open European Union and your willingness to accelerate its construction rather than slow it down. A few days after the entry into force of the famous General Data Protection Regulation, I would like to remind everyone that it was under the Luxembourg Presidency that agreement was reached on this pioneering text, which, moreover, was put on track by former Commissioner Viviane Reding, also from Luxembourg. And you will allow me to claim the pride that it is a green minister of your government, Félix Braz, who concluded the negotiations with Parliament's green rapporteur, our colleague Jan Philipp Albrecht. We are also pleased to note that, like your Irish colleague who opened this round of debates in January, your government has moved forward the values of equality and, in particular, women's rights. This is all the more remarkable given that within the European Union some Member States want to go back in this area. I am also pleased that your government has given the ecological transition a greater place in public policy. I would like to stress the positive role played by Carole Dieschbourg at the Paris climate conference. Very logically, on the climate front, your government supports the position of the European Parliament, which is much more ambitious than that of the Council and the Commission. On this ground, you engage Luxembourg in renewable energies, but also in a spatial planning policy that respects our common assets: soil, air and water. Similarly, while the Grand Duchy has been the unglorious protagonist of the LuxLeaks saga, I am delighted that it is now supporting the draft European directive on the protection of whistleblowers, which are so essential to our democracy. And you see where I am going to come because, as European ecologists, we are globally proud of the European and national achievements of the government in which our Luxembourg friends work, there remains a big black spot that separates us: taxation. Since the 2013 Offshore Leaks revelations, a litany of scandals have revealed how the world's largest companies and fortunes evade and defraud taxes. Of course, the Grand Duchy is not the only player in this senseless tax competition between Member States and Europe against the rest of the world. But it is difficult to deny the responsibility of your country, especially alongside its neighbours in the Benelux. The European Commission has made no mistake in recently pinning Luxembourg for its aggressive tax practices. Our wealthy Belgian families know something about it, who have housed no less than 48 billion euros in your country by creating mailbox companies there. And many of our Red Devils, our footballers, did not hesitate to transfer a large part of their advertising revenue to Luxembourg to benefit from your regime, far too lax, in terms of intellectual property protection. The Grand Duchy's European tax action is also largely disappointing. When your finance minister does not play the clock to delay the introduction of a tax on digital giants, he is failing to block initiatives in favour of the interests of the European taxpayer — those taxpayers, as Manfred said, who do not have the opportunity to play one state against the other — in particular the introduction of a public reporting, country-by-country, for multinationals or the implementation of a common consolidated corporate tax base. In short, your opposition in principle to any form of tax harmonization, citing the fact that this would mean a reduction in the taxes, at a time when multinationals almost do not pay for it — we are talking about an increase in taxes, indeed, and it is necessary and justified — is unworthy of a country that claims to defend the European project. I would say that from the country with the highest per capita income in the entire European Union, I think that Europeans could wait for a hand outstretched rather than a closed fist. Prime Minister, I would like to conclude by dedicating my speech to Camille Gira, your Secretary of State for Sustainable Development, who passed away on 16 May. He has been a pioneer in political ecology in your country, in particular by transforming his village of Beckerich into a showcase of ecology, with 100% renewable energy, but above all with unprecedented citizen participation. Its model of ecological transition by citizens has inspired many green agents across Europe. He will miss ecology and we will miss it. He was one of ours.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (NL) Mr President, a warm welcome, also on behalf of our group, to the Prime Minister of Luxembourg, Mr Bettel. I must say, however, that I am rather disappointed by your superliberal speech, because people's real question is really not how well multinationals are doing. The real question of people is: who have the power in Europe? Are they the Heads of Government, is this Parliament, or are they the multinationals and the large financial institutions? If you look at the developments of the last few days, weeks, in Italy, you can see that the financial markets also have a lot of political influence. When you say 'reduce tax', we see that the multinationals still have a great deal of influence on you every day. And it is surprising that the President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, has given us the good advice on tax avoidance, because in view of the previous discussions — and Mr Juncker's personal involvement — we had a different expectation. But he's right. It is precisely on this point that the citizens of Europe are extremely concerned. If you, as Heads of Government, allow yourself to be led entirely by multinationals, by large financial institutions, by banks, what can you expect? Then people start to become anxious, then they are indeed victims of extreme groups, especially on the right side. I think there is a factor that I haven't really heard you about at all. That is the growing inequality in Europe. Okay, in Luxembourg, income is high. But I can tell you that in many Member States, inequality between haves and port ots is increasing on a daily basis, and they see that in the European Union there are stories — like yours — that we need to reduce taxes on multinationals. How do you think that would happen in the difficult neighborhoods, in the cities? How do you think that will happen to young people in southern Europe who do not have a job? How do you think that happens to elderly people in Greece who have barely retired? That is hard language, it is a language that undoubtedly plays into the hands of populists in Europe. The European Union has a task here: to combat inequality, as organisations like the OECD say, as organisations like the IMF say. If you do that, if you, as Heads of Government, take your responsibility there, then you will do the best, including with a view to the European elections. I think there's a few things to do. You're not the only one. We have in the Netherlands a Prime Minister, Mark Rutte, a good friend of yours, who has had to admit that the dividend tax is being abolished under pressure from the multinationals. A measure which no one understands, which does not do any good to the economy, but which benefits the friends elsewhere in the world of the shareholders and the multinationals that represent it. This means that ordinary people are with higher VAT and have little and less social benefits. And then Mr Rutte says, like you, that taxes are reduced. I would like this to be a subject in the Council of Heads of Government and that, instead of serving multinationals and banks, the citizens of Europe and especially those who are struggling to return to the centre. You will then be a European, and otherwise you will simply be an extension of the multinationals.

name: Laura AGEA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, Mr Juncker, this series of debates on the future of Europe is likely to become something else, a debate on the past, failures and the mistakes that led the EU to collapse. If we go on like this, if you go on like this, there will be nothing left to debate. One thing is for sure: Europe's future will have to be very different from the present. Just these days a founding country, Italy, is experiencing dramatic moments. We were close to realising a dream, but we could wake up inside a nightmare. Nearly twenty million Italians, in elections on March 4, rewarded two political forces that would give birth to the government of change. Our goals are a law against corruption, putting hand to golden pensions, taking power away from lobbies, eliminating privileges, putting citizens at the centre. But this seems to not be possible: a well-orchestrated palace maneuver, with the complicity of many, from finance to strong powers, is preventing the birth of government, and just in these hours it would like it replace with an unvoted, unelected government, and that won't even have the confidence of Parliament. I ask you: is this democracy? And all this has happened with the complicity of the EU. You tried it in every way and at all levels. How can we not remember the warnings and threats of the European Commissioners? What a shame! What a misery! Even yesterday, Commissioner Oettinger told a German TV, except later apologising, that the markets will teach Italians how to vote for the right thing. You got it right: markets will teach how to vote. We are outraged and upset, and it must not be a German Commissioner to say how Italians or other European citizens must vote, either today or ever. I say it again, what a shame and what a misery! But you see, we're not even surprised. On the other hand, this European Commission has done everything but the interests of the citizens, as Mr Juncker clearly shows, its history. You have put us through as modern barbarians inside the walls of Rome, like those who want to destroy the European Union, get out of the euro, drown the markets. No, that's not the case! Yet, I address you, fellow Members, our work here in Strasbourg and Brussels is clear and evident in everyone's eyes. We tell you this clearly, once again: we do not want to destroy the European Union, nor the euro, nor the markets. Is Europe's future at risk? Yes, and it is not because of our fault, but because of this present bankruptcy that you have built. And come out of these palaces, listen to the cry of the citizens, do not be deaf, it's up to you to do your homework. Where are the eurobonds? Where are the tax transfers between surplus countries and those in deficit? And the unacceptable surplus on the current account of Germany and Holland. I take advantage of the presence of the Prime Minister of Luxembourg, Bettel. Why are there still tax havens in the eurozone? The present which is not working asks us to Europe, but the future must be — the citizens ask you — the future will be Europe if we call into question those treaties that see it succumb, if let's re-discuss austerity, crazy immigration management, big trade deals that hurt citizens in favour of multinationals. The Europe of the future is not the one that cuts citizens' pensions with one hand and with the other increases by 6% those of the European institutions. The Europe of the future respects the popular will and does not allow the vote of citizens to be trampled by the rating agencies, banks or the special interests of some State. Yes, it's true, you still won today. Enjoy these moments! Courage, liberists, go celebrate with the sneer and ignorance of the first of the class. You see, it's only a matter of time, and then the government of change will be born in Italy, and then more will be born across Europe. This is the one great future that we imagine for Europe: change, there is nothing but change.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, the future of Europe will be bright after the collapse of the EU, and we are now witnessing the death struggle of this failed project. We see it in the elimination of the freedom of speech and the demonisation of political opponents and the acceleration with regard to the EU army. We see it in the acceptance of state violence against the people of Catalonia and the opposition against democratic governments of Poland and Hungary and the sabotage of Brexit. We see it in the creation of an enemy image of Russia and of the United States of America, a long-standing ally. These are all rearguard actions of a union which already failed. Turning the EU into a Soviet-style empire will not avert its inevitable end, and it’s already showing widening cracks. It’s a union that consists of irresponsible liberals in the west and of realists in the east; of dictating money-suppliers in the north and suppressed receivers in the south. It’s a union of happy migrants that profit from our welfare state and miserable citizens who are just good enough to pay the bill but are silenced about their grievances. This union creates more problems than it solves. We have seen a debt crisis, a migrant crisis and now a crisis in political freedoms. What started as a project to progress peace through trade has deranged into a suppressive, totalitarian instrument of a globalist elite. The last fundament off this bankrupt union is the unlimited printing of money by the European Central Bank. Imagine the shock when Italy was about to install a eurosceptic government, and there again the EU showed its ugly face of dictatorship. It denied the Italian people their rightful government. This union that has sold his soul to investors in the Middle East cannot last and should not last. Turkey is turning into an Islamic society and Erdogan is overturning the achievements towards a secular state. Journalists, professors, military personnel are being jailed. Christian property is being seized. Genocide is being committed on the poorest part of the population. And firmly stands the EU to protect? No, not the values of human life, not the freedom of the secular state and rule of law. No, it stands firmly to let Turkey become a member of the EU. In the UK, Muslim grooming gangs have abused hundreds of children. They were abused, raped, some even killed, and although the authorities knew about it, they were reluctant to act – and when it finally blew out in the open, they tried to cover it up. In Germany, Sweden, the Netherlands, hundreds of young girls are victim of grooming gangs – and where is the protection of our children? Where is the outrage in the EU? It’s not there. The EU does not and will not protect our children; instead it sacrifices them. The EU elite welcomes these child rapists and still does. Honest and strong men like Tommy Robinson are silenced and thrown in jail to be murdered by inmates. That is the true character of the EU. The EU has no right to a future. The EU has no future. The future of Europe is to the nation states and its people.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr Prime Minister, the future of the European Union is uncertain as long as there are views such as those we are hearing here today and, above all, as long as actions like the ones we have witnessing over recent years have been committed. The European Union is trying to drown out any different views that support national policies by baptizing them populist, eurosceptic and extreme. What happened a few days ago in Italy is essentially a coup d'état with the support, if not the guidance, of Berlin and Brussels and dissolved the last pretexts that the dominant political class has been trying to keep. No, Commissioner Oettinger, the markets will not teach Italians how to vote. You, who are appointed and not elected, must learn to respect the verdict of European citizens. It seems that democracy is only good when the citizens do not decide to turn against your wishes. Today Italy is simply the last link in this long chain of anti-democratic interventions by the Union. We all remember the unacceptable and clearly blackmailed attitude of the institutions against Greece, against the will of the Greek people, as expressed in the referendum of July 2015. We also remember the ongoing attempt to overthrow Brexit, as well as the pressure that many are trying to turn into sanctions against Poland and Hungary, simply because the people decide differently from the plans of the Brussels nomenclature. With behaviour like this, you can rest assured that the days of the European Union in its present form are numbered and you will bear the burden of your responsibility. Finally, Prime Minister, if you would be so kind as to inform me, always in the context of European solidarity, when the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg will be transformed into a normal country and no longer be a tax haven, a refuge for the profits of large multinationals to the detriment of the other peoples of Europe?

name: Xavier Bettel
text: Prime Minister of Luxembourg. — (FR) Mr President, I would like to thank all the speakers on this first round of table First observation, on which I would like to stress: some say that Europe is going wrong, that it has already experienced better times. Yes, we have already had more glorious times, and I must tell you that Brexit is a cost for all of us. As for wanting to condemn voters for the choice they made — and that is the same thing for Italy — would be a second mistake on our part. The British chose Brexit. I regret it, but I have to respect that choice. The Italians voted for what they voted, it wasn't my favorite choice, but I have to respect it. To condemn this choice and say that they have been wrong, that we want to teach them and that we, as Heads of State or Heads of Government, you as the European Parliament or as a Commission, must tell them what they have to do is not understand them and push them even more towards the extremities, whereas it is towards the center that it is necessary to try to bring them back. Yes, as Luxembourg Prime Minister — a position that has a longer life than in Italy, which is going to have its fourth Prime Minister in five years, while Jean-Claude Juncker has held this post for 19 years — I think we simply have an obligation to show what works as well. I have experienced Brexit, I have experienced the situation with Greece, I have experienced the refugee crisis, I have experienced situations for which, it is true, we have not been able to find solutions right away. Someone said this in this chamber about the crisis of immigrants and refugees: yes, we need a common solution, we need a common immigration policy. We will not find a solution as long as we believe that everyone needs to do their individual calculation and solve this problem individually. We have to do this in common. Some say that Europe is over. Let's stop doing the siren of the national thinking we'll come to a solution. This will not be achieved at the national level; only together can we do it. Mr Henkel referred to the fact that there was never a war. Today, in Ukraine, we have a conflicting situation that is still tense. Whoever thinks that Ukraine is settled, is wrong. But the only document, the only text, the only commitment I have today is that of the Normandy format, drawn up by the European leaders around the table. They were the ones who obtained commitments from the Ukrainian and Russian side. Without the European Union, I do not know where Ukraine would be today. So let us stop saying that without Europe there would be no peace. At the time, in 1945, who would have thought that 12 years later, in 1957, we would be around a table and that we would create something or want to build something together? I would like to remind you that Ukraine is right next to the European Union and does not know peace. Mr. Lamberts, let me begin by thanking you for the tribute you paid to Camille Gira — it is true that it was a shock to all of us — who was Secretary of State in my government, who had a heart attack while presenting his most important text in his legislature, which was environmental protection. For those who did not know it yet, I would like to say that the choice of the Greens to replace Camille Gira has been on your neighbour, who will leave your assembly and with whom I am already looking forward to working in my government. You and others here spoke of Luxembourg as a tax haven. Have you seen the legislation that has been drafted over the past four years? Have you read the OECD reports? Have you read the European Commission's reports? Look at the texts opposite and you will find that today's Luxembourg is no longer on a blacklist of international institutions, that Luxembourg is considered compliant, that we have done what we had to do and that the directives that had to be transposed in the field of transparency, exchange and collaboration have been transposed. For those who don't know, I want to send them a note with all the texts and all the efforts that Luxembourg has made. And let me also quote the latest studies carried out by the European Commission: 'The Commission takes note of the positive step taken by Luxembourg'. In this regard, we can mention the next transposition of a directive which will, if necessary, increase the effectiveness in the fight against aggressive tax planning structures, etc. If you think that these are mailboxes, come and see companies in Luxembourg, especially those of more than 2,000 or 3,000 people who are work in the digital sector. Mr President, I think it was Mr Lamberts who said that the Luxembourg Finance Minister was blocking some progress. We don't block to block, believe me! GAFA is not a Luxembourg file, far from it! Let us not forget that tomorrow Britain will no longer be in the European Union. It is very good, today, to make short-term calculations and say that yes, it is great, such a company leaves London and will move to Paris, Frankfurt, Berlin, Amsterdam, Dublin or Luxembourg. We look forward to it. But I do not want Britain tomorrow, or already today the United States, Asia or Hong Kong to become shelters for companies leaving or leaving Europe, because Europe applies taxes that do not exist elsewhere. Therefore, let us act at the OECD level. We know that the OECD is working on this, so let us have the tools we want, but at the widest possible level. Nobody talked about the financial transaction tax. Nobody touched on this topic today. If some want this tax, let them apply it. In Luxembourg, we are not against this tax, but let us apply it at an international level. Let's stop wanting to penalize our own continent! Europe is between Asia and the United States, two blocks that are our direct competitors. So let's do something on our side for our attractiveness, for our industry, for our economy, for our finances. Therefore, I want to tell you that Luxembourg fully agrees — and everyone has said it here, be it Jean-Claude Juncker, be it you — to impose the GAFA. It is not acceptable that companies do not pay taxes. We are the first to say they have to pay for it, but let us try to prevent them from going elsewhere on this continent tomorrow to escape tax and our country from losing jobs and tax revenues. Mr. Weber spoke about the rule of law and freedom of the press. These are fundamental elements of our European Union. If we believe that freedom of the press or the rule of law are ancillary, would we reduce Europe to what? Just finance? Just to the economy? Just free trade? In 1957, the basis of the European Union, which I described to you earlier, was to want to bring peoples together, to get closer, to have values to share. These values, they were not pecuniary, they were also human. I know that there are discussions at the European Council level, and you will surely have some here about the Structural Funds. Should the Structural Funds be linked to this point as well? I just want to warn you. If it is done only in a certain country, its leader will say: “I no longer have Erasmus grants, I no longer have aid for farmers, Brussels has decided”. Do we not risk provoking a reaction that will be contrary to what we want? In other words, the leader of this country will have even more ease, in his capital, to explain to his farmer and student, to the one who hitherto received European aid, that he will no longer have them because “Brussels” decided that it was not in line with what they, the Brussels-people with whom he has nothing to do, have in mind, because a particular beneficiary does not fit into the scheme imposed by 'Brussels'. I'm a supporter of other systems. When something doesn't work, it's because our rules are not good. We see today that Article 7 does not work because we need unanimity. If they are two, there will always be one that will support the other. I think it is better, in this case, to tell the politician who arrives at Brussels will not have the right to vote at the next European Council. Or we have to find rules that hurt politicians, those responsible, so that they themselves say that, given their decisions, given the state of the situation in their country, that they are punished, but not their people directly, because we risk strengthening the anti-European sentiment among this population. As far as the rule of law is concerned, I know that the European Commission has threatened to refer the matter to the Court of First Instance and the Court. I hope that this is not going to happen, and I trust Frans Timmermans to continue explaining to the countries concerned that the rule of law is something very important to us. A number of parliamentarians talked about social Europe. We are not talking enough about social Europe. It is a Liberal who tells you that. There is not enough talk about social Europe. One of the causes of Brexit, one of the causes of the rise of some anti-European parties, is that citizens feel that Europe is not touching them. That is why we must explain today that, thanks to the Posting of Workers Directive, we are trying to create a more social Europe with a number of points. You know that President Juncker is very committed to social Europe. I am very pleased that in Gothenburg we had a meeting with European leaders to make progress on this issue. Forgetting social Europe would be as serious as forgetting that we have a Europe of values. We need a social Europe as much as a Europe of values, a democratic Europe. Someone also talked about foreign policy earlier. Europe must have a foreign policy if it does not want to lose its place on the international stage. As a continent, it represents the most important economic force in the world. But I have the impression that we have complexes. If a continent says something, we, as a European continent, are reduced to react. We do not anticipate. European foreign policy is essential if we have the ambition to make ourselves heard on the international stage in this area. I think that the move to majority voting will be necessary. Today, any country can block any progress. If we are unable to agree, it is not possible that 500 million citizens will be deprived of a common position because one country has decided to block. Today we are caught in vice. The greatest fear of our citizens is insecurity, it is Iran, it is what is happening in Syria, it is what is happening around us. If we ourselves are unable to have a common position and say what we want to do, we have already lost all the place we intend to have in a debate dealing with the stabilization of international relations. With regard to investment and reform of the euro area, we believe it is important for Parliament to play a central role, particularly in the redesign of the euro area. But to say right now that we need a euro area minister or not need one is the same as institutional issues, nobody asked me about it. What matters right now is having a euro working. Mr Henkel criticised the euro, but I think that without the euro our situation today would be more delicate. But we agree on an analysis, Mr Henkel. If Italy is doing well economically, it is good for all of us. If Italy is not doing well economically, it is not good for this country, but it is not good for any of us either. In any case, I would like to thank you for this first round of questions. Again, those who think that they have before them a Europhile who finds everything perfect, who lives in a dream or who imagines that everything is going well are mistaken. I have very diverse origins. Most of you don't know. I have a Russian grandmother who was Orthodox, I have a Polish grandfather who was Jewish, I have a Luxembourg grandfather who was Catholic and a French grandmother who was an atheist. Today my husband is Belgian and I am free to speak in front of you. Without Europe, I might not be.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, I want to raise a point of order, not about the debate, and I would like to thank the Prime Minister. I want to ask you to prepare a statement for the plenary at 12.00, as President of the Parliament, on the arrest of Bill Browder in Spain on a Russian arrest warrant. I think that Europe has to react to this immediately. An American citizen, who is in fact fighting for justice in Russia, cannot be arrested in Europe based on a Russian arrest warrant. We as Europeans were always at Bill Browder’s side from day one in this case, the Magnitsky case. Mr President, I would like to ask if you could prepare something for 12.00.  It is better to ask this now than at 12.00.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thanks for the proposal. Let's now move on to the debate. Please respect the scheduled time, one minute for each MP, for catch the eye. Hon. Gardini. “Catch the eye” procedure

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the Prime Minister of Luxembourg, he has made some very shareable speeches, also expressed closeness to Italy and understanding for the passing moment. I share what you say with respect to the need for a stronger Europe, more competitive than countries and the challenges that other major economies throw at us. But I wanted to ask you: you do not believe that the economic crisis in 2008 highlighted the need for this European Union, which in its time has abandoned a harmonisation project in some way fiscal, in order to limit itself instead to the coordination of both fiscal and social policies, and which has therefore been limited to a government of differences, has somehow laid the premises for so much dissatisfaction, distrust, but above all suffering of so many citizens, businesses and families? He does not believe that it is time to remedy these negative effects that this tax competition creates, to correct existing distortions, that precisely this tax competition within the European Union causes? We see it a little bit every day.

name: Mady DELVAUX
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, you are at the head, a country that is traditionally pro-European. Luxembourg knows what we owe to the European Union, peace, security and prosperity and, as a small country, we need to be part of a larger set to defend our values and interests in a globalised world. It is therefore logical that you call for greater unity and solidarity, and I support you in this call. Solidarity is indeed the binder of the European Union.
