It is at this cost that we can move forward to reduce inequalities between countries, Member States and regions. But I think that words and actions must also be coherent. Solidarity should therefore also be expressed in everyday issues, other than those of migration. Should Member States, and therefore also Luxembourg, placed before the choice, not, if necessary, place European interests ahead of national interests?

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - Mr President! Following the announcement of the UK's exit from the European Union at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we have a series of debates on the future of Europe with the participation of the presidents and prime ministers of the Member States. We hear about many ideas for sanctioning our organization — most often technical ones. But you need to pay attention to the basis, which is the foundation of the European Union. It's no doubt the Christianity that the founding fathers alluded to — Robert Schuman, Alcide De Gasperi, Konrad Adenauer. Today we only hear about the Communist-Altiero Spinelli, who demanded the liquidation of nation-states. And the other thing — democracy. The talk was about internet companies. If we enter the password “democracy deficit” into the Internet search engine, the European Union pops up. Even George Soros, a friend of the commissioners Mr Juncker and Mr Timmermans, said publicly after the UK referendum that the European Union was a flawed construct. So it needs to be fixed by giving a vote to citizens of member countries who will not be hassled or even terrorised by Brussels officials.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: — Mr President, Mr Bettel, you talked about the Erasmus generation. There are many deputies who have also been in Erasmus. I will also ask you a European question concerning the fight against tax evasion of multinationals and unfair competition. After LuxLeaks's revelations that unveiled some very advantageous tax arrangements, the controversy over tax benefits granted to certain companies was central. At the time when Mr Juncker was Prime Minister, Luxembourg was systematically obstructing the progress made by the Task Force on Taxation within the European Council. What is your position today? I would also like to remind you of the fundamental role of the European Parliament's TAX committee, which has issued a recommendation on the protection of whistleblowers. You talked about freedom of expression, but the two whistleblowers tried in Luxembourg are symbols of the lack of protection for whistleblowers in Europe. In April 2018, the Commission published its draft directive on the protection of whistleblowers. What will be your proposal within the European Union?

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President! Mr Prime Minister, I have listened to your comments and ideas on the future of Europe with great attention, and it all sounds nice and good at first, but it is still very contradictory. On the one hand, you are talking about tax fairness, and on the other hand, we know that Luxembourg's corporate tax policy is futering huge tax dumping competition in the EU. And even if you do not like this word, this tax dumping, as a consequence, has a negative impact on the day-to-day living conditions of the majority of people in Europe, because their daily lives lacks the money for investment in schools, kindergartens, education, research and health. You say that Luxembourg has done its homework in tax matters. But on the black list — to give you some examples that this is not the case — Luxembourg has opposed the zero-percentage criterion, has turned against the public register in the fight against money laundering, and has taken action against public land-to-country reporting to prevent tax avoidance. I wonder, and I ask you, how this contradictory behaviour should be in line with the expectations of the future of Europe that you have presented.

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, you have listed several things that you believe are the main ones in the European Union. I repeatedly point out that for decades — 60 to 70 years — the European Union has faced a democratic deficit. And that is the European Union's main problem. That's why people don't go to the polls, why they can't identify with the European Union. It is high time that we started thinking about an alternative, a different arrangement of the European continent where there will be no democratic deficit, an arrangement with which citizens can identify, and it is this is another alternative alongside the five variants presented by the European Commission, which we could discuss, but which all continue in the future with a democratic deficit. It is necessary to start a debate about the real alternative. I sent out a text a few months ago, where I described one variant of what Europe might look like in an alternative arrangement. I wanted to thank you because your Foreign Office replied to my initiative and at least indicated that in Luxembourg there is the greatest willingness to talk about alternative arrangements of a European continent where there would be no democratic deficit, where democracy, the rights of citizens, their democratic right to vote just by an institution such as the European Union, which to them makes it impossible to democratically influence what is happening in the European Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr Prime Minister, welcome to Parliament! You mentioned in your speech that national sovereignty is part of globalisation. Given that globalisation is based on the dissolution of states and nations, I consider that your position is contradictory. Do you think that in future the European States should become vassals and operators of world government or something else? You also said, quite rightly, that there must be security at the external borders. But how can this be achieved when this competence has been removed from the external border states and has been entrusted to Frontex, whose mission has failed miserably, as the facts so far have shown? How do you think that the European Union should address the issue of illegal immigration as a whole, so that Greece will cease to be a place for the collection and permanent establishment of illegal immigrants? By the way, how many illegal immigrants does Luxembourg host? What do you think Europe's future will look like when the principle of unanimity is abolished and Europe becomes a two-speed, three-speed or more Europe? Finally, what are the relations between the Europe of the future and an Islamic Turkey?

name: Viviane REDING
text: — Mr President, first of all I would like to say that the Luxembourg Prime Minister has been very committed to the answers he gave to parliamentarians. Thank you. Yes, Luxembourg has always been the engine of the European Union from the foundations. Yes, Luxembourg has been a pioneer when you think of the euro, when you think of Schengen. Luxembourg has always been this indispensable link to create a bridge between German ideas and French demands. So, I ask myself the question: “Is he still?” Because we'll need him to be. The Prime Minister has talked a lot about the progress of the past — they are remarkable — but we also need concrete progress now. It was said here in plenary, “Action, action, action”. So this is not what we have done well in the past, but what we are going to do concretely in the future. Here, I would like to hear from Luxembourg — which in the past has always put forward cutting-edge ideas — what it proposes to reconcile conflicting proposals. Luxembourg as an engine, we need it again today.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, first of all, thank you for appearing before us today. As this is a debate on the future, I would like to refer essentially to young people and I welcome, first of all, their commitment to the Erasmus programme, which you yourself have lived through. I am also glad that the multiannual financial framework presented to us by President Juncker at the beginning of the month provides for a significant increase in funding for this programme. But I also think it is necessary for young people to know better, in schools, the background, objectives and functioning of the Union's institutions. You cannot value what is not known. And I therefore very much welcome the fact that on 22 May the Council adopted the Commission's recommendation on the promotion of common values, inclusive education and the European dimension in education. This European subject, if I call it, seems very convenient to me and I very much welcome this initiative by Commissioner Navracsics. Secondly, I would like to point out a serious problem that already affects Europe as a whole today: low birth rate, ageing and therefore a future with fewer young people. We have before us a demographic winter, which is already a present in some regions, and what I would have liked is that in the multiannual financial framework the demographic issue would have had a little greater weight in the allocation of funds between regions. I would like you, Prime Minister, to share with us some thoughts on these issues relating to young people and demographic decline.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, it is excellent that this Parliament is discussing the future of Europe. Whether we like it or not, our countries are interdependent. We have to find common solutions to common problems. But there is one government that is conspicuously absent from this debate – that from my own country. There is not even a single Conservative MEP in this debate today, and that is a shame. It is also striking that in the Brexit negotiations, two years after the referendum, the British Government still has no opening position on what it wants to secure in terms of customs relationships. We have a White Paper that is promised for next month – two years after the referendum. Frankly, what is happening is that the Government is discovering that you cannot distance yourself from your neighbours and your main economic partners without paying a terrible economic price. But if you remain close, then of course, you have to play by the same rules as everybody else – without, if you are no longer a member, having a say on those rules. This Government, with its deep ideological divisions, is incapable of finding a solution to this dilemma. It is time it made way for a government that will be constructive and find a solution.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Mr. Chairman, Dear Mr. Prime Minister Bettel, thank you for your contribution to the important debate on the future of Europe. I am pleased that you are decisively advocating the involvement of citizens in this dialogue. I believe that this ambition you share with French President Macron is truly sincere and that citizens will increasingly be asked about the direction in which the European Union is heading. Unfortunately, that this is not so, the reactions to the elections in Italy where European issues have been in focus are also shown. The democratic will of the Italian people is once again wanted to suspend, and some senior European officials openly support it. Such irresponsible behavior creates additional distrust of citizens in state and European institutions, which will eventually lead to the collapse of the whole system. This system of parliamentary democracy of ours, ladies and gentlemen, without citizens and their trust cannot exist, no matter how many may wish it. Let's always keep that in mind!

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, your country's tax policy separates us: you can say that it is not a tax haven but, in fact, it attracts multinationals who take resources from many countries to balance their public accounts, invest in their public services and therefore it is a matter of justice tax. The non-protection of alert launchers separates us: it is not fair that Raphael Halet and Antoine Deltour should be persecuted by justice. You have defended freedom of the press very well here. You must also defend those who risk their lives in the name of the common interest. His vision of migration brings us closer. Your country is the most emigrants host to the European Union. The largest of these communities is from my country, Portugal. In recent years they have faced many difficulties, particularly in access to education and the question of the Portuguese language in schools. Your government sought a solution to this problem. I ask you to keep that commitment. You know how important the Portuguese community is to the economy of Luxembourg.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, congratulations on your speech. You are one of the youngest heads of government in the European Union and the representative of an influential country, one of the founding countries of the Union, and your support for European integration is very important. I have seen you for years at LYMEC meetings, and I know that your commitment to European values is sincere and strong. I appreciated your support for cohesion policy. This policy has brought concrete results for European citizens. The Commission proposal is good and balanced, and for my country, Romania, it will remain a very effective tool to clear the differences between the poorest and more developed regions of our Union. Referring tax, tax avoidance is compromising the future of our European Union. It's about tax fairness. As President Juncker and Manfred Weber, Chair of the European People's Party (EPP), stated, it is about contributing to the national budget in a fair way, so I would like to ask Prime Minister Bettel if European citizens can count on his support in moving Europe forward to a fair, sustainable and modern tax system.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Prime Minister. I do not like Luxembourg because of the many gas stations or cheap cigarettes — Luxembourg is a beautiful country, and Luxembourgers are an open, friendly people. But why are many headlines about Luxembourg not so kind to the people of Europe? I quote Commissioner Moscovici, who said in March that tax practices in Luxembourg undermine fairness and a level playing field in our internal market. And according to Le Soir, the hundred richest Belgians park 48 billion euros in their jardin fiscal. These contradictions call into question our common Europe as a whole among many people. My question to you is therefore: how do you intend to contribute to more justice in your country, to fair taxation in Europe, to a better life for everyone in Europe and not just for a few better earners? More specifically, do you support the Commission's proposal on a common tax base and country-specific reporting in the Council so that we can finally pull together within the EU on this point too?

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Mr. Chairman, although we refer to European values, it seems that we do not all inherit them in the same way. There are significant differences between new and old Member States, both in rights and standard. Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria are still waiting for entry into schengen and the right of freedom of movement has not been achieved for our citizens. Products of lower quality arrive on our market, so one might think that we are viewed as second-class citizens. It is dangerous and humiliating because what is not good for you is not good for us either. The big challenge for all of Europe is migration and the security situation, but no one is doing anything to stop the radicalisation happening in the heart of Europe. Our European values are seriously questioned, and most of all we are responsible for this, because by passing laws against life, against family, against our Christian roots, we do not contribute to our own progress but rather the opposite.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, as the fight against climate change is a major challenge for the world as a whole, but also the European Union, I believe that Luxembourg's leadership in the Council of Ministers in promoting an energy transition towards clean energy is very positive and can be strengthened by the incorporation of Claude Turmes to the Council of Ministers. I encourage you to continue in this direction in order to achieve greater penetration of renewables into the next directive. But it is true that, knowing the multiannual financial framework and, yesterday, the proposals for the Cohesion Fund, and the demographic decline being precisely one of the important challenges facing the European Union, I cannot understand how the depopulation criterion is not part of the criteria for redistributing resources and so put the spotlight on an important challenge. Of course, Prime Minister, I would like to invite you to take this criterion into account: therefore, reinforce the objective of depopulation as a priority in the Council of Ministers of the European Union.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Prime Minister Bettel for his very constructive speech. Prime Minister, I would like to ask you very directly: are you are willing, and what are you going to do inside the Council? Because the Member States are quite often the most difficult part of the integration process to work towards a better and faster integration of the EMU area, including monetary union, banking union and economic governance. Are you willing to act in favour of the social dimension to be included in the EU competencies, as proposed? And are you willing to work to include better taxation governance, including the common corporate tax base and also the proposals of unfair tax competition between the countries? Last but not least, is of course the refugee politics.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: — Prime Minister, welcome! I'm going to ask you a question I asked to the previous leaders we had here before us. It is about the future of Europe, and you mentioned it in your initial intervention. You talked about energy security. In the Eastern Mediterranean, the European Union is shaping an energy strategy. The Commissioner responsible is here, even though he is speaking with a colleague of his. The energy strategy of the European Union in the Eastern Mediterranean is focused on the Republic of Cyprus and Turkey has intervened with its fleet and hinders the energy planning of Cyprus and the European Union. I want to hear your position. What should we do? Are we going to proceed with sanctions? Please don't pretend you didn't hear the question. Leaders are different from politicians because they have positions in difficult times.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, Prime Minister Bettel, among the many issues that have been addressed, and sharing the fact that Europe should be reformed, but strengthened in its own right. construction, I think there is a central theme, certainly that of cohesion policy, but also and above all that of trade policy. We have approved in this legislature, this season, two measures that are extraordinarily relevant and central to our industry, for our small and medium-sized enterprises, for the protection and defense of thousands of jobs. I am convinced that this process should be better and more strengthened in a concept of liberalisation, but of pluralism, but surely, also and above all, of rules that must be in the WTO safeguarded. We're going through a season of duties starting at Trump, with China's unfair competition. Our workers, our small and medium-sized enterprises want concrete answers, that is, they want this Europe to be close to them with the facts. I do not believe demagogism, I do not believe populism, I believe in content, I believe the quality of government action, but I also believe and above all in a Europe that overcomes the selfishness of the Member States.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, I share with you the idea that unanimity is essential for an effective foreign policy. You said that Europe's policy for peace is a weak policy by unanimity. I ask you whether you do not think that same unanimity is an insurmountable obstacle to fair taxation in the European Union, to sustainable taxation with the internal market. Do you not believe that there is a need to overcome unanimity in order to be able to obtain mechanisms in tax matters to overcome the existing disloyalty between States in the area of taxation in the area of harmonisation of taxation? You say we have to wait for the world to advance on this matter. But then we will never move forward, because the construction of the welfare state is precisely the consequence of some countries starting as avant-garde, as we did with social security, progress towards justice. Today we have fair social security because a hundred years ago we made just that avant-garde advance.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: — Sur President, fadal issa anqas minn sena fejn i家-ittadini kollha fil-pajjiżi tal-unjoni Ewropea jkunu qed jivvutaw gЂall-elezzjon ta' dan Il-parlament Ewropew. U hemmhekk tkun qed issir mistoqsija wada: kif il-futur tal-unjoni Ewropea jorbot mal-futur ta' hawk wieed u wada go? Gthe alhekk, ma nistax ma nilqax ir-referenza li gShoammel il-prim Ministru tal-lussemburgu gShoad-dimensjon sothe jali. Kif qiegohuda L-unjon Ewropea mhux biss tikkrea x-xogol, imma anki tiggarantixxi l-kondizzjonijiet adegwati tax-xogthe ol? Kif qiegЂda L-unjon Ewropea tares lejn iż-żgЂażag, li galija mhumiex biss il-futur tal-unjoni Ewropea imma il-preżent tal-unjoni Ewropea? U hawnhekk meta nitkellmu, Sur President, dwar il-futur, il-futur irid ikun marbut ma' viżjon, u l-viżjon bilfors hija bbażata wkoll fuq il-valuri tagna, li huma r-rutagthe. U gatmosalhekk ir-referenza, iva, gЂat-twemmin tagЂna fis-saltna tad-dritt, il-libertà tal-istampa li wkoll hija l-garanzija ta' kif nikkomunikaw b'mod ckieles ma' xulxin.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, foreign direct investment in your country is worth trillions, much more than what the rest of the world’s governments together state that their citizens own in Luxembourg. In Luxembourg, cash is king. Over the years, EUR 500 bills were printed as much as in Belgium, Ireland, Netherlands and Spain combined, until printing was stopped this year, but the bills are still circulating. So, don’t you worry that your country is seen – and it may be working – as a world centre for money laundering and tax evasion, namely for tax dodgers from other EU Member States? Will you then stop the race to the bottom in taxation, will you stop blocking tax harmonisation in the EU and will you support CCCTB? Why is your Government delaying the VAT reform proposed by the Commission to stop carousel fraud, which shifts EUR 50 billion per year into organised crime, including terrorist groups? Why do you continue to obstruct media in your country from finding out what is going on in Freeport Luxembourg?

name: Franck PROUST
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, I understand that you share this ambition to make the European Union more asserted itself in globalisation. Although she has always been an actress of trade, there are some recent signs that Europe could become a mere spectator. We therefore need strong support from the Member States, and I say well from all Member States, regardless of their interests, because our common interest is to act to ensure that Europe is the engine of controlled and fairer globalisation. On the filtering of foreign investment, for example, which we voted the day before yesterday, here in the parliamentary committee, we are ready to discuss with the Council pragmatically and effectively. I hope that the seriousness of the European Parliament on this technical subject, but above all political, will lead the remaining Member States to convince the Member States of the usefulness of better understanding what is happening in terms of investment on our continent. Prime Minister, take this opportunity to equip Europe with a tool that will fill a vacuum in its internal market, a tool that will simply protect our strategic channels, our businesses and, of course, our jobs.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, what do you think of the proposal to reduce aid granted under the common agricultural policy and cohesion policy for the countries of Central and Eastern Europe? Luxembourg is a founding country of the European Union, it is an important country. Do you not believe that this will create a divide between Western Europe and Central and Eastern Europe? What is your policy concerning the Schengen area? Because we Romanians have been waiting for ten years. We spent EUR 500 million to secure our borders and we are still not admitted into the Schengen area.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, good afternoon. I am as free to address you in Dutch as Benelux, and I may say that you have said little or nothing with which I do not agree to prove that the Benelux Alliance is closer than ever. You referred to the social dimension, which must be strengthened as one of the instruments to make it clear that we, the European Union, also protect people. That is at the heart of your speech, respect for that. You have pointed out the importance of strengthening European defence, small Member States — Luxembourg, Belgium, the Netherlands, others — so I think we should support that too. Then the digital single market. I'll touch it for a moment, because Mrs. Vestager is still in the room. We recently met with the CEO of Facebook. It has left a daring aftertaste and made it clear that — our President Weber said it at the time when he spoke with Mr Zuckerberg — that Facebook monopoly must be put to an end. I refer to Mrs Verstager: she has the power, she has the competence, she also has the guts to do so. I wonder if you — if she intends to tackle that monopoly — would support it.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, I am pleased with your intervention and the answers you have given. I want to refer to a statement: 'Citizens demand an open and tolerant Europe'. I would also add “fair”. Of course, the citizens of my country would like to live like in Luxembourg. The problem is, and the question to you is: do you think that the cohesion funds and the strategic investment fund had the best criteria and social cohesion has been reached? What do we do with these disparities? How can we have a united Europe, which you have spoken about, and I want it, as long as we have so much difference in the quality of people's lives? People are disappointed. We need to give them a message, as you said, that we can have social support and that needs a lot of fairness. Would you like to stop being unanimous in the Council? He wants a very clear answer, because, behold, Romania and Bulgaria are not in Schengen precisely because one or two are opposed and it is not normal to have two Schengen markets in a single market.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, personally I am sick to death of listening to leaders of groups, parties and governments laying all their ills at Europe’s door, when they themselves haven’t the courage of a mouse or the common sense of an imbecile. Thankfully, Prime Minister Bettel is not one of those, and I commend him on his courage and his good sense here today. He made one very important statement. He said ‘shared sovereignty guarantees our own sovereignty’, and I want to ask him how come the smallest Member State can have that attitude when a big Member State like the United Kingdom has to say that they are losing sovereignty and they must ‘take back control’? Have you not lost control by being involved in the European Union? What is the secret, when the smallest country can feel empowered and enriched, and the big countries, with all their influence and all their MEPs, feel the opposite. There must be a secret. Can you tell it to us, please?

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say to the Luxembourg President, of whom I have listened with great commitment and interest to the speech, that the debate on the future of Europe these days, in my country, Italy, is red-hot. It's not just hot, it's red-hot. And on this idea of Europe you can play destiny not only Italian, but European. As pro-Europeans, we democrats are convinced that there is no future for Italy except within this context, of which we feel protagonists, not a side part. However, it is clear that in order to be truly European, we must build Europe on a day-to-day basis. One day it is not possible to declare oneself pro-European and the next day to be anti-Europeans, anti-system, anti-euro, “anti-thats”, and light fires. That is why I want to reiterate here that Italy, whose constitutional foundation we hold firm and the clarity of our position within this Europe, is a country that will work day by day to day to strengthen this institution, in order to make it closer to citizens, not to markets, citizens, their needs, and that is why we want a Europe that is more united, more supportive and more social. But this we do it every day, coherently, like other political forces in Italy, but not like the ones that take down the system one day and the next day say they want to build it. No, with those we're not going to go ahead, either in Europe or Italy.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Prime Minister Bettel and Luxembourg for this very constructive approach. I am sorry to disappoint you, but transnational lists are not the solution for integration. I am a federalist and I can tell you that there is no federation where there is a global constituency, so this would be something against federalism, instead of the contrary. I saw with some optimism that you defended tax harmonisation and tax convergence here. I would like to ask you if the Luxembourg Government is prepared to take a major step on this issue because Luxembourg, together with two or four more Member States, is a country that is really responsible for blocking and paralysing any tax convergence. Let me tell you that tax convergence and tax harmonisation are much more important for European integration than transnational lists.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, Prime Minister Bettel, you heard in this debate on the future of Europe words of recognition to Luxembourg, a founding country of the European Union from which great figures have come from its construction. A small country, of the smallest; but I have not heard a single word about the ravages of inequality, not precisely between big and small — caused by crisis — but between rich and impoverished, between creditors and indebted. And it is imperative, given inequality, that, when you talk about taxation, you do not talk to us about lowering taxes, but about ensuring and not stopping until Luxembourg cannot be the deposit of the unlawfully acquired fortunes of the corrupt people in half Europe; and that, when you talk about resources for the European Union, express your willingness to contribute more — as a weish country — to building a better Europe than this, because that will be the key to combating the unrest and populism that have redefined the political landscape of those most impoverished by the crisis — Italy, Greece, Spain — because, without tackling that problem, there will be no future for Europe.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The Greens group has exhausted all the speaking time because it was taken by the chairman of the group Verhofstadt, but as I try to be flexible, if the Prime Minister of Luxembourg has patience, now I would give the floor again to three Members, one from the Green Group and one from the EPP who had stayed out, then Mr Goerens, Mr in't Veld and Mr Virkkunen, and then we respond, but know that you had sold out. all your time. It is a matter for the group of liberals, choosing who to entrust the floor to, so this is a concession that the other groups also make to you, two minutes longer. Please on. In't Veld.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, indeed, Mr Verhofstadt will be slapped on the wrist. Mr Bettel, thank you very much for your speech. I agreed with a lot of it, but not everything. You said that institutional talks are boring. I actually fundamentally disagree because institutional talks are about who has the power. How can citizens influence and decide in the European Union? How can they hold their representatives to account? But it also determines the ability of the European Union to act, and we have seen that intergovernmental Europe is dead. Intergovernmental Europe is not able to respond to migration flows, to Trump, to the financial crisis, to conflicts in the world, and it is not able to ensure that the rule of law and fundamental rights are upheld in all the Member States.  One final remark. Please ask your colleagues to understand one thing. Yes, there are eurosceptics or anti-EU people in Europe, but there is also a vast majority of people who are actually supportive of the European Union. Let’s stop serving only the eurosceptic voices and also represent the people who wholeheartedly support European integration and make their voices heard in the debate as well.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, it is easy to agree with you that we need to strengthen Europe's competitiveness, economic growth and the internal market, because only with a strong economy will we be able to secure the welfare and future of the people in Europe. Certainly one of Europe's greatest, if not greatest achievements, is that we share an internal market of 500 million people based on common democratic values. I am very happy that you stood up for these democratic values, but the fact is that unfortunately some of the EU's Member States have begun to slide away from our mutually agreed values — human rights, freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law, to which all EU member countries are committed. We have not had sufficient tools to address these developments. Now the Commission rightly proposes, as part of the future budget, that in future EU funding could be tied to respect for the rule of law. You talked about this with some hesitation. It would be good to hear clearly now about whether Luxembourg supports the line that EU funding should be conditional on compliance with the common values of the EU. Isn't the minimum requirement for funding these states to follow legislation, common principles and values there?

name: Charles GOERENS
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, you rightly called for action by all Member States to move the European Union forward. Indeed, 28 are reaping the fruits of European integration, the citizens of the 28 Member States have benefited from the internal market, but we are barely half a dozen Member States sharing the burden of receiving refugees. On the other hand, many of us leave Italy, Greece or Germany alone when it comes to fulfilling the commitments made by all Member States under the Geneva Conventions on refugees. We are also far from unanimity when it comes to meeting the funding needs of our European Union for the years to come. This is disconcerting. Still, we are twenty-eight enduring a US president who is tackling all the achievements of multilateralism, common security, foreign trade and many international agreements. We cannot remain in inaction, otherwise we marginalize ourselves. I hope that on 30 March, the day after the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union, the 27 Heads of State and Government will be able to lay the foundations for a project incorporating the values of solidarity, which you have called for in your remarkable speech.

name: Xavier Bettel
text: Prime Minister of Luxembourg. — (FR) Mr President, if I understand correctly, I have 27 seconds left to answer 60 questions, so this is going to be a little limited. Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the many speakers who have asked questions about Luxembourg, and in some cases I will allow myself to answer them in telegraph style. But I missed one topic because very few Members have raised it, is digital. Some have talked about the future or questioned the challenges of the future, but very few asked me about the digital strategy at European level. But it will be a challenge, which today is economic, but it will be a social challenge tomorrow if we are not ready to make efforts at the level of the digital single market and if we do not reduce the divide in the digital market at European level with 28 legislations, 28 regulators and a common market that does not exist at this level. Tomorrow will be digital. I remember, when I was in the presidency, some MEPs asked me whether it was a chance to seize or a danger. It is a chance if we are ready and it is a danger if we are not. And we'll be ready only if we manage to make this deal at twenty-eight together. Mr President, some Members have told me about Schengen and the situation in their country in this regard. I support them in their efforts to join the Schengen area. I think they have a willingness to access free movement. But on the other hand, I must say that we currently have — both at enlargement and Schengen level — prerequisites which must push us to move forward quickly, so that these countries arrive in an area where the rules we give ourselves work. Today we do not have a common migration policy. For someone who is in the Schengen area, we do not have a rule, everyone has their own rules. So I would like to see people quickly come to have rules that work to explain to people that this Schengen area works. Because if the message is right, we enlarge Schengen, we enlarge the European Union, but if we don't try to make it work better, I do not know if the message will be properly understood. But we must, as soon as possible, open the Schengen area to these countries, as I have just said. Mrs in't Veld spoke about institutional issues. Do not take it wrong, Mrs in't Veld, but believe me, citizens are making fun of whether we have a finance minister or whether the President of the Council and the European Commission is the same. They don't laugh! Today they want to know how security works, whether tomorrow they can get a job, whether they have rights in their country, freedom of the press, freedom of expression. But institutional questions, whether we have transnational lists or not, is a bubble in Brussels, Strasbourg, Luxembourg. Be aware that it is really not the daily concern of most citizens and that they have other questions and expectations of the European institutions than to wonder how they will work tomorrow. We'll have to do it. And I think if we are more efficient, we will work better. But to believe that this is a priority is, in my opinion, not the right direction. We talked about the rule of law, and one Member of the European Parliament also talked about the Structural Funds. As I said earlier, I believe that linking the rule of law to the Structural Funds is likely to have an opposite effect. By stating that if the rule of law is not respected, the Structural Funds will be cut, we risk having on the backs of farmers, students, industries and workers who are working and who, today, can benefit from the Structural Funds. If we tell them “We will cut them tomorrow”, we will push them to the extremes, which will say “Brussels and Strasbourg have decided that we will not receive anything anymore”. I therefore believe that we must find more effective mechanisms that work, and, in fact, above all, punish politics rather than at the end, the citizen, because we would only reinforce him in his idea that Brussels and Strasbourg decide for him. You talked about Brexit. For Brexit, I hope we move forward. I had made a little description to explain how Brexit worked, starting by remembering that at the time they were in the family, They were in but they wanted to have a lot of opt-outs. Now they are out and they want a lot of opt-ins. It's reality. I think what's important is above all to keep a level playing field. It is not that we want to sanction Britain, but if today we tolerate cherry picking and Britain can choose the benefits without the constraints, without having certain obligations, we will favour a situation in which every state can say: I, too, want a Europe like Great Britain. Therefore, we must have common rules and we must tell Britain that we cannot have just one without having the other. Whistleblowers, we talked about them. Luxembourg is one of the first countries to have legislation on whistleblowers — it was already in 2011 — and the recent ruling of the Court of Cassation confirms the jurisprudence of the European Court of Human Rights. Some have talked about taxation. As I have told you, Luxembourg has made considerable efforts and the negotiations on the common base — some have also raised the question of corporate tax — within the Council are still very far from over. Many technical issues remain to be clarified, and we are also constructively involved in this work, particularly with a view to determining the impact of these two proposals on national budgets. You cannot say “We do it” without knowing what the impact will be. We need to have all the necessary information. But what has been very important for me is to know that substantial progress has been made in combating aggressive tax planning also at the internal market level. We are talking about social dumping in Europe, but we must also talk about tax dumping. I am the first to want to stop a race down where the challenge would be to know who will have the lowest rate in Europe. How do you want us to explain to our fellow citizens that some companies always pay less taxes? Earlier, Mr Weber talked about citizens. Of course, if we give citizens the impression that a society is not paying taxes when they have to pay taxes, we will once again provoke them. This will lead to a breakdown of politics, which will lead to political crises that we ourselves will have caused by accepting tax dumping. On the other hand, one of which is very little talked about is environmental dumping. Today, together with the United States, has decided to leave the Paris Agreement. Perhaps one day it would be useful to discuss the criteria for environmental lists and to draw up a black list of states that do not meet the criteria that are our heritage at home. Some people have said in this chamber — I think it was Mr Lamberts — that heritage is not bought in a supermarket. It's a common heritage. We speak “social”, we speak “tax”, but we often forget that there is environmental dumping today, because some countries do not want to comply with certain rules for economic reasons. Some have asked what my visions were for youth. I told you earlier, it feels like everything is granted. We have a problem at the political level. I often hear many politicians say that all that is going well is thanks to them, but when something goes wrong, it is Brussels's fault, when they forget that Brussels is themselves. They are the ones who sit on the Council, it is their country that sits on the Commission, it is their MEPs who sit in the Chamber. They forget that since the Treaty of Lisbon, national parliaments have more power. It is so easy to say, when it's wrong, 'it's the fault of... it's a directive, it is a regulation, it is Brussels that imposes it on on', whereas Brussels is Mrs Merkel, Mr Macron, or myself, it is the MEPs of their country and they are the Commissioners. But it is easy to reason as if Brussels was a bit like an alien with whom we have nothing to do with, and Brussels decides for us. You know, without wanting criticising colleagues in Britain is very hard, when we circulate a message from Monday to Saturday saying that we do not like Europe, to ask people on Sundays to vote for the European Union. I come back to the question of young people. They are the cornerstone of the European Union. We must ensure that young people are once again passionate about Europe. Erasmus is an important element. When I go to a school and talk about Europe, I explain that I knew the borders when I was a student in Thessaloniki and went to Turkey, or to the country whose capital is Skopje, or Bulgaria. At the time, there were borders that I did not know as a Luxembourger. As a Luxembourgish, I took my car, I didn't even know if I was in Germany, France or Belgium. I didn't ask myself that question. Today, a young person no longer knows that there were border crossings. He only knew the euro. He travels without a passport. He leaves without the need for Form E 411, the form we had at the time for medical care. Today I have rights abroad, I can go to study in another country, I can get married there, I can give birth, vote, work, retire, I can live in a Member State other than mine. I no longer pay roaming fees when I am abroad. All this is acquired. Today, young people do not realize that it is people who are at the root of all this. Recognition of diplomas is also one of these achievements. So let us remember what we have managed to build since 1957. Today, let me say again, the European project — which some here have criticised — is above all a peace project. Who would have thought in 1957 that we could put French and Germans side by side? That those who were killing each other a few years earlier would want to build a joint project? So, Mr President, I will put all my energy at the service of this European ideal. We have the impression that everything is granted, but believe me, rights, freedoms, peace have nothing obvious, nothing easy and nothing acquired. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thanks to Prime Minister Bettel for being with us this morning. The discussion is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. — As a continuation of its many years of prejudicial and purposeful practice, the European Parliament, in particular the LIBE Committee, is currently conducting a real campaign against Hungary, threatening to initiate the procedure under Article 7 of the EU Treaty. The backdrop of these attacks is, above all, the migrant pike. Who do you think, Prime Minister, is really offending our voiced European values? Who defends their own citizens and borders, Christian culture and traditions — or those who are prominent in facilitating the invasion of illegally invading Muslims instead of the legitimate interests of their European constituents? And what do you, Luxembourgies and other Western Democrats think of President Jean-Claude Juncker's scandalous performance on the anniversary of the spiritual father of mass murderous communist ideology, Karl Marx? On behalf of the hundreds of millions of victims of the Communist dictatorship and several hundred million oppressed, I ask you: Marx, with a huge statue from China's comrades, is it intended to serve Europe's value and future? Please take a position on this shameful matter before President Juncker personally demands the victims of Marxism in Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Yesterday Russian journalist and writer Arkadij Babčenko was shot dead at his home in Kiev. Babčenko was among the most prominent Russian war correspondents, he had to leave his country in 2017. He had been the victim of death threats and a social media hate campaign, unleashed against him because of his work as a journalist and political views. This vile assassination is a new, unacceptable attack on press freedom and journalists watching over our values and democracies. This Parliament calls for full light to Babčenko's death and that not only the material executors but also the perpetrators of this vicious murder be brought to justice. It is our duty to support the media's efforts in favor of freedom, including honoring the memory of journalists who paid their thirst for truth with their lives, such as Anna Politkovskaya, Daphne Caruana Galicia and Ján Kuciak. Until we find out who the killings of these two last journalists are, we will not remain silent. As for the retainer and subsequent release in Spain of Bill Browder, we received information, as requested by Mr Verhofstadt, but we also had positive news, it was stopped and then issued by the Spanish authorities this activist of British nationality. News reports that are available at the time indicate that Bill Browder had been stopped at first by Spanish police on the basis of an international arrest warrant, the catch was not later validated and Bill Browder was released back into freedom. I remember Bill Browder being the cofounder of the Russian capital management firm Hermitage, whose lawyer Sergey Magnitsky was assassinated in a Russian prison in 2009. In 2014, this Parliament adopted a resolution calling for sanctions against thirty-two Russian citizens involved in the Magnitsky murder for various reasons. We carefully follow the developments of the affair and are in contact with the Spanish authorities for more detailed information on what happened.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, it is an honour to welcome the President of Colombia, Juan Manuel Santos, today in Strasbourg: the first leader of Latin America to speak before the plenary in the last six years. Latin America must be put back at the center of our foreign policy agenda. Colombia has undergone a unique and historic moment under its presidency with very important achievements. I am referring to Colombia's entry into NATO — the only Latin American country to achieve it — the trade agreement concluded with the European Union, but above all, the historic peace agreement that you, President Santos, managed to conclude with the FARC after more than half a century of conflict. This earned him the Nobel Peace Prize in 2016. The European Union has always supported the peace process politically and economically. This will continue to be the case in the future. The first round of the presidential elections, held last Sunday, took place for the first time without violence. This is very positive. The European Union must be more present and contribute with investment and economic diplomacy so that no steps are taken backwards, to continue on the path of peace, economic growth and poverty reduction, because the stability efforts made by the Santos Government and the Colombians are at risk because of the worrying situation in Venezuela. Colombia, like other countries in the region, was facing the largest displacement of people ever recorded in Latin America; there was a risk that the situation would worsen and a real refugee crisis would be reached. The European Parliament therefore called for urgent assistance to the countries concerned and announced that it would send a delegation to border posts to assess the situation. Thank you, Mr. President, for your work. Now you have the floor. (Applause)

name: Juan Manuel Santos Calderón
text: President of the Republic of Colombia. — Mr Antonio Tajani and honourable Members of the European Parliament, I am very honored to address this international legislative body, the par excellence representative of European democracy, to discuss peace and its challenges. Last Sunday, just three days ago, the first round elections were held in Colombia to elect my successor to the presidency of the Republic. There we were accompanied by a multiparty committee of the European Parliament — made up of eight MEPs — and a mission of electoral experts from the European Union, who were able to verify the vitality, plurality and transparency that today characterize Colombian democracy. Two candidates obtained the majority of the votes, and among them Colombians will decide on June 17 who will preside over the nation's destiny until August 7, 2022. These were not ordinary elections, as were not the parliamentary elections last March. These are the first elections, after more than half a century, that we have without the threat and interference posed by the internal armed conflict with the FARC guerrillas, the largest and oldest in the Americas. They were also the safest, most transparent elections, with greater guarantees, with more observers, and most importantly, with the greatest participation in our history. Even my most staunch opponents say it. Seeing Rodrigo Londoño, formerly alias “Timochenko”, former FARC commander and today head of his political party, voting for the first time says it all. (Applause) That, ladies and gentlemen, makes a big difference, and that is why this time the candidates' discussions focused on issues such as education, health, pensions, citizen security or taxes, and no longer — as had happened for so many years — in the absurd war we were suffering. I am not here to tell you that Colombia has already achieved complete peace, because it is not the case. There remains the threat of a last guerrilla, much smaller than the FARC, the ELN, with which we are currently holding peace dialogues in Havana, and there are also organized crime groups dedicated to the dire drug trafficking business. But the achievement of the FARC's demobilization and disarmament, and its constitution as a political party — without prejudice to the fact that its leaders and principals must submit to a transitional justice process — has fundamentally changed our country's outlook and perspective. And whoever my successor is, this progress towards peace is definitive. It's irreversible. Not only because our own Constitutional Court ordered it, but because it is the word committed by the Colombian State. It is also a commitment to the international community. Never in the history of the United Nations, for example, had the Security Council unanimously adopted so many resolutions in favor of a process. Because, as Secretary General Guterres said at the last assembly, Colombia is the only good news the world had today. But it is irreversible especially because no one wants to return to the horror of war. Ladies and gentlemen, in a world where intolerance and confrontation between societies and nations remains a constant one, it is great news that in Colombia — a country with more than 50 million inhabitants and all the potential to make a positive contribution to humanity — an armed conflict has been brought to an end that left more than 8 million people victims and more than 270 000 dead. In a world where some continue to privilege the arms option over dialogue and coexistence, it is good to be able to tell you that the weapons that so many Colombians wielded against Colombians are now being converted into monuments to peace. Because without peace there is no society that can achieve real development. A little more than two weeks ago, in the convent of Assisi in your country, Mr President, in Italy, I had the pleasant opportunity to hand over to German Chancellor Angela Merkel the lamp of peace bestowed upon her by the Franciscan community, which protects Saint Francis of Assisi, the patron of peace of the Catholic Church. A recognition of high symbolism that I also had the honor of receiving the year 2016. And that day I recalled — as I would like to recall here today — the legacy of coexistence that the European Union represents for the world. Well, the Norwegian Committee summed it up when it granted you Europeans the Nobel Peace Prize in 2012: it said that its most important achievement — that of you — has been the successful struggle for peace and reconciliation, and for democracy and human rights. In this, Europe has been an example, and that example must continue to illuminate the path of humanity. Because only peace and reconciliation, only democracy and respect for human rights can counter the harmful influence of nationalism, fundamentalism, racism, populism and intolerance. (Applause) And I cannot imagine a better scenario than this to thank the European Union and the nations that make it up for their determined and permanent support for our peace process, and for this complex phase that we are now facing, which is that of the post-conflict. We are accompanied by the European Union in the search for the supreme good of any society, such as peace. And we greatly appreciate the work of your special envoy Eamon Gilmore, not only during the negotiation process but also now, in the implementation phase of the agreement. A year and a half ago, in Brussels, the European Union Trust Fund to Support the Post-Conflict in Colombia was created, with an initial capital of €95 million. Some 62 million euros have already been committed to various projects, such as the case, for example, the Nasa indigenous community in the south of the country, which already exported, thanks to this contribution, its first container of coffee to Europe. Or another project, for example, for smallholder farmers in areas recovered from conflict, who have been able to achieve bio-certification of their products, thus increasing their income by at least 15 per cent. The European Union has also offered €400 million of reimbursable cooperation through the European Investment Bank. And it has committed another €85 million in cooperation programmes for humanitarian demining, for sustainable development, for the fight against climate change, innovation, technology, education, human rights... Look at this very encouraging fact: thanks to the end of the armed conflict with the FARC, and to cooperation international that you are giving us, Colombia went from being the second country with the most victims caused by anti-personnel mines to today and the tenth. And we're going down. We have 673 municipalities planted with anti-personnel mines and we have already been able to declare 225 — the third part — as mine-free. You can't imagine what this means for the peasants of those sidewalks, who can now travel their land and work their plots without fear! And we hope to reach 2021 as a totally mine-free country. This is how we are moving forward — with difficulties, of course, but with firm step and with the European Union — in the construction of peace that follows the signing of the peace agreement. Because it is one thing to silence the rifles and stop bleeding and stop the deaths resulting from the conflict. And another, even larger task, is reconciliation of hearts and ensuring opportunities for progress for millions of families who suffered the consequences of violence. Only in this way can a stable and lasting peace be consolidated. And for this purpose you, Europe, have been a great ally of Colombia. Thank you for your accompaniment! Thank you for your support! Our country offers the international community, in retribution, a successful model of the peace process. In a world full of unresolved conflicts, Colombia's peace process has become a laboratory that can be useful in attempting solutions in other scenarios. Ours was a sui generis process because it was not limited to establishing the conditions for the end of the armed confrontation — as is the usual — but focused on asserting victims' rights, the rights to truth, justice, reparation and non-repetition, and implementing — and this is very important — development in the areas most affected by the conflict. That is, more than an end of war pact, it was a pact of humanity and development, a fairer, more inclusive development that focused on the victims of that war. The peace agreement establishes a comprehensive system for the fulfillment of victims' rights, including a Commission for the Clarification of the Truth, a Unit for the Search of Missing persons and a transitional justice system that — experts say — is a model for the world, being the first time that a peace settlement has been made under the umbrella of the Rome Statute. And, in any peace process, one of the most difficult aspects is to harmonize society's demand for justice — that is, sentiment — with society's desire for confrontation to stop. The eternal dilemma between justice and peace! Our challenge was to achieve a transitional justice system that would guarantee maximum justice without sacrificing peace, respecting our Constitution, respecting our international treaties, such as the Rome Statute. And I think we've made it. Colombia is now warning a new dawn, a much better future without the burden of armed conflict. But we know it's just the beginning of a long way. In addition to the implementation of the end-of-conflict agreement with the FARC — which is in itself long and complex — we have another challenge ahead, an immense challenge: building peace in the minds and hearts of Colombians, who are used for so long to hate and disqualify the adversary. We are grieving by the murders of social leaders, human rights defenders, representatives of victims, ex-combatants, which have occurred after the signing of the peace agreement, and I would like to assure you here that the Colombian State is committed to clarifying these cases and to curbing this situation. We created — and it is working — a National Guarantee Commission, which I myself chair, to coordinate actions to protect communities and their leaders among the various institutions. Forty per cent of the cases reported to the Office of the Attorney-General have already been clarified and we are determined to continue to make progress to punish those responsible and that no more murders occur. That is today our greatest challenge as a society: to learn to recognize the other, learn to live together within the difference, to learn to process disputes without violence, something you — in Europe — have made positive progress in. I am optimistic, because I know that the values of unity, love, tolerance, compassion are more powerful than the countervalues of fear, hatred, revenge, exclusion. This is a universal truth, applicable not only in Colombia, but throughout the world, for example, in the fight against terrorism or managing the migrants' crisis. I said that when I received the Nobel Peace Prize and today I want to repeat it in this emblematic auditorium of a continent that has given the world a lesson of unity within diversity. Human beings have to understand that, beyond all differences, beyond all nuances, in the end we are one people and one race: of all colors, of all beliefs and all preferences. Our people, ladies and gentlemen, is called the world. And our race is called... humanity! (Applause) I cannot fail to refer to a problem that concerns us all: drug trafficking. The Colombian conflict would have ended much earlier without the fuel that was meant by the illicit drug business. This cursed business is behind violence, corruption and crime almost all over the planet, and we have to recognize that the so-called “war on drugs” — which has been declared in the United Nations itself for more than half a century — we have not won nor are we winning it. I say this as a representative of a nation that has perhaps been the biggest victim of this bloody business, which took away our best soldiers and policemen, our best judges and journalists, great political leaders. The way in which the war on drugs is being waged is equal or even more harmful than all the wars that are being fought together in the world today. That is why not only is it indispensable, but it is reasonable to change our strategy. We need to find ways to hit more effectively the strongest links in the drug trafficking chain, the big mafias, those who launder assets, those who produce inputs, rather than continue to chase farmers or addicts themselves. There are more people in U.S. prisons for drug-related crimes than all those in Europe's prison population. Anti-drug policy with an exclusively punitive and repressive approach has failed. Until we find more effective common strategies, the drug business will continue to undermine the health of our young people, the morale of our societies and the governance of our countries. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have come to Strasbourg, to the seat of the European Parliament, to share with you the reality of Colombia and to thank you, heartily, for your support for our present and our future. Between Europe and Colombia, there are increasing ties and fewer barriers between Europe and Latin America. August will mark five years since the implementation of the EU-Colombia Free Trade Agreement, which has benefited our economies and strengthened our trade and investment ties. And I also want to thank and acknowledge the big step taken in exempting Colombians from the Schengen visa requirement, which has contributed to more tourism, more business, more integration between Colombia and Europe, and more dignity for Colombians. I give you only this fact: while in 2015 340,000 Colombians traveled to Schengen countries, last year more than 550,000 did so. That is the world we want: a world with more bridges and fewer walls, a world of solidarity where friendship flourishes, where cooperation flourishes, a world of open arms and hearts. And speaking of cooperation and integration, this afternoon, in Paris, I will sign with the Secretary General of the OECD, in front of President Macron, the agreement that protocol the decision of this organization to admit Colombia as its thirty-seventh member. (Applause) This is a very important achievement, which I share with the European nations that endorsed and supported our income, and that will ensure that our country meets the highest standards in governance practices, economic and social policies. We are also the first Latin American State to become that category called 'NATO's global partner', which tomorrow I will also formalize in Brussels. And I give my successor, in just over two months, a country without armed conflict with the FARC; a country with less poverty, with more equality, with more jobs, with more and better education, with a health system that now has universal coverage, with much better infrastructure, and a country committed to taking care of our extraordinary biodiversity . And how good to be able to leave this legacy! And I conclude by recalling Robert Schuman's words in his famous 1950 declaration: “World peace cannot be safeguarded without creative efforts comparable to the dangers that threaten it.” In Colombia and in Europe we are making these “creative efforts” and that is why I am here today, before you, to ratify our willingness to work, to work for peace, but above all to say thank you, thank you very much! , to the generous European people. (Long applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much, Mr. President. When Members get up, the message is very clear. Thank you for being with us! (The meeting was suspended for a few moments).

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: — Mr President, I would like to ask for a minute's silence. I will ask for a minute of silence, because today is the funeral day of little Mawda, who was killed by a bullet fired by a police officer in Belgium on Thursday, May 17. All the light must be shed on this atrocity, responsibilities must be established and justice must be done. But today, I think we must take part in this grief and show our respect to Mawda's parents with a minute of silence. At the moment, in Belgium, a white march is organized to accompany the family in their mourning, Mawda's mother, father, brother. We cannot be with them, but I propose that we show our respect to this family by a minute of silence.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: As usual, I take note of your request and also of the consent that a part of the House has given to your request and send it to the President of Parliament, because so is the custom.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: In relation to the decisions of several committees to initiate interinstitutional negotiations pursuant to Article 69c (1) announced at the opening of the sitting on Monday 28 May, I have not received requests for a vote in the House by a number of Members or one or more political groups equal to at least the average threshold of 10%. These committees may therefore begin negotiations.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: — Mr President, yesterday's vote on the proposal to revise the Posted Workers Directive, it was not clear what exactly was being voted on. Therefore, in accordance with Article 184a, I wish to raise a procedural objection to yesterday's vote on the revision of the Posted Workers Directive. The president has bewildered indicating the vote in a way that has led to 37 corrections so far in the ballot from colleagues across political factions, an unprecedented number of corrections. Despite the controversy of the proposal and the alert from a fellow EPP, he did not change his position immediately after the vote and did not repeat the vote. So, I think, it would be very good to repeat this vote.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, however, dear colleague, I must point out that the vote on the Morin-Chartier and Jongerius report took place in the utmost transparency and in compliance with Rule 59 of Parliament's Rules of Procedure, which provides that the provisional agreement takes precedence in the vote and is subject to a single vote, unless Parliament, at the request of a political group or a number of Members equal to at least the threshold low, i.e. 5%, decide instead to vote on the other amendments in accordance with paragraph 4. The request of the ENF group to vote on other amendments was put to a vote, this request was rejected and then the President put the provisional agreement to a vote, as provided for in the regulation. Let's now proceed with the votes.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the round of voting. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: rapporteur. — (PT) Mr President, I shall be very quick. In this report, we propose mobilising EUR 104 million for Portugal, Spain, France and Greece to deal with the damage caused by natural disasters, but also in this report we ask the Member States to do everything, to use all the means and funds at their disposal to act on the sense of prevention. Prevention is the best solution. In my country, in 2017, more than 100 people lost their lives in fires. This situation cannot be repeated and we must all work together to ensure that this does not happen again. In this resolution, too, we ask that the Member States that receive these amounts from the Solidarity Fund, which are proof of solidarity, in fact, to use them fairly, transparently and qualitatively.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr President! Dossier regarding the posting of workers is one of the most important dossier of this Parliament, this term. Many politicians built their election campaigns on this dossier. It is impossible to underestimate our votes, from which it follows that by mistake, by bad running the vote we voted wrong. Our adjustments, which until yesterday properly affected 37, and they affect further, are a serious twist in favour of the fact that we should reasumption of this vote. I, very much, of the Lord President, ask that this be the case.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I thank you for your comment, but the Bureau has already spoken on this.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: — I would just like to point out that a substantial part of the amendments to the report are not translated, so a significant part of this House cannot, in practice, express its opinion on their substance. I would like to point out once again this protest which naturally arises, I say, from the cuts in translation services and which shows the need to maintain this fundamental principle of translation of all documents in order for democracy to function effectively in this Chamber.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Look on Viegas that the documents have been translated, they are all available, so let's take note of your comment, but let's go ahead with the votes. — Before the vote on Amendment 41:

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, did I understand correctly that you said about the 170, first part, rejected? If that was the case I wanted to ask for a check.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: It's not that I said it, it's the verification of, say, the hands that have risen, now on the first part of 170, I'm willing to do an audit. So, let's resume from the 170, part one, the vote is open.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Mr President, the purpose of the three oral amendments which I am going to present now is to keep the report up to date and to reflect what has been negotiated this morning in the area of cooperation and information sharing as regards the negotiation and conclusion of international agreements. I am doing so on behalf of the two co—rapporteurs, myself and Mr Corbett. The first concerns paragraph 71, where the word ‘two’ is to be replaced by the word ‘three’. At the end of paragraph 71, once again, the following sentence should be added: ‘Notes the progress made so far and strongly insists that these negotiations should be concluded still under the Bulgarian Presidency’. The third is to delete the whole of paragraph 74.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, first let me congratulate you on your birthday. (Applause) I would like to propose an oral amendment, paragraph 86(a) (new). I will read it and I hope it’s self—explanatory: ‘takes due note of the Judgment T—540/15, De Capitani v European Parliament, which reaffirms that the principles of publicity and transparency are inherent to the EU legislative process and that no general presumption of non—disclosure can be upheld as regards legislative documents, including trilogue documents’.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you on. Hautala, thank you also for your affection, is there opposition to this request? No one gets up, then let's put it to a vote. (The oral amendment is accepted)

name: Nuno MELO
text: Mr President, briefly, just to say that my voting mechanism does not work very often and so I would ask someone to come here.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We ask the services to verify, thanks to the reporting.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: With this concludes the round of voting. (The sitting is suspended for a few moments)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Then colleagues, let's start with the declarations of vote, we have received numerous, the sitting can continue until 14.45, to allow the session to resume at 15 pm. All remaining statements of vote that cannot be accepted will be examined tomorrow after the vote. Any other declarations of vote may be submitted in writing.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: Mr President, the general policy of the European Commission to problems of unemployment or industry, such as global overproduction of steel and aluminum, has been to do nothing. In Spain, in 2009 the Directorate-General of Labour approved an employment regulation dossier of ArcelorMittal for 12,000 employees, which has been extended until the end of 2018. And all this, despite the overall benefits of this multinational: €3,670 million in 2017. The European Union's position should be to defend working people rather than the benefits of multinationals. We should protect ourselves from imports in order to have the capacity to build an alternative and sustainable production model. However, for the Commissioner for Commerce, there is no bad thing that does not come. You are taking advantage of the situation to negotiate with the US government again neoliberal policies, a new zombie TTIP. And without any transparency. And without any negotiating mandate from the Council. Because all they want to defend are the interests of the German automotive industry and the multinationals.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is the largest market for fish products in the world, fuelled largely by imports from third countries. Producer organisations play an essential role in these continuous exchanges through their production and marketing plans. Take an example: Italy. Italy is one of the countries with the largest number of producer organisations made up of artisanal fishermen. For countries such as Italy, therefore, the creation of targeted measures to control the access of the European market is an excellent opportunity for small fishermen to compete successfully with the products of the European market. imported or industrial fishing. Uniform requirements must be laid down for fishery products sold in the European Union, and Mr Engström's work goes in this direction, with the aim of allowing consumers to make choices informed and that they are no longer victims of improper labelling, as shown by various studies. For this reason, targeted measures are needed: for example, common marketing and control standards, with relevant penalties, also applied to conservation measures, in order to promote a market Transparent and quality. Market measures that increase the traceability of caught fish is required, and premiums and incentives for sustainable fishing practices. They are therefore well received priorities in the report which we supported.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Mr President, this report is very important because we must know where the fish comes from. In my country, Galicia, canned fishing is very important in representing the volume of production. As far as labelling is concerned, it is very important that the species, the area, the method of production and also the fishing gear appear. Unfair competition can no longer be allowed, but I also draw the attention of this Parliament to working conditions. According to this report, the European Union clearly has little credibility with regard to labour standards for fishermen in other countries, as it does not assume its international responsibilities within its borders. Many congratulations to the rapporteur on this report which is also very important for my country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, fishermen in Greece face a great many problems, mainly because of the anti-grassroots policy of the memorandum and, of course, they have now become poor. At the same time, however, they also face other challenges, as Turkish fishing vessels literally carry out piracy. Together with the protection of the Turkish coast guard, they illegally enter Greek territorial waters and fish illegally. This is happening throughout the Aegean Sea. It happens with great emphasis in the area of Imia, but also in the area of Thassos. Furthermore, another serious problem is the importation of Turkish fishery products, which are illegally caught, as Turkish fishing vessels do not comply with the standards and bans that exist on fishing matters. Thus, these catches enter the Greek market and the European market. It is unacceptable, illegal, and it must be stopped.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: — Of course, I could not support the proposal for the report on the future of agriculture. Mainly for reasons because he is under-ambitious because there is still too much room left to poisoning in agriculture with different pesticides and because we haven't taken a decisive step forward here. The other very important thing that convinced me about not supporting this report is, above all, that we are not protecting small and medium-sized enough farmers who are actually key to preserving our countryside. And if we only favor the big ones, then of course we will very weaken this agriculture market. Straight small farmers are the ones who put added value, who worry that of course local food finds its rightful place. And it is precisely the local food that we need to bring to the plates of the most vulnerable group, both children and patients, and the elderly.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
