text: Mr President, this report represents another attempt to resolve the squaring of the circle. It advocates important things that we point out, such as against nationalising the costs of the CAP, maintaining its budget, strengthening POSEI and protecting small and medium-sized farmers. Now, let us be serious, without putting the foundations of the CAP into question, this is another exercise of hypocrisy, because this model of the CAP, with its liberal orientation, is what supports this intensive production model geared towards export, agribusiness, and this model is the one that crushes prices and income of farmers. What we want is, in fact, a break with this CAP, with public instruments to regulate supply, which will enable each country's food sovereignty to be defended and, in turn, to guarantee fair and dignified incomes to those who produce, our farmers.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: — Sur President, meta nitkellmu dwar il-futur tal-agrikoltura u r-rabta anki mal-ikel, nafu, u hawn enfasi dwar, il-ħtieġa li jkun hemm remunerazzjoni xierqa u adegwata għall-bdiewa. Għalhekk qed nieħu din l-opportunità biex nagħmel appell lill-gvern ta' pajjiżi, ta' Malta, biex kull fejn jista', jara li l-prodott lokali, kif qed nirreferu għalih fir-rapport, u l-prodott frisk jintuża. Mhux kif sar dan l-aħar, fl-iskema tat-tqassim tal-frott u l-ħaxix lit-tfal tal-iskejjel, feud il-gvern, għal raġunijiet li jaf hu biss, bunch mar għall-prodott loci u frisk, għażel mod ieħor. U dan kien anki b'detriment għall-istess tfal fl-iskejjel, u b'detriment għall-bdiewa, li kellhom prodotti u trakkijiet sħata' prodotti li kellhom jarmuhom. Irridu niftakru dwar il-ħtiġijiet ta' pajjiżi żgħar, irridu niftakru dwar pajjiżi żgħar feud l-art agrikola dejjem tonqos u allura rridu nagħmlu anki inċentivi biex ikun hemm aktar użu tal-art għal skop agrikolu.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — The common agricultural policy is the oldest pan-European policy. Bearing in mind the turbulent times that European agriculture is going through and the uncertainty of European farmers and, in particular, Bulgarian farmers, I find the proposal to reduce the budget of the common agricultural policy dangerous. In this regard, I believe that the Bulgarian government should insist at least for maintaining the budget for Bulgaria during this programming period and I call on it to finally do so on the example of other Member States. It is time, however, to change the model of Bulgarian agriculture. The distribution of subsidies is not fair. It is not logical to subsidise grain production and vegetable production disproportionately, as it is at present. Agriculture becomes monocultural, the sector is not attractive enough for the young, there is no targeted policy towards mountain areas. The problem of land concentration is becoming more acute. Against the backdrop of all this, the reduced budget in the next programming period is not a solution and it is irresponsible to put up with it.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: — Mr President, the economic activity of the outermost regions depends heavily on agriculture. For this reason, in the European Parliament's position on the future of the CAP, which we are voting on today, the safeguarding of the POSEI budget and its regulatory arrangements should be emphasized. It is also worth noting that the outermost regions deserve differentiated treatment also with regard to the functioning of the milk market, and the Commission is asked to take account of indicators adapted to the reality of the outermost regions for the monitoring of milk prices and the definition of the crisis of the sector. To conclude, I advocate greater external convergence of direct payments between Member States in the first pillar of the CAP, the logic of which should exclude the amounts received by them under Pillar II, and so I voted.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while I recognise the need for each Member State to adapt the common agricultural policy to its own needs, I am very strongly opposed to the idea of nationalisation of the CAP. The current two-pillar architecture must be maintained, however, considering that the existing system for calculating direct payments in the first pillar should be modernised and replaced by a method of calculating payments at European level. The new CAP must be ambitious targets, it must ensure that the food produced is sufficient and safe, protect its competitiveness on international markets, protect farmers from volatility prices and market crises, support the family dimension of European agriculture and especially the new generations of farmers. In my view, the need to make farms more sustainable and fully involved in the circular economy and the promotion of innovation should also be among the priorities of the future CAP, of intelligent research and practices. Goals, however, can only be achieved with a sufficiently funded CAP and therefore without budget cuts.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it must be said clearly that cuts in agriculture, cuts to the CAP, are a great disappointment. I am a disappointment with the objectives which the European Union must have, namely strong and cohesive agriculture that can protect the agri-food supply chain, which has absolutely extraordinary added value, in particular in our country, in Italy. And I believe that these cuts do not benefit above all to quality agriculture, agriculture which must see a new frontier, that of young people, young people linked to a territorial identity, but above all to a brand identity, a guarantee mark that leads to kilometer zero, what we have always hoped for. So this Europe is not going in the right direction, especially for what happens, namely imports, particularly of agri-food products that need barriers, duties, I think of the rice that comes from Southeast Asia, which is likely to compromise traditional crops that, particularly in Lombardy, have a centuries-old tradition. And all this is accompanied by a series of, I would say, particularly damaging contrasts, such as Commissioner Oettinger's statements that aim to create even more disaffection in a state such as the our country, Italy.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, for many of us the detail in this report is important, but for farmers it is the budget to support the common agricultural policy which is vital. I quote figures from Irish agriculture from last year, where cattle and sheep farmers were entirely reliant on the payment for their income. What that means is that if they didn’t have the payment they would be working for nothing. It’s a very stark reality, and therefore we do have to press that the budget for agriculture is not slashed in the coming review of the Multiannual Financial Framework.  Added to that, we want to support young farmers. One of my concerns is that the young farmer payment goes to the landowner from whom the land is rented and not directly to the young farmer. That is something we will have to address.  On the issue of moving away from historic payments, which started in 2013, I expect the proposals due on Friday to continue that process and I look forward to the details.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, the common agricultural policy should be truly common. When I say this I do not only mean further integration and harmonisation of the rules, but also that the European Commission should overcome the silo approach.  Agriculture is also part of our development and cohesion, commerce and international trade. This is why I am very glad the report includes the opinions of numerous parliamentary committees. I wish the European Commission had a similar holistic approach to the goal of achieving the revitalisation of our farms. We must make farming attractive to young people. In recent years there has been an extreme decrease in the share of young people in rural areas. Personally, I am particularly worried about this negative trend in Latvia. The poor quality of professional education is a big obstacle. In addition, agriculture is considered to be low prestige and inferior to other sectors, and our young farmers do not feel that they have priority in public support programmes. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, dár ndóigh vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus, mar Rapóirtéir don Choiste Trádála, bhí mé páirteach sa díospóireacht a bhí againn oíche Dé Luain in éineacht leis an gCoimisinéir Ó hÓgáin agus an Rapóirtéir Dorfmann. Caithfidh mé a rá go bhfuil mé dóchasach go bhfuil todhchaí mhaith dár bhfeirmeoirí agus dár mbia san Aontas. Ach, ba mhaith liom dhá rud a rá faoi.  An chéad rud, má táimid ag déanamh comhaontú saorthrádála, caithfimid a chinntiú go mbeidh an bia a bheidh ag teacht isteach san Aontas ar chomhchaighdeán leis an mbia atá á sholáthar san Aontas féin.  Agus an dara rud, caithfimid a chinntiú freisin nach mbeidh an tionscal talmhaíochta thíos leis ar mhaithe le tionscail eile agus sinn ag déanamh comhaontú saorthrádála cosúil le Mercosur. Sin a bhfuil.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Mr President! It has come to the point here today: in this resolution, we have voted a sentence that says: given that the consumption of saturated fats and red meat in the Union far exceeds the recommended levels of demand for nutritional values... etc. In the last session in Brussels, they voted in the last session. You have the opposite. Namely, it is thought that one should defy the prediction that lamb is difficult to cook and reverse the current tendency to avoid red meat. You take data at random, you speak on topics you don't know, you don't know what you vote on and you make a brothel out of EU law. What is that anyway? You will vote two conflicting bills two weeks apart.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! The report deals with very technical matters of law and legislation, but it is worth recalling on this occasion that bad law is not respected, that the law overregulated, difficult and expensive to implement is not respected by citizens, is bypassed. In contrast, the law used badly, the law misapplied by the State and its institutions to the advantage of the State, and against citizens, discourages them from the institutions of the State, as well as the European Union. Therefore, we should take care to make law good, simple, transparent, understandable to citizens, law created with citizens and for citizens. I would also like to say that I am mainly referring to legislation and legislation in the Member States, because through bad law, which is created very often in Member States, then the European Union is badly perceived as such. We should here as politicians, EU and national parliamentarians, work together for a good, better law.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, the way of lawmaking in the EU is known to be highly complex and slow. This is one of the things our international partners notice with regret. At the same time, our legislation is the most inclusive and most respectful of the will of our citizens, and we need our people to know that their voices have been heard. We organise consultations and collect opinions before the legislative process, but we lack the citizens’ assessment during the implementation. For this reason, I welcome the call for a dedicated joint database on the state of play on legislative files. Transparency must be our key word and efficiency must be our testing criteria. We need a politically intelligent approach to gain the support of our people for the laws we do. Our laws must be something that these people can be proud of, and I am convinced that our S&D Group is politically and ideologically equipped to lead such a battle. If we want to have well-informed and supportive EU voters tomorrow, we need to share more information with them and get more feedback from them.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, even under the Treaty of Rome, the so—called European Economic Community was to be financed by national contributions for the transitional period only and subsequently by a system of own resources. Today, in the light of Brexit, we come back to the same discussions. Probably somewhere between 14% and 19% of the EU budget will be lacking when the UK exits the European Union and we need to finance the EU, especially in times when actions at EU level are more and more demanded by our citizens and we are taking on more and more tasks.  Therefore, I strongly support that we follow one single, simple and transparent principle: that EU resources flowing from EU policies should flow to the EU budget. It will ease the burden borne by the Member States through their national contributions and ensure the proper financing of EU policies with clear European added value.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr President! It was hard not to support this compromise. No doubt this is not an optimal solution, but developed in great difficulty, with unfavorable situations related to, among other things, Brexit. What do I want to pay attention to though? First of all, for three doubts. The first concerns a reduction in European Social Fund funds by about six per cent. In my assessment, in the current situation, this is a downright unacceptable thing. The second thing, despite numerous announcements, was not sufficiently increased, on the contrary even, the financial resources were reduced in favour of the intensification of research and innovation programmes. I am pleased that there has been increased funding for Erasmus+, a scholarship program that is extremely relevant from the point of view of the younger generation. But I will remind you that it was foreshadowed that this increase would be almost three times. This reduced the increase — which I also pay attention to.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: — Mr President, we already knew the general approach of this Multiannual Financial Framework: less cohesion, less agricultural policy and more security and defence. Yesterday, the European Commission confirmed this approach by announcing a 7% cut in the Structural Funds for Portugal and the maintenance of macroeconomic conditionality. For us, it is unacceptable to link the application of the Structural Funds to the European Semester and to the country-by-country recommendations, because this limits the decision-making capacity of the national states on their own development model. This proposal by the European Commission not only cuts into the Structural Funds, but also creates new blackmail mechanisms in order to impose its neoliberal agenda on national states. With each passing day, it becomes absolutely clearer that it will not be this European Commission or this framework that promotes the social and territorial cohesion which it so preaches.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I welcome the Commission’s proposal for the new Multiannual Financial Framework for 2021-2027, as well as the flexibility introduced by the own-resources proposal for the financing of the EU budget. The proposal well reflects the key European Union priorities and goals in the context of increased external challenges and the budget hole which will be left by Brexit. I support the increases foreseen for the security, defence and such flagship programmes as, for example, Erasmus. However, I strongly believe that we should continue the current support level for such traditional policies as the common agricultural policy and the cohesion policy. We all benefit from these policy areas, and any decrease can only be gradual and with compensation mechanisms in place. Thus I hope during the negotiation process we can ensure adequate financing, quality and effectiveness of these policies.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: — Mr President, I did not vote in favour of this proposal and I have two comments on it. One relates to those own resources. Let's not mess with our own resources. The European Union is a union of nation-states and should therefore be intertwined and its budget also with levies that come primarily from nation-states. If we create additional resources and other resources of our own, we will cut the European Union away from its basic building blocks and build it somewhere in the air, and most importantly, we will have to invent some new pan-European taxes and fees. I don't see any logic in this. The second comment concerns a change in the structure of the budget I understand that cohesion policy is to be limited, that for example, the countries of Central and Eastern Europe are to get a little less, while the border countries of the European Union are a little more to fight the illegal by migration. Okay, but in that case, Central and Eastern Europe must be compensated for us somehow. So please stop harassing us with refugee quotas and then maybe we'll agree to that.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr President! One of the more serious issues in the draft budget proposed by the Commission is the planned reduction in expenditure on the common agricultural policy and cohesion policy. This is not a good solution, because these are key EU strategies and such radical cuts should be opposed. Dear ladies! When it comes to falling funds for agriculture, farmers are evidently dependent on payments and the agriculture budget should not be reduced. We should do our best to support EU, European agriculture. The common European policy should be a real common one, so I am advocating against cuts to agriculture, and I am also trying to equalise subsidies for Polish farmers.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! We're talking about a budget for future years and creating it under completely different conditions than in years past — we need to take that into account. Often, during speeches are reminded of the issue of Brexit, but let's remember that behind us is the biggest financial crisis, behind us, too, the biggest migration crisis. All of these factors we need to take into account, learn from them and shape the budget so that it also serves to prevent similar crises in the future. There's another — the fourth — very serious factor that we should be considering. Namely throughout Europe, to a greater or lesser extent in different states of course, nationalism, particularism is rampant, anti-EU movements grow into power, parties that have their strength in certain states, populist parties, ba — even gain power, as recently in Italy. These issues must also be taken into account in order to provide funding in the budget to tackle these bad phenomena.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, with regard to the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 and own resources, it should be pointed out that the European Union is setting increasingly ambitious targets. This means that the hard-core states, which earn billions from the functioning of the European Union and the euro area, must put their hands deep in their pockets. The budget of the European Union must be strengthened and it must exceed 2% of the Union's GDP. Strengthening with Eurobonds and making courageous budgetary transfers to the countries of the European South. There should be increased funds for the CAP and there should be no reduction. Support cohesion and measures for migration and youth employment. At the same time, to those who want cuts, we say cut the funds for Turkey. A complete cessation of funding for Turkey, which is threatening Greece and Cyprus, which currently has two Greek military prisoners in prison. No euros in Turkey.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr President! Commissioner Günther Oettinger once again returned to the fateful idea of making political assessments under the pretext of inspecting the rule of law by the Commission while preparing the draft multiannual budget. On what basis? How can you talk about the rule of law and usurp for a body of administrative and coordination powers that belong to the governments of the European Union which have concluded our Union? The Treaties speak clearly about the competence of the European Council and the Commission should keep that in mind. It should also keep in mind the acquired rights that this budget needs to pursue. Polish agriculture in half of the area of Europe occupied by the Soviet Union was a phenomenon due to the preservation of individual property and its family structure. For decades he has not benefited from any help, today he is simply entitled to it.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – (start of speech off mike) ... Mr President, the powers that be have already made up their minds. The future of Europe is set out in how we spend the budget up until 2027. The priorities are clear: fighting before feeding. What is proposed is a larger budget than we currently have – this in spite of the UK leaving. The hole is to be filled by an increase in contributions from Member States through a variety of means, yet we’re being told that funding to the two most important areas – agriculture and cohesion – must be cut. So the cake is bigger, but still we have less for the two most important areas.  So why? Well, the answer is that priorities are changing. What used to be core common policy – feeding the population – has been replaced with a common policy on defence. The budget Commissioner, Gunter Oettinger, was at least open as to why agriculture was to be cut when he said that there are more important areas.  So here we are, with the EU, which touts itself as the ‘biggest peace project of our time’, and we’re told there has not been in a war in Europe since the foundation of this institution, and yet, after all these years of peace, we are now to become a war machine and we are to sacrifice our ability to feed ourselves to do it. Madness! I voted against this rubbish.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, there are many good things to support in this resolution, which largely reiterates the position of Parliament some months ago, particularly the support for those areas that increase scientific research programmes, and so on, are there to be welcomed, and we are happy as Labour MEPs to support those aspects of the resolution. However, only aspects relating to own resources.  First of all, the United Kingdom has a derogation from changes to these systems between now and the end of the MFF and, of course, the UK intends to leave before this new MFF, so it would be inappropriate to express a view on those points. Finally, on the question of the rebates, many of which flow from by far the largest rebate – the UK’s, it seems to us that it is important for UK citizens to understand that that will continue to the end of this MFF and the end of the UK’s membership, and the time to discuss those rebates is perhaps once the UK has left, rather than before.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr President! The internal situation in Libya is very complicated. Moreover, the crisis over several years has a significant impact on other countries in Africa as well. It also has influence over the European Union. You can see this clearly from the example of illegal migrants. Many people cross Libya by transit or flee it in an attempt to get to Europe via the Mediterranean. It is good that the report calls for long-term and realistic solutions to the root causes of migration. The European Union's priority should be to provide effective assistance to local communities, both in Libya and elsewhere in North Africa, in such a way as to improve the standard of living on the ground. This direction was already pointed out more than two years ago by the leader of Law and Justice, Mr Jarosław Kaczynski. It should also be considered positive that the European Union wants to assist Libyan authorities in ensuring the return home of internally displaced people and to support the implementation of effective measures to combat human trafficking and migrant smuggling. That is why I have decided to support this report.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, we have brought Romania and Bulgaria much closer to Schengen. They can now use the information entered by other Member States in the Schengen database, and also all Member States can see the information entered by Romania and Bulgaria in this database. As such, they will be able to collaborate perfectly and in real time. When you have information, you have science, you have power and you can prevent terrorism, illegal migration, cross-border crime. You can also identify and catch those who are preparing to commit such crimes, or those who have already committed them and are walking from one country to another, or, finally, hiding somewhere. The application of these things, which are already in the law, lie in the vision, in the science, in the political capacity of leaders, politicians leading us and judicial, police, border institutions and so on. We don't have a second to lose.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, to begin with, I want to emphasise that the Schengen agreement is a fundamental part of the European Union’s project, and the benefits it brings to the citizens’ daily lives and businesses are undeniable. However, during recent years, due to the ongoing migration crisis and influx of unregulated migrants caused by the failure to protect common external borders, the Schengen area experienced serious challenges, including some Member States even changing their legislation. I believe that this is very alarming, and we need to guarantee the free movement of people and services, as this comprises a crucial part of European Union. I fully support the rapporteur’s call on the Member States to swiftly implement the Commission’s roadmap on bringing back the Schengen.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I did not support the adoption of this report. It is the duty of every sovereign nation to keep its borders safe and intact and to ensure the safety of its people. The Schengen agreement has undermined this principle fundamentally, and if I could change a key sentence in the report, it would actually say that the Schengen agreement has been one of the greatest failures of the European Union, not an achievement. The enormous number of migrants who have been able to vanish within the Schengen area has actually led to one of the most significant threats to the European continent, and by reintroducing border controls, certain Member States have been able to fulfil their primary duty to help keep their people safe. The United Kingdom never signed up to Schengen, and with very good reason, and we will continue to support those countries who assert their right to say who can, and who cannot, cross their borders.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the functioning of the Schengen Convention has completely failed. Germany, France, Austria, Denmark and Belgium have reinstated internal controls. At German airports and Brussels airport, passengers are subject to quarantine from flights from Greece. Indeed, there is full legitimacy from the Commission, since in our constant protests and in the questions we have asked the Commission considers this to be a so-called legitimate procedure. What functioning of Schengen are we talking about? Even here in Strasbourg, for three years, everyone, even MEPs, has been subject to passport control. It is therefore a complete failure of the functioning of Schengen. At the same time, the famous Frontex is doing nothing. The Aegean islands are filled with appeals and illegal immigrants and Frontex is just watching. She's there with all her might. Sixteen and a half thousand are currently refugees and illegal immigrants on the Aegean islands. The Aegean islands can't take it anymore

name: Marek JUREK
text: — Illegal immigration is essential and indeed the only source of the crisis in the Schengen system of open borders. Instead of talking clearly about it, this report postulates, firstly, the old idea that was repeated by the European Commission, i.e. the legalisation of illegal immigration, and, moreover, unfortunately, this report included such curiosous wording as taking the term 'illegal immigration' in quotation marks or talking about “so-called illegal immigration”. How can you question her illegal character and at the same time tell about the rule of law? Border protection is a duty of all States, a triple duty: to their own citizens, to the law that dictates it, but also, as far as the external borders of the Union, to our consensual arrangements. And it is high time for the European Union authorities to respect the law of the Union.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, many people are victims of crime in the Union every year. In Romania, in 2016, more than 1,800 victims of domestic violence were registered, more than half being minors. Authorities must guarantee victims swift, efficient and needs-oriented procedures, firstly, and secondly, information about the release of a criminal, precisely in order to protect victims and enable them to take protective measures. Cooperation between Member States, from this point of view, is essential, because both criminals and victims circulate like any European citizen in the European Union. As such, this cooperation is very necessary. Also, for trafficking in human beings, for example, it is necessary to protect victims, even sometimes to hide their identity, because otherwise we will not catch the offender, we will not catch the trafficker, we will not have evidence and we will also endanger the lives of victims, who are trafficked.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr President! The report on the implementation of the directive establishing minimum standards for the rights, support and protection of victims of crime has legitimate recommendations, but the document focuses on victims, leaving out crime prevention. In most Member States, the concept of family is known and described in the Basic Laws, so it is difficult to see what extensions of this notion are about. While the document is based on the principle of non-discrimination, it highlights the need to provide special assistance to victims of sexual crime and LGBT people, which simply means favouring them. Sexual violence or hatred as a violation of the law occurs in any European penal code, and the document pays close attention to it, especially as it overlooks human life crimes. As ethical abiding persons, especially Catholics, we cannot support records where killing a conceived child is treated as a human right, under a veil of not-so-worthy sounding reproductive and sexual rights — that's the reason I voted against it report.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I abstained on this vote, for the simple and justifiable reason that this report highlights the inadequacies of European Union regulation. The Directive has failed in virtually every sense, so it was absolutely unsupportable. Victims of crime need their rights protected, and this is best done at a Member State level, whereby local considerations are not only understandable but they are also applied. The one-size-fits-all approach taken by the European Union simply does not work, as has been demonstrated most admirably by this report, and there were major failings in the detail. When that happens, no MEP in this Chamber should have supported such directives or reports.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr President! Poland implemented a directive on the protection and support of victims of crime within the European Union. I believe that such action is one of our common priorities. As for today's resolution, I abstained in the final vote, however, because the report included many controversial content relating to reproductive rights, sexual minorities or the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. Dear ladies! Do all European Union documents have to be tainted by left-wing ideology? After all, reproductive health has no relation to the subject of this report, and the ideological nature of some of the provisions of the Istanbul Convention does not allow it to be regarded as a coherent European legal framework. To treat abortion as a basic human right I find objectionable and unworthy.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, in the past few years the trade environment in the world has changed dramatically. We see strong protectionist tendencies enforced by the United States, insecurity caused by Brexit and growing trade with Asian countries. This means that consistent monitoring and assessment of the policy should become an integral part of the EU trade strategy so that the best trading opportunities can be created. I support the report’s view that the EU, as the biggest trading power, should continue to pursue common trade policy which reflects the interests of the EU citizens and companies and at the same time guarantees a fair playing field for the partner countries. Finally, the trade agreement should always adhere to the European values, ensuring responsible management and value chain, and their implementation and negotiations should become much more transparent.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, our common commercial policy is the main instrument to fight against the challenges of globalisation. In a context where China and the US rearrange the trade order according to their individual agenda, we need to be stronger and more united. The withdrawal of the USA from the international trade and multilateral system is a threat to democracy. We need to create commercial security mechanisms to protect our businesses and industries from such shifts. I appreciate the spirit of this report and the assessment of the achievements that have been made, and I have of course voted in favour. I regret, however, seeing that European companies are not making sufficient use of the benefits available under free-trade areas. The reason for this is lack of open data and expert support. This is why I support the call to make the implementation of the common commercial policy more transparent, particularly during the negotiation of trade agreements.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on a topical issue (Rule 153a of the Rules of Procedure) on EU values and the growth of corruption and crime caused by 'golden visas' (2018/2676 (RSP). I would point out that there are no spontaneous speeches in this debate and no blue cards are allowed.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, you have invited the Presidency to speak on behalf of the Council on the topic of the proliferation of corruption and crime through golden visas. This is an important issue which concerns not only visas and residence permits, but also the broader issue of European citizenship. The granting of citizenship and long-stay visas by a Member State falls under national competences, and as a consequence, these matters are not governed by EU law. However, the consequences deriving from decisions by one or more EU Member States frequently have an impact on all the others. Therefore, I would like to thank you for drawing the attention to this topic. Third-country nationals who benefit from a citizenship or residence-by-investment scheme, commonly referred to… (Disturbance in the Chamber) …as golden visas, are usually entitled to reside, live and work in the territory of the European Union Member State granting the permit. At the same time, they can also benefit from the Schengen area residence permit and the citizenship of the Member State. Fundamental privileges and rights are attached to the European Union citizenship and residency permits in an EU Member State. The golden visa programmes matter because they might offer the possibility of misuse or are sometimes perceived as potentially weakening the fight against corruption in the European Union and its neighbouring countries. For this reason, when defining national legislation, each Member State should not only take into account international and Union law but also the essence of EU citizenship and its inherent value. The protection of European Union citizenship is our joint responsibility, shared among all Member States and institutions. The European Union, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission have already expressed their views about these developments. In your resolution of 16 January 2014 on EU citizenship for sale, you called on Member States to recognise and live up to the responsibilities they hold in safeguarding the values and objectives of the Union. Let me also recall that, in its conclusions on the EU citizenship report of 2017, the Council addressed this issue. It invited all Member States to act in accordance with the principle of sincere cooperation and respect the limits set out by the Court of Justice when granting or removing nationality. It is also very relevant that the Commission announced its intention to produce a report on national schemes granting EU citizenship to investors. The Commission is expected to describe current national law and practices as well as its action in this area and provide some guidance for Member States. This report could help us to have a better overview and understanding about existing practices. It will also help the Council to revert to this issue if necessary. I am looking forward to hearing from Commissioner Bulc on the subject. Let me conclude by restating the obvious. Member States are solely responsible for defining the applicable rules in this area, but because of the rights conferred by EU citizenship, we all care. EU citizenship is not and should not become a tradable commodity.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for tabling this debate today. It covers issues that go to the core of EU values, of EU citizenship, and of the duty of sincere cooperation inside our Union. The Commission takes seriously the need to safeguard the essence of EU citizenship. While it is for each Member State to lay down the conditions for the acquisition and loss of its nationality, this must be done in full respect of Union law. Member States should award citizenship in a spirit of sincere cooperation with other Member States. This involves fully recognising that the conferral of their nationality means conferral of EU citizenship and the rights and advantages this brings with it. EU citizenship is the entry door for the internal market. If one Member State does not apply the necessary security and criminality checks, then this can affect all of us. It is for Member States to ensure that the necessary steps are taken to counter security risks. They must also apply rigorous criteria to identify and then combat criminality and corruption. With these points in mind, I can assure you that the Commission is closely monitoring citizenship investor schemes in the EU and their applicants. In the 2017 EU Citizenship Report, the Commission announced that it would publish a report on national schemes granting EU citizenship to investors in 2018, and we will do so in autumn. As regards golden visas, in the absence of harmonisation at EU level, the Commission has no competence on the issuing of residence permits or long-stay visas for investors. Member States are competent to set the procedures and conditions of entry and stay for third-country nationals who wish to invest in the country and stay for longer than 90 days. The effects of such residence permits are largely confined in the granting Member State. They do not entitle the holder to reside outside the issuing Member State, and the short-term travel possibilities are limited to up to 90 days in any 180-day period, in line with Schengen rules. The issue is, however, being analysed in the context of the Commission’s fitness check of the legal migration legislation. The results should be made available in the second half of 2018. Where allegations of fraud and criminal activities arise, it is for the national competent authorities to investigate, be they law enforcement authorities or judicial authorities. The Commission has no competence to intervene directly on allegations of fraud or criminal activities, except in cases where the EU budget is affected. Member States must diligently conduct those investigations, including by applying the provisions of EU law on the prevention of the use of the Union financial system for the purpose of laundering money. I know that many of you are concerned about the possible link between citizenship-for-sale golden visa schemes and money laundering. These schemes indeed may be a factor that facilitates the injection of illicit money into the licit economy of the Member State. Thanks to the efforts of Parliament, the new Anti-Money Laundering Directive includes a specific provision addressing the need for better screening of applicants to national schemes for granting long-term residence or citizenship to investors. This specific provision requires all obliged entities, including banks, members of the professions or wealth managers, to pay close attention and perform enhanced due diligence checks when they are dealing with a third-country national who applies for residence rights or citizenship in exchange for capital transfer, purchase of property or government bonds or investment in corporate entities in that Member State. The Commission now expects all Member States to comply with the new rules as soon as possible and will monitor the implementation of the Directive. Integrity and the fight against corruption in Member States are key priorities for the Commission. As I have already set out, while the Commission has no competence to intervene directly on allegations of fraud or criminal activities, we expect national authorities, be they law enforcement or judicial bodies, to tackle this vigorously. National anti-corruption policies are monitored at EU level. In the framework of the European Semester, the Commission is closely following the functioning of the Member States’ judicial systems, their fight against money laundering and their fight against corruption. All Member States are subject to an ongoing assessment of their general anti-corruption policy landscape and anti-corruption efforts. In March 2018, corruption was indeed identified in several countries. In the Country-Specific Recommendations published on 23 May, recommendations on corruption-related issues were proposed for the following countries: the Czech Republic, Malta, Slovakia, Hungary, Italy and Latvia.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: f'isem il-group PPE. — Il-popli li li nirrappreżentaw huma massba dwar in-nuqqas ta' sigurtà, il-kriminalità u l-- asil tal-flus. Bir-rathe un jistennew azzjoni, jistennew protezzjon u serthe il-moto. Dak li qed niddiskutu llum ser ikollu impatt fuq dan kollu. Hawnhekk mhux qed nitkellmu dwar golden visas jew ittadinanza biss. Hawn qed nitkellmu dwar on the endeavor li gŵr andhom implikazzjonijiet for the alwaysafna akbar. Qed niddiskutu kif jidlu n-nies fl-ewropa billi jakkwistaw passaport jew the aliex ithe allsu. Ahengna rridu lil min guro andu interess enwin li jinvesti, li jothe loq ix-xogthe ol, li jkattar l-impjiegi f'kull pajjiż tal-unjoni Ewropea, isib il-mezz kif jagthe dan, imma li tinxtara huwiex sew.
