I nistgux naglqu gajnejna. La ato, la L-kummissjoni Ewropea, la iteadd. I

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, golden visa schemes allow certain third—country nationals to obtain citizenships or permanent residence of a Member State, and with that they have access to the Schengen area and the internal market. They are very often highly corrupt individuals who have not been properly vetted and who may well be criminals. According to Transparency International, such practices are carried out by at least 11 Member States of the EU, and that is of great concern. Golden visa programmes are not exclusively a national matter, but an EU matter too. We talk about the safety of the Schengen area and our citizens. How can our Member States justify on the one hand refusing to accept a single refugee fleeing war or persecution, whilst on the other being more than willing to give citizenships to potential criminals who bring a lot of money through investments, without knowing what their real background is? EU citizenships should not be for sale. Most systems for obtaining golden visas lack transparency and accountability, especially in the decision—making process. Lack of control risks potential money laundering practices and links to criminal financing for such investments. The EU must ensure that residency and citizenship by investment schemes do not undermine the EU core values of freedom, security and justice, nor threaten the principle of sincere cooperation between the Member States. We strongly call on the European Commission to prepare proper legislation on obligatory reviews of investors and provide very clear criteria for obtaining such golden visas.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, Honourable Council Representative and Mrs Commissioner! Who really peeled off in these countries the issue of such Schengen so-called golden visas or temporary residence permits or passports? It is usually peeled off by a relatively narrow circle of people connected with the financial world in these countries, albeit with the development of real estate, and they earn in reality an overvalue that does not belong to them, because not only property is sold for investment purposes, but also the entrance to the Schengen territory or the British Commonwealth. And this is what many people here, in this building, like the classic Marx, who calls it a superficial value, so a thing, a value that doesn't actually belong to these entrepreneurs. By contrast, investors who come inside the European Union with these, being both owners of this money, and often merely representing or trustees, do not come with pure purposes. And all of this in general contributes to both money laundering and corruption in the European Union, and all these processes that are among them are undesirable in the European Union. Special cases are then that you sell citizenship. This not only changes the attitude to European Union citizenship as a value, but also actually makes it possible to find ourselves in a situation where we suddenly find out that there are Maltese or Cypriot citizens who actually get on US sanctions lists and cause us problems, also developing business in another European Union in the country. And finally — we like or dislike — I think the United States is more influencing these processes in the European Union in this case and cleans us of unwanted money than the European Union both in Latvia — in my country — and in Cyprus.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs in't Veld, may I address you briefly. Unfortunately, we had a little confusion. You would have been the first speaker, and I had 2 minutes of speaking time, but as an author you have an additional 2 minutes. So you have 4 minutes of speaking time. We got a little confused with the speaking time. Please, my colleague in't Veld!

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, that is very generous and that’s good, because I’ve got a lot to say and I was trying to squeeze it all into two minutes. The first thing I was going to say was that if I were – let’s take a random example – a Russian oligarch and I had some criminal money that I would like to park somewhere, then I would be really delighted to hear the response of the Council and the Commission here today. Because while we are very busy building ‘Fortress Europe’ for people who want to come here to work, we’re actually rolling out the red carpet for certain other people who want to come here, get residency permits and citizenship for themselves and for their family. This is not just about state facilitated corruption and money—laundering, and I repeat that – state facilitated corruption and money—laundering – as that’s what we’re talking about, but we’re also talking about importing a security risk. I don’t even need to mention what’s going on in Moscow—on—Thames, where Russian oligarchs are bumping each other off apparently, but we’ve also seen that there is a very real risk for people who are investigating this, like the journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, and also like whistle—blowers who are exposing these practices, because – let’s be honest – this is just a big scam.  This is not just in some countries that were mentioned by you, Madam Commissioner, which got a red flag near their names. Even in a country like mine, we have so—called investor schemes and it all looks nice at the front door. But if you look at the back door there’s one big weak spot and that’s the screening of the applicants, because we know that we are dealing with countries of origin which are known for their corrupt systems. How are we going to verify if the candidates are legit, if we can trust them, if the money is not criminal money? How are we going to verify that this is not serious?  Therefore I very much agree with the proposals by Tanja Fajon. We do need European standards, European rules. We need a common scheme. And we do need the European Commission to bring forward legislative proposals, because I don’t want to hear anymore ‘we have no competence’. You know, you’re legislating in all sorts of areas, concluding agreements where there is no legal basis either. And this is a very serious matter because there are people here who buy passports, not on the black market but legally from governments. I’m very curious to hear from the European Commission, because you say you are closely monitoring the situation and there will be a report in full, but I really would like to hear a little bit more about it, because it’s become a very, very urgent matter since the situation in Malta last year.  We also need more transparency from the Member States because it’s just not acceptable anymore, with everything that’s going on, that Member States are saying ‘oh no, this is a national matter, we’re not giving out any information on this’. This is about people coming into our European Union, getting EU citizenship, benefiting from all the rights that EU citizens and EU residents have. We have a right to know. So the argument that this is a national competence to cover up criminal activities is simply not good enough anymore. We need harmonised rules. We need harmonised standards for the screening procedures. We need more transparency. We need more information. But, finally, I also think that we need to stop applying double standards because, as I already mentioned, people who want to come to the European Union to work are treated like criminals, and those who want to come here and park their criminal money are received like kings. If you’re an EU citizen affected by Brexit, for example, because you happen to live in a country that you do not have the citizenship of, then you’re in big difficulty, but if you’re a Russian oligarch, or a Chinese oligarch, then you’re fine, if you have money.  We need to stop applying double standards. This is something that we cannot explain to our citizens anymore. Our citizens don’t care about national competence or EU competence. They want to know that EU citizenship is for EU citizens and not for criminals.  (Applause)

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. If we look around the Internet, then it offers luxury watches, luxury yachts, very beautiful villas and exactly in the same way and language, citizenship in states of the European Union and just as unlimited residence rights. I am totally with my colleague in't Veld: this is not just a problem for some states. Recently, an investor from Ukraine in southwestern Lower Saxony received unlimited right of residence just because he invested enough. Was it ever looked at exactly where the money came from? No! But we must not do one thing: citizenship and residence rights are obtained by doing something in a country, integrating, making every effort there, and not because it is a commodity that you can buy for money, because then you lose all respect. That is why we from the Council and the Commission here today need clear proposals on how they intend to deal with this problem. The Commission should not only draw up a report on the status, but also present an analysis of its proposals, which it would like to do now.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, it is not an accident that various golden visa schemes in the EU have been surrounded by corruption scandals. Golden visa schemes in the EU are designed to facilitate money laundering – they actually invite it. They allow dirty money to be entered into a clean economy, often through real estate with minimal checks. The basic fact that explains why the existing due diligence procedures for the ultra-rich applicants are failing so badly is because they are not designed to work. These schemes worsen inequality within states and between them. So we urgently need strict and enforceable due diligence procedures to determine the origin of the money flowing into the EU through these schemes. But do we really want simply to regulate these commodity schemes? They foster corruption and inequality, as we know, and we should be preventing and abolishing them entirely. Selling citizenship to the highest bidder when millions of refugees in need are being turned away at the gates of the EU is the scandal of our time. Rights should not be for sale, full stop.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the business of golden visas, according to a series of journalistic investigations, is feeding into the European Union a market for the rich Foreign citizens who come to invest in the absence of standard rules of control and transparency. Citizenship and rights of entry and residence have become the bargaining chip to obtain substantial investments. There is a high risk that national programmes that bind to wealth the granting of residence permits, the opportunity to live and work in Europe, to have citizenship and even give it a price, promote corruption and laundering funds of dubious origin, weakening the contrast to such phenomena. There are programmes that would provide for secret on the recipients of gold visas, and details on investments and who benefits from it would be scant. The European Union must make the fight against corruption and money laundering effective by thoroughly and constantly monitoring golden visa programmes, so that it preserves its borders from criminal subjects with financial availability and from corrupt.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, the practice of golden visas is scandalous. For some Member States of the European Union, it consists in selling very expensive residence permits with a promise of nationality to wealthy foreigners which give them access to the Schengen area. Who are the buyers? Often Russians and Chinese, anxious to obtain a second passport to protect themselves in case of danger or simply to practice tax evasion or even money laundering. What are the selling countries? There are a dozen of them within the Union, notably Portugal, tariff 1 000 000 euros, Malta, tariff 1 200 000 euros and, the crème de la crème de la crème, Cyprus, tariff 2 000 000 euros. The Brussels Commission was well aware of this practice, but for a long time it remained silent, proof if necessary, that it serves the interests of the business operators. Given the scale of the scandal, she promises us a report on golden visas for the end of the year. Let's expect that once again, the mountain will give birth to a mouse.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, the golden visa programme is operated in a significant number of European Member States, and quite frankly, shame on them for actually being in a position and even feeling they have got the right to offer that. A number of my colleagues have kept on about Russia and China – but what about some of the countries on the European continent that are seeking membership of this European Union, such as Albania? We have had stories in the United Kingdom of individuals there using the golden visa programme who are known criminals, already guilty of corruption and other awful crimes against humanity, and yet they are making use of this particular system. We have also heard this afternoon – but I am going to reiterate – the dangers that the Schengen system actually presents. It allows these individuals, once they are inside the European Union with their golden visa, to go where the hell they want and export their criminality and other actions of ill repute everywhere and anywhere. This whole process needs fundamental reform, and this report does not include any seemingly reasonable or justifiable ideas or concepts as to how to address the problems.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, I am very happy to see this broad agreement in this House. This is very unusual but very reassuring. Indeed, in many cases these golden visa schemes are abused and simply allow EU passports to be bought by wealthy third-country nationals, who use this possibility to escape sanctions, avoid taxes or launder money. Many examples connected to illicit financing, especially coming from Russia, certainly support this claim. Moreover, the golden visa schemes clearly discriminate against ordinary third-country nationals who live and work in the EU and yet have to wait for many years until they are eligible for naturalisation. The standard granting of citizenship permits is a competence of Member States. I nevertheless see an urgent need for more coordination and cooperation between Member States in this field. Firstly, golden visas should be restricted to granting residence status to foreign investors, but they should not automatically offer citizenship. EU passports should only be issued to applicants who have spent sufficient time in a Member State and can demonstrate that they are integrated in its society. We should not treat the EU like a supermarket, where passports can simply be purchased. Secondly, the national procedures for granting residence permits and citizenship should include standardised background checks on all applicants, involving the exchange between Member States of all available information on the applicant. I encourage the Commission to take the initiative in order to help Member States to regulate this area more efficiently.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President! I very much welcome the fact that we are having this debate today. She's overdue, and this is the right moment. Possession of citizenship increasingly decides what life a person can lead. Anyone who is supposed to be members of a nation has now become part of often shameful political debates. For various reasons, people are being robbed of the opportunity to stay permanently in other countries, even if this would be necessary for reasons of political persecution or economic hardship. This debate is being held loudly. Yes, in some Member States, defence seekers has become a political business model. At the same time, another practice was quietly established: people can very well find permanent stay, you just need to have the necessary financial resources. Almost half of the Member States have such programmes. The layout is different, but the principle applies everywhere: it is not the need that decides, but the financial capacity. All the barriers created by individual Member States against immigration are suddenly devoid of purpose, and the principles that have been invoked for them are suddenly no longer valid. This is scandalous. The fact that most states are still engaged in this matter offensively only makes things worse. These practices deserve European attention. We must by no means leave it to the individual Member States to decide who to recruit as citizens — firstly because they also acquire citizenship of the Union with citizenship and thus benefit from free movement of persons, and secondly, because this business model is inviting us to launder money. and promote criminal practices. Experience so far shows. The Commission would do well to prepare an appropriate legislative proposal.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I am delighted to have heard so many speeches with which I fully agree. There is no disagreement here in this House at all, and I can repeat all this again and confirm what colleagues have already said: it is a scandal when citizenships are simply sold, and it is impossible and contradicts EU values if it promotes criminal activities and disseminate them in the EU, if money laundering is promoted and when corruption spreads in the EU — we all agree on that. However, with the exception of what Mr Rosati said, I have not heard a single workable proposal on how to deal with this problem. That's why I think we need to talk about this. Mr Rosati is quite right: we have to say that if a right of residence is granted for purchase on investment projects, then this must not be linked to citizenship. We have to make a distinction between residence and citizenship. If citizenship is granted, we may also have to make a distinction between national citizenship and citizenship of the Union, and we must say that citizenship quickly does not yet give access to European citizenship. European citizenship does not exist until you have been here for a long time and when you are truly integrated into the European Union and its values.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: - Mr President! The revelations surrounding these 12 countries selling citizenship in their own country and thus to the entire EU, that is simply outrageous. It is also unfair because it is only very rich people from third countries who can make use of this, while the poor continue to risk their lives on deadly journeys across the Mediterranean and are at the mercy of traffickers in search of new chances of life. The golden visas we are discussing today also undermine all our work to combat corruption because they premiere tax evasion and money laundering. It's time to stop with this undignified behavior. It is time to stand up for Europe's fundamental values of the equal value of all people and to fight corruption and other misery. In order to maintain security in our EU, I now demand that the Commission actually review how these programmes work and how they are used. Transparency needs to increase, and now is actually the time for you to act.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, do you need to move swiftly to acquire a different citizenship for business purposes? Are you suspected of money-laundering and facing a little local difficulty? No problem. For a few hundred thousand euros, you can become a citizen of an EU Member State. New Zealand-born billionaire Christopher Chandler bought EU citizenship from Malta, while British citizens are losing theirs thanks to the Brexit campaign backed by his Legatum Institute. When Putin’s mate Oleg Deripaska found EU sanctions too hot to handle, he found an easy way out. He paid to become a Cypriot and was free to do business as a European citizen. The global kleptocrats disdain national governments. When those governments sell them the precious rights of citizenship, they are undermining the rule of law. Both Malta and Britain have come to regret inviting such people into their countries. Selling freedom of movement to the wealthy may seem attractive, but in terms of social cohesion and public safety, the price may be higher than you thought.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Mr President, the absolute zero point on this issue is under what circumstances a sovereign nation allows residence of foreign nationals. At bottom, it’s a question of sovereignty. Presently in the UK, our government gives a so-called golden visa if the applicant makes an investment of at least GBP 2 million in government bonds, share capital or loan capital. This gives an open goal towards securing a British passport. In 2017, the UK granted 355 of these visas. The majority of them were Chinese or Russian nationals. Given the present geo-political situation, we have to look at whether this selling England by the pound is really in the national interest or fairness to other applicants. The absolute minimum any responsible government selling – a phrase, by the way, which just sounds wrong – visas is to fully investigate where this money came from. Surely it’s incumbent upon any nation state to ensure that applicants are people of high moral character? Otherwise we are opening ourselves up to the charge of being accomplices to money laundering, slave labour; of being accessories to the possible undermining of our own national sovereignty. Our governments should treat all applicants equally and fairly. The ability to loan a government GBP 2 million pound, or however much it may be, should never, ever be part of that equation.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister. A number of EU Member States offer nationalities and residence permits, the so-called 'golden visa'. And some of them — Malta, Cyprus or Portugal — have already been exemplary and criticised in this House's reports, particularly by the TAXE Special Committee and by the PANA Committee of Inquiry. This 'golden visa' is a very lucrative business for the Member States. Cyprus alone has generated 4.8 billion euros in revenue for granting citizenship to 1685 foreign investors over the past ten years, most recently very prominent: Oleg Deripaska. My country, Austria, too, is always mentioned in this context — I believe that it is completely wrong, because the so-called super-claim, Article 6 of Section 10 of Austrian citizenship law, explicitly does not provide for 'golden visas'. On the contrary, it is necessary to approve the Austrian Council of Ministers for citizenship, which is really only granted in exceptional cases, namely to 300 people in the last ten years. These are primarily artists, such as opera singer Anna Netribko, athletes or deserved personalities. “Golden visa” rules, however, are, of course, due to a lack of transparency — suspicions of corruption and the circumvention of common accounting standards, and this must be avoided. Here is the fitness check... (The president withdraws the speaker from the speaker.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, many in the European Union who, through their actions and omissions, are responsible for the transformation of many countries of the European Union into tax havens, as well as cleaning machines of large amounts of illegal money, are too hypocritical to accuse some other countries of promoting corruption because they give foreigners gold visas. A very nice way to give up their responsibilities! I mention this because my homeland, Greece, is a typical example. The country, whose people suffer from the austerity imposed on it by the memoranda, is forced to sell its homes at very low prices, even at half their real value. Others lose their homes because they are unable to repay their loans and all these houses come and buy them by wealthy foreigners. Chinese, first and foremost, Russians, even Turks. So you understand the enormous responsibility that the European Union has for this situation and now comes to accuse us of promoting corruption. In addition, he comes to accuse the country of having to grant its right to control corruption and control it... (The President removed the speaker from the speaker.)

name: Nuno MELO
text: Mr President, the residence permit, to begin with, is temporary, at least in my country, and it can be a good thing as it can be a bad thing. It depends on your monitoring, and what happens in one country is not necessarily replicable in all others. In my case, my country requires a transfer of capital of EUR 1 million or more, the creation of a minimum of ten jobs and purchased buildings of at least EUR 500 000. Since 2012, it has implied revenue for Portugal of €3.5 billion and investments in excess of €84 million. Obviously, security checks are required, a verification of each application and, in the face of each conviction, the expulsion and the revocation of the benefit. But if the regime is complied with, it will not necessarily be bad before the law provided that the person who violates is relentlessly convicted and tried.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, many have already said how many countries in Europe can obtain citizenship for money or investment. I think we should see that citizenship business has now become a multi-billion-dollar global market over which, in essence, no one has control. If, for example, a person has access to EU citizenship in this way, the freedom of movement within the Schengen area applies mutatis mutandis. But governments also promise tax benefits, access to the European internal market and social benefits. However, those who obtain EU citizenship in this way do not undergo any serious national security due diligence. This will also open the way to the European Union for people who want to leave their country, for example, because they are involved in money laundering, tax evasion or corruption transactions, or want to pursue such activities within the European Union. Since this is a complex and sensitive issue, S&D has already urged the Commission to look at this problem horizontally, in context and not just focusing on one Member State. It is true, of course, that there are procedural differences between individual Member States. In the vast majority of the Member States concerned, the state itself carries out this procedure, but in Hungary, for example, they gave the business into the hands of private companies specialised in this regard, which significantly increased the threat of corruption and security policy threats. This is particularly disgusting in the case of a country that does not want to accept any refugee while selling almost twenty thousand settlement bonds. I am convinced that the business of citizenship must be completed, and this cannot be maintained politically or morally. Settlement bonds have no real economic or political benefit, they only increase corruption and security policy threats. Therefore, the Commission and Parliament must act jointly to put an end to this practice.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, Golden Visa is the immediate receipt of citizenship or residence in another state, if you have a large amount of money at your disposal. In more than 12 EU countries, a passport or residence permit costs between EUR 250 000 and EUR 10 million. Among them are: Hungary, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Cyprus or Greece. The source of the invested funds and the profits of the applicants are superficially verified and thus Russian, Ukrainian or other oligarchs can finally settle in the European Union. By doing so, EU states turn into real tax havens of corruption, organised crime or money laundering. In addition to a luxurious life, they escape justice at home. The upscale migration of the corrupt must be stopped by closing these programs.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: — Mr President, with golden visas, we are really facing a mechanics that does not smell good, I would even say that smells bad. It is a shame that European citizenship can be bought, including with dirty money. In addition, in many cases, the residence permit granted is not used to reside effectively in the country which issued it, but to move with impunity within the European Union and to do business there. It is a private annuity obtained by the sale of a European common good. Thirdly, and this is perhaps the most dangerous point, we are more controlled in the European system to obtain a short-stay visa than to obtain a long-term visa, which will allow business to be done indefinitely within the territory of the Union. In the face of this, we hear the Council and the Commission saying: 'We will remind the Member States of the principle of loyal cooperation'. Do you think the Member States are listening to you? You can see that they don't listen to you. So there is only one thing to do: long stay visas have to become a collective responsibility, as is the case for short-stay visas.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I should like to point out once again that statements of consent or disapproval from the gallery are not part of a Parliament's practice.

name: Eva JOLY
text: — Mr President, more than 12 Member States have put in place citizenship acquisition programmes in exchange for investment. In fact, these programmes allow criminals and fraudsters to laundering their money, get back into virginity and import their trafficking into the Schengen area. In Portugal, golden visas are at the heart of a huge corruption scandal. In Malta, Lithuania and Cyprus, they allow Russian oligarchs to escape sanctions. They can also allow French citizens to escape the radars of the tax authorities. Yes, states are sovereign over the granting of nationality, but when the European area of freedom, justice and security is threatened, the European Union must act. It is unacceptable to allow investors to move freely in the Schengen area, when control over the origin of their money is often insufficient. The Schengen area requires confidence and solidarity. Golden visas jeopardize him. That is why the Commission must, if not prohibit them, at least supervise them.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, let me start by saying that I am a proud Czech as well as a proud European. Europe for me means history, values and principles. They can help us to build a better future together, so we should not lose them, we should keep them. The selling of passports or residency for thousands of euros is surely not consistent with these values at all. I firmly believe that such a policy undermines the fairness of our society, creates a lot of economic problems, and downgrades, relativises or seriously undermines the achievements of our Europe. Sometimes it is associated with financial wrongdoings, criminal risk or at least an increase in real estate prices for residents. If you put into your computer search engine a question about the best passports for sale, you can be almost sure that among the top ten countries, you will find two, three or four EU Member States, not excluding our Presidency. Some passports and residencies in the EU are cheap and some of them are expensive but very beneficial. As has been said, this is not a national matter – because whoever gets them has access to the Schengen area. There are very strong reasons to reconsider this practice, so I believe that if the Council acts in a sincere way, we will move forward and the situation where we are at the top of the list of passport sales will be in the past.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, whatever one may think, whether for or against, ‘golden’ schemes by governments to grant citizenship, residence permits or visas constitute legitimate tools of policy. Under globalisation, direct investment is being sucked away from the smaller peripheral economies towards the centre of the larger economic systems. Through ‘golden’ schemes, smaller economies seek to attract investment to their territory by giving a personal stake in it to agents having some control over investment flows. Obviously these persons will have their reasons for joining ‘golden’ schemes – some acceptable and others not. We have hysterical claims even here by some who, whiter than snow, insist that this is an abuse of European citizenship and that it promotes criminality. The truth is that most states have practised, or now practise, some form of ‘golden’ scheme. Most do it in a non-programmed way, at least on the outside: the schemes lack rules; decisions are informal and announcements are hidden, so nobody protests. Do—gooders and parts of the international media attack only those countries like Malta and Cyprus which have open, advertised programmes. Speaking for Malta, the process of assessing applicants for its ‘golden’ scheme is extremely rigorous. I asked to see how it is done and I was impressed – and still am – by its rigour. Yes, mistakes may be made. When detected they are corrected. Whoever here knows to the contrary, let him or her submit cases, not wild accusations. Argue for reasonable parameters to define golden schemes, both formal and informal, plus due diligence in implementation; argue for total transparency applicable to all schemes, formal and informal; but do not create scapegoats. If money laundering is really the problem that upsets you … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: — Mr President, golden visas, that is, passports and residence permits for money and investment, have become a billion-class business for many EU countries. But they also carry a high risk of corruption and money laundering. As a result of incomplete background clearances for applicants, security is also possible. It is morally problematic for people to be placed in an unequal position based on wealth. With golden visas, wealthy investors get a residency permit significantly more easily than a regular working visa applicant. The backgrounds of applicants and the origin of funds to be invested should always be able to establish very accurately in order to ensure that the scheme is not used to promote criminal activities such as money laundering, tax evasion or financing terrorism. As a result of free movement, arrangements such as golden visas affect the entire Schengen area. That is why I hope the Commission has a firm grip on tackling the problems of the system.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Mr President, the schemes for granting residence in exchange for investments are a real scandal, because we have no control where the money comes from. Basically, it is a policy that what it does is that people who want to come to the European Union to earn their bread honestly do not let them in, and people who bring the money we don't know where we give them residence permits. In addition, I have to say that in Spain, where we have given up to 30,000 visas since 2013, we are leading this issue with two very serious problems identified. The first is the impact on the real estate market. It has been allowed to enter money into the real estate market, favoring developers, but with an impact on the price of housing very, very negative for the majority of citizens. And then, on the issue of the origin of money, in the Spanish case, the first country of origin of money is China. And in China it is forbidden to take more than fifty thousand dollars out of the country. How is it possible that Chinese investors will then come to Spain to invest, in exchange for residence, five hundred thousand, one million euros? This is a real scandal, and we therefore call on the Commission, please, to act and draw up a European legal framework to tackle this issue.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Mr President, as is known, there are States which offer 'gold visas' in exchange for economic investment ranging from EUR 2 hundred and fifty billion to ten million euros. In this way, third-country citizens obtain a residence permit which, depending on the granting Member State, grants freedom of movement, tax advantages, access to the single market or citizenship. But they've been investigated by the OECD. They have been for possible abuse for the purpose of evading taxes. These investigations have detailed how “gold visas” are used to weaken the fight against corruption in the European Union and its neighbouring countries. The phenomenon has increased over the past six years, mainly driven by millionaires from China, Russia, Libya, Iran or Venezuela eager to find a safe place for their money and a passport that will save them formalities if they have to leave their countries of origin. “Gold visas” granted in exchange for a given investment have proved to be, in many cases, linked to laundering, corruption and organized crime. And therefore, to the financing of all kinds of illicit activities, such as drug trafficking and terrorism. Well, I, along with other Members, say: 'European citizenship, European law'. I am the rapporteur for Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, which concerns the granting of visas. In this regard, Commissioner, I propose that you launch a legislative initiative by amending that regulation in a timely manner and making all Member States subject to compliance with it.

name: Ana GOMES
text: — Mr President, security concerns dominate the management of the European Union's borders, but only for migrants and refugees, of the most vulnerable people in the world. For the rich and powerful, criminal and corrupt, several Member States, including my own, have shamefully opened secure channels for accessing EU residence and citizenship through gold visas and direct selling of nationality. Over the past five years, I have warned national and European authorities that these schemes encourage the abuse of corruption by political officials and all kinds of intermediaries, as the trial in Portugal of a minister and other senior officials of the state shows. They are a threat to the organisation, integrity of the financial system and the security of our citizens, they attract kleptocrats, criminal organisations seeking shelter in the European Union to laundering capital. As our inquiry into the Panama Papers demonstrated, due diligence about big applicants is perfunctory. Banks even offer credits to obfuscate the origin of the money transfers involved. These schemes also exacerbate the gulf between the 'haves' and the 'have nots'. Transnational networks that market such schemes to Russian, Chinese and other rich people that they designate as global citizens, such as Henley and Partners, the Arton Group that hires Mr Durão Barroso for promotional events, the Big 4, and so on, need to be scrutinised in their activities, profits, processes and contracts binding EU governments, that even compel prime ministers to go on roadshows selling European citizenship, as does the Prime Minister of Malta. This race to the bottom has to end. The Commission and the Council must act.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Dear Chairman, the basis of citizenship contains a common identity and values which each citizen is obliged to respect and preserve. I am not a supporter of citizenship trade and so-called gold visas, but I respect the right of members to assign them as sovereign states to whoever they want. Because gold visas and citizenship granted to various foreign officials and investors are often a way for them to avoid prosecution in their home country, and often pose a security threat as they facilitate sponsoring terrorism, control must exist. The right of a country to grant citizenship or a gold visa must not jeopardize the rule of law and the interests of other members. That is why I believe that these nationalities and visas, of course, in addition to the protection of personal data, must be notified to all other Member States and partner countries with which we have visa-free regime.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, eleven Member States in the European Union have programmes which grant residence permits to foreign investors. Let me make it clear that I don't necessarily think that's a bad thing. On the contrary, such programs can be a way to attract valuable investment and encourage entrepreneurship. But the granting of citizenship cannot be done with double standards and weights, which is why we are here this afternoon. If the withdrawal of these visas is not accompanied by adequate integrity checks, then we run the risk of giving free rein to criminals and money laundering carousels. Then it's pure selling to the highest bidder. I am fully aware that the granting of citizenship is an exclusive matter for a Member State, yet Europe has the right to express its opinion on this. What one Member State decides has consequences for all of us. Citizenship automatically gives access to the internal market and allows us to enjoy our freedoms. Of course, this is not by chance the ultimate selling point in such constructions. And that's where the shoe is wringing. It is completely absurd that we have no idea who and how European citizenship is being awarded to. So let me be clear. There is nothing wrong in principle with a golden visa programme, but Member States must take their responsibility in this. To give criminals who are waving money a safe pass to launder their funds through those programmes, that really cannot be done. Within the Committee on Financial Crimes, Tax Evasion and Tax Avoidance, we must carefully examine these programmes. We need to know who will receive these visas, according to which criteria it will be done and how the preliminary investigation will take place. We owe that to the citizens of Europe.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, golden visas, residence and citizenship look like issues which belong to the national legislation of the Member States. But they are not – and they never have been since the Lisbon Treaty entered into force – because they fall under a common European visa policy and European legislation. Golden visas have a negative impact on the status of EU residence and citizenship. They have a negative impact on the common fight against corruption, money laundering and fiscal unfairness. European residence or citizenship should not be bought in a black market or sold out by Member States’ governments. Finally, they have a negative impact on equal rights, equality before the law, because they benefit the rich, and they are an offence against most fundamental EU values.  My conclusion is clear, crystal clear. A new European visa code and a common European strategy are needed in order to fight against not only corruption but also tax evasion, fraud, fiscal fairness and fairness for all.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: We return to the debate on the current topic (Rule 153a of the Rules of Procedure) on EU values and the rampant of corruption and crime in relation to “golden visas” (2018/2676 (RSP).

name: Frank ENGEL
text: – Mr President, I fear that it must have been my potentially incendiary remarks earlier that led to a fire alarm – one of the most successful fire alarms ever, Mr President, because I want to have it put on record that next time the House tries to organise one, it should at least make sure that the gates are not closed to people who do not have badges. Had there been a fire this time, I would probably not be talking to you now, nor would you be here for me to talk to you. Let’s try and do better next time! I was going to say that it is all very funny to talk about legitimate reasons for throwing passports around – which, in the good old days, were a sacred sovereign prerogative of Member States to attribute, passports being the material reflection of citizenship. Then came a time when we sold out, and we did so for the basest of reasons, notably for money. We call it ‘citizenship by investment’ but, please, what sort of investment is that? Investment like the Pilatus bank in Valletta, whereby a sovereign country in the Mediterranean turns itself into an Azeri colony just in order to service a few corrupt Azeri businessmen and the whole regime with it? That’s called investment? I’m sorry! In Hungary, I suppose that in the good old days, when they were still running newspaper ads in order to sell their passports, the money had to be transferred into an offshore account that apparently belonged to the Government. That tells you about the transparency and the legitimacy of the investment that was supposed to be behind it! There is no passport and no citizenship by investment. There is citizenship by identification, integration, merit, and belief in what we stand for as nations and as the European Union. Madam Commissioner, I know that the Commission has limited means of action in this regard, but please condemn the practice, as clearly and as unequivocally as this House does, because only then are we going to get the more reluctant Member States to realise that what they are doing is wrong.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: — Fil-fatt, hemm tlettax-il program FL-unjoni Ewropea, the minnhom iwasslu gЂal ittadinanza f'xi pajjiżi tal-unjoni Ewropea. U nifhem it-tthe assib li ssemma f'din il-kamra. Min huma l-persuni li gandhom a Se ndashort-term, FL-unjon Ewropea, riskju gЂas-sigurtà? Kien hemm minn qal li ma jsirx screening, li jidnolu persuni li jwettqu reati kontra l-umanità, li niftu l-bieb gall-kriminali. Issemma wkoll il-bżonn li jkollna linji - ari. Kamra tobb tissemma lil Malta, galiex f'din il-kamra tobb tissemma to Malta. Gandna erba' livelli ta' “due diligence process”. Kull applikant huwa vvettjat individwalment. Il-prothe ess jinvolvi lill-pulizija, lill-europol u lill-interpol b- ala l-ewwel check. Apparti, imbagjoo ad, li jsiru investigazzjonijiet u checks ora f'livelli ora, inkluż — u l-aktar importanti — minn fejn to the el-flus. Maltese biss gЂandha din is-sistema. Maltese qiegЂda minn ta' quddiem nett biex iddańal miżuri enalli timmitiga dawn ir-riskji. The program is ora huma galkollox oskuri. Galiex ma gЂandux ikun hemm dan it-tip ta' standards gЂal dan it-tip he' program? Issemmiet isto afna drabi r-rilokazzjon, u Ђ‹вЂa nsemmi r-rilokazzjon gЂaliex issemma, u sar il-paragun ma', min hu fqir u jipprova jfittex rifuthe ju FL-unjoni Ewropea. Taf kemm pajjiżi li daxenlu giheall-impenn li jirrilokaw lill-immigranti fil-fatt imxew ma' dak l-impenn u anki enki atar mill-engags li to the rauadu? Żewto pajjiżi biss: Malta u L-Irlanda. Jiena nifhem, iva, li gЂandu jkun hemm standards, gЂandu jkun hemm due diligence u l-istakeholders kollha gandhom jaraw li jkun hemm due diligence kif suppost.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, EU citizenship is, in the Commission's words, the essence of the common European project. Then it must hurt you, Commissioner, like me, that citizenship is simply put on sale in some Member States. That rich Russians and Chinese give some money — often with a dubious background — register at a gas station, for example in Malta, and then become European citizens. That goes against everything Europe stands for. For years we have been asking attention to it. Now it's really time to take action. There are three things that need to be done. First of all, a ban on selling passports. Secondly, a real investigation into how many of these types of residence permits are sold, under what conditions they are sold and how the origin of that money is checked. Thirdly, following this study, clear, strict European minimum rules on the issue of residence permits to foreign investors. Residence permits and European passports are a privilege and not a commodity.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Mr President, I would like to say that it is necessary in this debate to distinguish clearly, on the one hand, what the residence permit is, on the other hand, what is the granting of nationality. And then it is essential that the residence permit itself be subject to strict criteria, particularly from the point of view of examining the criminal record and, of course, the background of the people who apply for it. That has been done, so is communication to the European Union. But from that point on, we cannot enter into this drift that everything that is granting a residence permit and even, in certain cases, nationality, fulfilled the common requirements and conditions, is something that cannot be done by the Member States. It is interesting to note that many states that are doing nothing to welcome refugees are here invoking refugees to be against these programmes. This is the case of Holland, Mrs. In't Veld, where 20 of the largest Portuguese companies are registered, which then does not want the Portuguese State to have programs to attract investment, when the investment runs away all to the Netherlands that preaches austerity to us. If there were also fiscal harmonisation perhaps there would not have to be such differences.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their views. I fully understand their position and frustration and, again, thank you for your comments, but let me remind you that what the Commission can and cannot do on this topic is defined in the EU Treaty. Before I conclude, however, let me share with you some comments, and replies to your comments. First, on the corruption and security risks linked to citizenship-for-sale schemes, as I said, the Commission is currently working on a report on investor schemes, which includes all Member States. Let me repeat: all Member States will be included. It will describe the Commission’s action in this area. Let me be even more precise: the report will be based on a fact—finding study, detailed work for which is now underway. The study will look at both investor citizenship and investments residence, so—called ‘golden visa’ schemes. The contractor undertaking the study has been asked to look at the legislative framework, the security and due-diligence checks, the numbers of people involved and the schemes’ implementation in practice. On the topic of guidance for Member States, the Commission will issue some guidance to Member States on the question of citizenship for sale, together with the 2018 report on investor schemes. On the topic of legislative initiatives by the Commission, let me re—stress the following. First, the concept of residence has already been harmonised at EU level, following a sector-based approach, and covers the following categories: high—skilled workers, seasonal workers, students and researchers, family members through family reunification, intra—corporate transfers and long—term residence. Second, as competence on the matter is shared between the EU and the Member States, Member States currently remain free to regulate admission conditions and rights for categories of persons not covered under EU law, including self—employed persons, entrepreneurs and investors. So, what I am promising to you, honourable Members, is that I will share all of your concerns and positions with my colleagues responsible for this sensitive area. Thank you very much for all of your comments.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for giving me the floor. I have listened to this debate with great interest. On Ms in ’t Veld’s call for more transparency and monitoring, I would like to say that there is no EU monitoring, strictu sensu, since the monitoring of agencies which offer assistance in granting EU citizenship or residence permits relates clearly to a national competence. However, in January 2009, the so-called EUDO Citizenship, an observatory within the European Union Observatory on Democracy, was launched. This observatory analyses citizenship laws and policies in Europe. It is hosted by the Robert Schuman Centre of the European University Institute in Florence and funded by the European Fund for the Integration of Non-EU Immigrants. Secondly, we expect a report from the Commission, which will describe current national laws and practices, giving us a better overview and understanding of this issue, as well as providing some guidance for Member States. Concerning the view expressed by Mr Deprez, I would like to reassure you: ‘Les États Membres vous écoutent, la Présidence du Conseil vous écoute.’ In the field of legal migration, only the conditions of entry and residence of certain categories of third-country nationals have been regulated at EU level. It is for the Commission to see whether there is a need to propose EU-level legislation also for other categories of third-country nationals. In conclusion, as I have already emphasised, the protection of EU citizenship is about our joint responsibility, shared among all Member States and the European institutions. I am convinced that this issue of granting EU citizenship or residence permits should continue to be followed, in order to raise awareness and possibly to curb practices that could be problematic. I’m sure that we all share this view.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I'm closing the debate. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — With the crisis some EU Member States saw the possibility of improving their income by granting citizenship and residence to applicants contributing money to the country for the purchase of real estate or investing in a company. This has repercussions on the rest of the Union, especially in the case of citizenship, as holders of citizenship in a Member State automatically obtain Union citizenship and several of their rights and privileges and thus can become a form of parasitism of Union common assets. At least half of the Member States allow the granting of 'Golden Visas'. The EP has expressed concern that the beneficiaries of these programmes do not have to meet the same conditions as other applicants. Their concession may prove unfair as they offer opportunities to the rich who are denied to people without money. They offer opportunities for corruption and crime, as second passports are useful to criminals, tax evaders and capital launderers, who may need new identities and places to escape.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. — Gold visas, including the Hungarian settlement bond, represent a huge risk: foreign criminals and corrupt politicians can get access to and resettlement in EU member countries, as well as in third countries where they would otherwise not be able to reach. Meanwhile, the use of the funds thus earned has a significant risk of corruption. It is no coincidence that gold visas are most in demand in countries where there is high political instability due to corruption and financial flows are difficult to follow, e.g. In Russia or China. The free movement of corrupt politicians and criminals is not only a national security risk, but also a financial risk and helps to erode democratic interests. I therefore consider it necessary to act more vigorous than at present. EU institutions need to closely monitor the establishment and reception practices of Member States. In addition, the Hungarian settlement bonds have a peculiarity compared to gold visas, that the settlers did not pay the settlement fee to the state, but mostly offshore companies. Hungary is the only country in which the establishment 'business' is loss-making, because most of the profits are transferred to unknown individuals, presumably political. The Commission and most of the Member States must admit that, although citizenship is the competence of the Member States, the practice of gold visas also has a great task for the EU.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Elisabetta Gardini, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Decision No 1313/2013/EU on the Union Civil Protection Mechanism (COM (2017/0772/2) — C8—0409/2017 — 2017/0309 (COD)) (A-0180/2018).

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must say that I am very happy about today's debate on Civil Protection because it means that we have respected the times and times we had given ourselves. We have worked well and quickly, but above all well despite the tight times and I must say a very thank you to all my colleagues in the various committees, starting with the Environment Committee and all the Other Opinion Committees have worked with a great spirit of constructive collaboration to give a quick response to our citizens and we have achieved the objectives set. A very heartfelt thank you to everyone. On the other hand, Civil Protection is an exciting world. Once one comes into contact with this world he cannot forget it, he cannot leave it, because Civil protection means passion, it means competence, training, generosity, humanity. There are a lot of volunteers, thousands and thousands, hundreds of thousands, if we look at the volunteers in all European countries. We must recognise that a great leap in quality had been made compared to Civil Protection as early as the last legislature, when we had moved from an ad hoc mechanism to this mechanism that we know now of precommitted means and capabilities, because we had learned our lesson from Japan. We know, and we must never forget, that even the most prepared country as Japan was could become, by the level of catastrophe facing, an unprepared country. And now we are here precisely to strengthen the mechanism which has shown some weaknesses, and for this I must particularly thank Commissioner Christos Stylianides who, as soon as the analysis has come out. highlighted weaknesses and room for improvement, it immediately moved to action with this proposal, so we will now have the ability to react more effectively, with the main objective of saving human lives. And we must say really enough tragedies like those we saw last year in Portugal, where 100 people lost their lives, because we had to recognise that when different Member States they face an emergency at the same time, solidarity between countries that exist now is not enough. The collective capacity of the European Union has found itself having to respond to 17 simultaneous requests for help, only being able to respond to ten and in some cases even with delays. Now, thanks to Rescue, the work done together, we can prevent situations like this from happening again. First goal I said saving lives, but our goals are so many because we want to prevent economic losses, environmental damage, protect our artistic heritage, biodiversity. This is our work, then we must always emphasize it, is done in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, because the responsibility remains with the Member States at all levels. That is why we have emphasised, in many points, the importance of local and regional authorities. Let's never forget that the first people responsible for civil protection are precisely the mayors. Civil Protection is not just a response, more and more also prevention, so training, common language, this already exists and we saw it in the exercise which was done, just now, here in Parliament European. Next week in my region, Veneto, and in a neighbouring region, Friuli Venezia Giulia, there will be some European Civil Protection exercises and, as Parliament, on this line I think we have proposed a very beautiful thing, an Erasmus dedicated precisely to civil protection. There would be so many points, the streamlining of bureaucracy and so many other things, but here I stop, leave the floor to other colleagues.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the DEVE Committee. — Mr. Chairman, Dear Commissioner Stylianides, I would like to congratulate my colleague Elisabetta Gardina on an excellently prepared report that aims to strengthen the national civil protection capacities in the Member States without having them existing instruments at the level of the European Union are complemented. Last year's fires in the south of Europe alongside a large number of casualties and material damage revealed flaws in existing large-scale disaster-fighting mechanisms. In this context, I welcome the adoption of provisions allowing the Commission to retain powers, allocate the capacities of the RESCEU system, while maintaining operational control in crisis areas under the control of Member States. Furthermore, what I consider extremely important is enabling a co-financing rate of no more than 55% of eligible costs for transport, for Member States of the European Union that are unable to participate in the pooled civil protection capacities, which is extremely important for the Republic of Croatia. In my capacity as Rapporteur, on behalf of the Development Committee, I also welcome the adoption of a provision that will enable increased training capacities and enhanced exchanges of knowledge and experience in the field of civil protection, with international organisations and third countries, in order to contribute to reducing the risk of disaster in the context of the Sendai Framework. This improved mechanism of the Union for Civil Protection will serve European citizens wherever they are at the moments when Europe is most invited to show solidarity at work, without redundant red tape and delay when time means life.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am very grateful for your initiative to debate and vote on your position on the European Mechanism. It proves this Parliament’s commitment to the better protection of EU citizens, and a strong civil protection mechanism – a European mechanism – is our common priority. As I said when I presented this proposal six months ago, time is of the essence. There is no time to lose. The next disaster, unfortunately, is just around the corner. Thank you very much for your commitment. The Commission’s proposal aims to make the Civil Protection Mechanism better prepared and more responsive to protect European citizens, their livelihoods and our environment. Why do we want to do this? Because, unfortunately, the current system has reached its limits. We, of course, have achieved a lot through the current system, and I am deeply thankful to all the countries that have shown real, practical solidarity to others in times of emergencies. But disasters can strike at any time, with high frequency and high intensity. They can strike simultaneously in several of our Member States due to climate change. Climate change is making the challenge even bigger and more unpredictable. This is why we need to improve our collective preparedness and response. So, dear colleagues, climate change is not fake news. Recent deadly natural disasters, such as the forest fires in Portugal last October – Ms Gardini has already mentioned this – proved that voluntary assistance is sometimes impossible. What is our suggested solution? It is to create rescEU to strengthen the existing solidarity mechanism and to combine it with stronger responsibilities of each Member State. So it is not a revolution; it is an evolution of the current system. Prevention also begins at home. We need to support Member States in their efforts for better prevention, and the European Union solidarity element is strengthened by higher co-financing from the EU budget from the existing voluntary pool. At the same time, as a last-resort safety net, we create a well-defined set of EU capacities like forest fire-fighting planes and medical teams, hospitals, and so on. You have seen our proposal and worked on its details. I would like to thank in particular the rapporteur, Elisabetta Gardini, for leading discussions between various responsible committees, across different political groups, to come up with Parliament’s position – thank you so much Elisabetta – and, of course, also all the shadow rapporteurs and also the rapporteur from the Committee on Development (DEVE), Ms Zovko. My presence here today gives me the opportunity to thank you in person for your work, all of you. I am particularly grateful that you recognise the importance of the prevention and preparedness pillar – the second pillar of this excellent proposal. We need stronger prevention and preparedness activities if we want to address natural disasters in a comprehensive way. We need solid risk assessment and risk mitigation planning; flexible, innovative and adaptable risk management plans; and also even some corrective measures. I agree that the response mechanism must be efficient and workable in practice. It is therefore important that the Commission has a role of strategic coordination. This coordination is key. In an emergency time lost is lives lost. When disasters strikes, we need the authority to take rapid decisions on deployment of rescue capacities, in particular in cases of competing requests – and this is the most critical time. But when it comes to action on the ground, the Member State affected must be in control of operations on its territory. So there is no problem about subsidiarity regarding command and control. I know many of you have already expressed your support on other provisions, which are even more ambitious than the original text. Your report and interest in raising the point today in plenary demonstrate our shared objective of a strong ‘Europe that protects’. Thank you once again for your collaboration and your support in this very critical proposal.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. — (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, congratulations on the Commission proposal which meets our wishes. As we all know, Portugal experienced a tragedy in 2017 due to the fires that occurred. More than 100 human lives were lost, a tragedy that cannot be repeated. If this mechanism were in action, we could have spared these lives and that is our obligation to save human lives. That is why I welcome this proposal, this new mechanism, and I also want to tell you that I will see what the solidarity of the Member States will be when we discuss budgetary issues. For 2019 and 2020, we need EUR 280 million. New financial resources are also needed for new priorities, and so what Parliament advocates is that the EUR 280 million should be additional and not the result of cuts in other policies. That is our defence and we also count on the support of the Commission for this. A mechanism which must not forget prevention and which is obviously an alternative and does not replace the Member States. I will conclude by congratulating the two rapporteurs on this work.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: rapporteur for the opinion, the Committee on Regional Development. — Mr President, first of all I welcome the Commission's proposal, congratulate Commissioner Stylianides for his work and, at the same time, thank the rapporteur, Mrs Gardini, as well as all those who have worked on this report. The existing instruments provided for by the Civil Protection Mechanism had to be adapted to the new realities generated by the current crises. Vegetation fires, refugee waves, terrorist threats, but also hurricanes and earthquakes know no national boundaries. This entails the need to strengthen European mechanisms so as to enable a prompt and appropriate response. However, Member States and, implicitly, local and regional authorities have the main responsibility to take all necessary measures, primarily to prevent, intervene, but also to prepare the population to deal with any limit situations. The European Commission must retain its competence to manage civil protection capacities at European level while respecting the principles of subsidiarity. Finally, I welcome better coordination between the Civil Protection Mechanism and the European Union Solidarity Fund for Disaster Prevention.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Gardini for her excellent work on this report. People often seemed surprised. What does gender equality have to do with the Union’s Civil Protection Mechanism? Well, in fact, a lot. Gender equality is a fundamental value of the European Union and therefore, in the context of the Union’s Civil Protection Mechanism, Member States must consider gender in all phases, from prevention to preparedness and response processes, because natural and human-made disasters, as well as environmental policies, affect men and women differently.  Colleagues, you will also be voting on this very important issue. I urge you to support the view that money should not be taken from funds allocated to the key European policies, such as those promoting rights, equality and citizenship, including all the funds allocated to gender equality and women’s empowerment programmes and projects. Instead, any additional funding necessary should be mobilised using the flexibility provisions of the MFF Regulation.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, first of all, I would like to say that this is a very important report, because in recent years the European Union has had to face a number of catastrophes in the form of fires, floods, gale, earthquakes or migratory crises. These emergencies have shown that the means available in the European Union are not sufficient when a disaster reaches very large dimensions or affects several States, and we have the example in forest fires in warm drought times. The European Union requires cooperation mechanisms tailored to this reality and to the new circumstances that can lead to conflicts or climate change. We therefore support the creation of a European reserve in addition to the Member States' resources, but without replacing them and provided that it is under the coordination of the European Union. It should also be borne in mind that some Member States affected by the crisis cannot be in a position to provide the means previously committed to the European Union Mechanism. Prevention efforts by Member States and their monitoring by the Commission should also be strengthened. The existence of this Mechanism should not allow the guard to be lowering in the Member States, either in the media or in prevention. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Gardini, on the very effective and balanced work she has done on this report which we are going to vote tomorrow. Finally, I would like to welcome the budget increase proposed by the Commission, which is consistent with an increase in the capacities of the Civil Protection Mechanism.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: on behalf of the S& Group D. — Mr President, the European Civil Protection Mechanism is one of the most important programmes in the European Union and is a typical example of practical solidarity both between the Member States of the Union and with third countries. Unfortunately, however, in its present form, it cannot respond to the challenges of ever increasing natural disasters due to climate change. Already in this century we have experienced twice the worst floods in recent years. In 2017 alone, more than 200 people died from natural disasters. More than half of them died during deadly fires in Portugal, where no EU country could send aid. Today, ironically, we voted to activate the Solidarity Fund to make good the damage. The role of the European Union cannot, however, be confined to it alone. Citizens need Union support when they are in danger, and not just afterwards. For this reason, we welcome the European Commission's proposal to strengthen the mechanism by creating ResceU, a pool of last resort facilities, which will be activated when all national instruments have been exhausted and the other Member States cannot help. Aerial means of forest extinguishing, such as Canadair, which have been so lacking in recent years, are just one of the great possibilities that the mechanism should have. At the same time, the creation of ResceU is an opportunity to prepare for future dangers. At the same time, we should help Member States to strengthen their prevention infrastructures by setting up credible response plans. We must also provide the necessary incentives to strengthen the instruments they already have. The European Civil Protection Mechanism and ResceU do not come to replace national civil protection authorities, but to ensure that, even in extreme situations, where national capabilities are not enough, the European Union will be there to protect its citizens. Finally, I would like to thank Mrs Gardini very much for the cooperation we have had.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ECR Group. Dear Mrs Gardini, Commissioner Stylianides. Do you remember the devastating flood in Romania in 2010? Do you still have the pictures of the ammunition explosions in Cyprus? Or have you heard of the EU's joint mobile laboratory, which we used for the 2016 Ebola epidemic in West Africa, among other things, and which — if we follow the news — will probably be used again soon? In all these disasters, we have activated our European civil protection mechanism and have helped cross-border with great solidarity. To make this even better in the future, we are modernising the joint mechanism with RescEU. As shadow rapporteur for my group, I have travelled a lot with technical aid agencies, fire brigades and emergency services over the past few months, always with the same question: what can we do to make ResCEU better and more applicable to you in an emergency? I have tabled these proposals and would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Gardini, for her very good cooperation. Together we have pulled the bureaucratic teeth on the Commission proposal. We avoided duplicate structures and left the command and control where it belongs: with the local emergency forces. That's important, that's good. For example, today we are talking about a report which significantly improves the Commission's proposal, which makes it applicable. rescEU can thus be a powerful instrument for a Europe that delivers and helps in a very concrete way.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr President, I am pleased that, in accordance with this report, national rescue resources must be fully deployed before this RESCEU mechanism is launched. This new European emergency service can bring savings to the Member States when expensive rescue equipment for the fight against chemical or radiation accidents, for example, can be acquired collectively and not every country has to acquire everything separately. But the creation of a new mechanism must not really mean watering down citizens and national civil protection mechanisms. This duty of Member States is particularly weighty in predictable crises, such as wildfires, for which it is known when they usually occur, or floods. They don't come as much of a surprise. Mr President, however, I am disappointed that the Commission's proposal to create and reform the EU civil protection mechanism is not based on an appropriate impact assessment. It is not good legislative preparation that there is no pre-emptive impact assessment, but rather the desire for quick gains. For this reason, I would like to remove a detailed listing of the RESCEU mechanism or the resources to be acquired for the mechanism. The decision to purchase the equipment covered by the mechanism shall be left to experts on the basis of a thorough risk and impact assessment. I myself would not be prepared here in plenary to decide what equipment to acquire. I believe that I have no qualifications for that, especially when this impact assessment and thorough presentation has not been carried out.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission for the proposal in which rescEU is placed at the core. We all realise that this might be necessary when there is a cross-border natural disaster like a forest fire. Think of Portugal and Spain. At that moment, Spain might have been reluctant to jump into Portugal, so there is a need for European action; that is very clear. Therefore, we are very happy with the proposal and that is what we will support. The slight problem with what we are doing now in Parliament – and that is why we were critical in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) – is that for the rescEU, we are now broadening the scope on what it should work towards, even going into the locations of terrorist attacks, etc. I find that dangerous, not because I am against it necessarily, but we know that this is going to be a tough discussion with the Council, especially with more northern European countries. Where I come from, they will be critical of this proposal. If you are starting to broaden the scope of rescEU now, they will see this as a hidden agenda to create a European task force, which is not the case. We are trying to plug a gap that exists. Keep it restricted to natural disasters for now. Let’s make this happen so that we can see that it works. That is why we have put in some split votes in order to get the stuff about terrorist attacks out of it, because that takes the focus away from where it should be, and that is making sure that rescEU can function.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, it was high time we talked about fire prevention. We had to burn half the Iberian peninsula for it, but we're finally here. That's what it's all about. That we talk about the prevention of catastrophes, about anticipating them rather than patching their consequences. Because, ladies and gentlemen, terrorist attacks are a threat, but we are not sure as to when or how or where they will occur. However, about the effects of climate change we do have some certainties. It turns out that the United Nations estimates that 60 per cent of migrations occur as a result of hurricanes, droughts and floods. They also estimate that, by 2050, about two hundred and fifty million people will be considered climatic refugees, words you refused to use. We insist on the need to establish a climate change observatory at European level which also serves to recognize the protection status of those who are displaced from their territories as a result of the decisions we take from here in an absolutely irresponsible way. The Commission welcomes achievements in the area of humanitarian aid. However, in the meantime, the difficult conditions of refugees remain in the camps and we should never forget about women, who are the main victims. Because their bodies are the main battlefields, because they suffer trafficking and sexual violence both in the refugee camps and throughout their entire journey through Europe. Will we continue to look the other way on this extremely painful issue or will we be able to deal with the problem bravely, honestly and with a good sight?

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the European Union. In principle, any coordinating and supportive action by the Union in the event of a disaster is to be supported. Fortunately, the rapporteur also believes that the decision on the use of national capacities should be taken by the sending country. Nevertheless, some problems arise. The withdrawal of once deployed capacity could prove to be legally contentious, since the Commission must be consulted first and not the Member State alone must decide on it.
