Supporting coordination will be clear for me. It is also more than problematic that rescEU could increase the planned own EU capacity by means of delegated legislation at its discretion. A European parallel structure and commercialisation of civil protection would then no longer be avoidable. Hence a clear 'yes' to a supporting Commission, but a clear 'no' to parallel structures of the Commission and no further interference with the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Union and the governments are setting up ResCEU on the nudity of personnel, equipment, infrastructure, to deal with natural disasters in the states, and you also make strange references to the fight against so-called terrorism and the refugee issue. The fleet is made up of the very few existing infrastructures and aircraft in the Member States, which will now be available to the European Union and not to every state, widening the huge shortages, such as those in Greece, leading to tragedies with the dead. However, it is known, for example, that forest fires are extinguished by well-organized, trained and sufficient ground forces, while air fire fighting is required to contain fire until the ground forces arrive. Real protection of natural disasters, from giving forests and other critical infrastructure to major interests, can only be achieved through fire, flood protection and earthquake protection measures and projects, which are not a priority funding for the European Union. That is why we are demanding, under the responsibility of the State, that adequate funding be provided by recruiting permanent staff, with full rights and equipment to meet all real needs.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Security is one of the issues that citizens demand from the European Union in a major concert with municipalities, with the regions, with the Member States, and civil protection is one of the issues of security. That is why I am glad that, in a parliamentary process, we have managed to set up a civil protection model which, on the one hand, honours the principle of subsidiarity, but also the principle of solidarity. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Elisabetta Gardini and also Commissioner Stylianides, for their openness in this whole process. The European Union needs better civil protection. This has been demonstrated not least because aid from other parts of the world was partly faster in forest fires in Portugal than from the European Union. To look for how better civil protection can work, you can first look where it is working well now. I am therefore glad that my country, Austria, was the top representatives of the Fire Brigade Association, the Red Cross and the rescue organisations in the European Parliament in Brussels and reported on how this works for us. On this basis, as one who has been a member of the European Parliament for exactly six months today, I have noted that a parliamentary process can change many things on a Commission proposal that is actually centralised, and that we now have a proposal that we can wholeheartedly endorse because it is given to the regions, the European Parliament. does really give volunteers what they can do and also make civil protection possible at EU level, where we need it at a larger level. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Question about the procedure for the 'blue card'. — I have listened with great interest to what the honourable Member has said. I should just like to put a question to you, Mr President: do you know the opinion of the Land of Upper Austria on the proposal? And do you also know Vorarlberg's statement on the proposals before us?

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr Obermayer, we have examined and incorporated the red-white-red opinions. What you might be referring to is the old Commission proposal. What I refer to is what we have worked out in the parliamentary process in the preliminary discussions in committee, which we can decide here in plenary tomorrow. And this is not the centralist and bureaucratic Commission proposal — if I may say so — but a proposal that honours subsidiarity and freedoms, which we have also repeatedly considered together with the voluntary organisations in Austria and which we have worked out on this basis. to which we can stand fully.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: Mr President, congratulations to the Commission and also to the rapporteur — Mrs Gardini — and the shadow rapporteurs for this work. A work that contributes to the creation of the European Union, to do more Europe. Responding and protecting citizens through solidarity and coordination in the face of disasters is one of the great initiatives we are discussing here today. Climate change is one of the great challenges we face in the immediate future and we could already say that we are fighting it, but we need to know beforehand and be able to prevent the consequences. Every year we have examples of disaster; last year, Doñana, Portugal — with even human lives that perished. Therefore, we have to work from this unity and coordination to avoid it. These disasters have also highlighted the need to work from greater efficiency and effectiveness. Member States alone are unable or unable to fight them in the necessary way. I therefore welcome this initiative and I would like to highlight two points in particular. I am aware that the Climate Change Observatory has not come out and I think it would be an important initiative, but there are other initiatives that can make us move forward and which I hope tomorrow will have the necessary support. We need a risk map that allows us to differentiate which areas face specific risks and thus be able to better prevent them, be they seismic risks or lack of water resources, etc. Ultimately, we can overtake the circumstances of each region, and also adapt and coordinate this with other mechanisms such as the Solidarity. We need to make that fund adaptable to need and fairer, better suited to the per capita wealth of the area, but especially also that it includes the value of the environment. The environment when it suffers also has to be repaired and therefore this fund must incorporate the economic value that the environment also has.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, we advocate cooperation between states in responding to catastrophe situations, especially large ones. Such cooperation may involve coordination of efforts, lending or even sharing resources, but we should not forget some important aspects. The protection of persons, infrastructure, property, protection of territory and nature is an obligation of States, a function at the heart of their sovereignty. In order to be properly exercised, robust and appropriate to the risks involved are necessary. Civil protection services, by their very nature, require a strong connection to the territory and require a deep knowledge of the territory and the populations. This also has implications for chains of command, which, even in situations of cooperation or aid, must remain at national level. The European Union, which has not done everything it could, for example, in the area of supporting Member States in developing their own capacities, first of all, wants to do more than it should. The usurpation of chains of command for a supranational plan, for example, poses risks beyond founded political objection.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: — Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner here and also for the excellent work done by the rapporteur Gardini, because this actually comes out a proposal for a civil protection mechanism with enhanced operational capacity and with specific references to the support given to the outermost regions in in case of natural disasters. It is crucial that this support is translated into a link between this mechanism, the Structural Funds and the Solidarity Fund. The Commissioner has spoken here and a number of colleagues that, in fact, Member States must have control and responsibility for their territories. Cooperation and solidarity must also begin within its own territory and, therefore, it is regrettable that the Portuguese Socialist Government committed itself, in November 2016, to strengthen the Cohesion Fund for the recovery of Madeira by thirty million euros after the fires of August and that, until today, this reinforcement, this support, that solidarity have not yet been poured out and have been nothing but vain words. Prevention, risk management, implementation of warning systems and replenishment of firefighting equipment may be at risk, and this solidarity must therefore be poured out and must also have the support of the Union.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Mr President, it is uncontestable evidence that in recent decades natural disasters have increased in frequency and intensity, taking many human lives ahead and destroying many infrastructures and ways of life. But there is also a recurrence of these natural disasters, and that means that we have the capacity to learn and prevent and try to respond in advance to what is expected to happen to us. This was the key lesson of the Sendai Framework and the Cancun Global Platform, which we need to implement within the European Union. I think it is a good proposal to strengthen the European Union's capacities and resources for action, because while maintaining subsidiarity we need to increase solidarity. We have to respond to disasters affecting European citizens in Europe.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! As you see, we all agree that the Union Civil Protection Mechanism is an effective instrument, and it was important that in 2001, when it started functioning in the European Union, and during the Ebola outbreak, the typhoon in the Philippines or the Nepal earthquake, it was useful. Therefore, my congratulations to the rapporteur for working so well on this report. And because, as Enrique has said at the moment, it partly complements EU humanitarian assistance, any action by this mechanism should be part of the Union's agreement with Sendai to reduce the risk of natural disasters between 2015 and 2030. I believe that An important part of the review of this mechanism is the need to strengthen the training and exchange of good practices with partner countries in order to avoid, inter alia, stories such as the fires in Portugal; it is also important to define the extent of its operation in case of complex disasters, human-caused, or conflicts, and especially in the context of the use of differentiated aid and financial instruments depending on the situation in the country concerned.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: — Mr President, the amendments to the civil protection mechanism have created a valuable reserve of material and human resources. It is good that European citizens and governments understand that this mechanism will not replace the responsibilities of the Member States and that any intervention will always have to be pre-authorised. What changes? investment in training and research, the creation of local intervention groups, the Erasmus Civil Protection programme, enhanced cooperation with third countries and a much more active role of the outermost regions. Strengthening this mechanism means giving real meaning to the word solidarity in the most difficult times a Member State can go through. It also means increasing and giving more protection to the citizens who are part of this Union. There is nothing more important than the certainty that, if necessary, the duty of assistance will be up to all members of this family, of this Union. Commissioner, I can't help but thank you for making a good time with this proposal. No one, not a country, is free from the unpredictability of a catastrophe.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: — Mr President, I would naturally like to welcome the Commissioner and I would also like to welcome the rapporteur Gardini for the work she has been doing and which, in fact, enables the creation, in essence, of this first, to say, truly integrated civil protection system. I have to say that I have been in favour of a European civil protection force for a long time, and therefore I am not satisfied with the degree to which we have reached. Let us say that I think this is a very big step forward, given the situation we had before, but that we, the European Union, must move towards an even more integrated and more advanced system, with a genuine civil protection corps for major disasters. This means, therefore, fires, floods, environmental accidents such as nuclear or chemical accidents, earthquakes and other types of events. For that, I think we should look essentially at this point. No state, particularly small and medium-sized ones, has the resources to be able, by itself, to have all the means necessary for major disasters, and therefore it is absolutely necessary that we have the capacity to share resources, because, as we know, it is very unlikely that a wave of disasters of this nature can be replicated at the same time everywhere and, therefore, this will allow savings for the European Union, European citizens, European states and, at the same time, the advantages of having skills and knowledge and expertise in this area.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr President! I survived the flood, and not as a resident, but as president of Wrocław, a city with more than 600,000 inhabitants, and I remember that there was no aid during the flood. Whereas after it was completed in a very short time we received help from Berlin, Vienna, Budapest, Prague. It was extremely significant. I have experience after this disaster resulting from attending many European conferences on fires, earthquakes, as well as floods. And I know that big cities are capable of securing themselves fairly well on their own. Large, medium, much less small cities — by no means. I would like to congratulate you on this report because I believe that solidarity in disasters is the most important barometer of our European sensitivity, and that it is important to have equipment and to have conditions for aid and rapid response to dramatic situations, because it is about human life, about the environment, but also about national heritage.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the light of the recent disasters that have devastated Europe, many of them linked to climate change, a change in the decision on a Union mechanism of Civil protection was desirable. The mechanism proved to be a useful tool for mobilizing and coordinating the assistance provided by participating states, in response to the crisis, but experience has shown that voluntary offers to Mutual assistance has not always been enough to guarantee the availability of means, and I could mention as examples the cases of Portugal and Italy last summer, countries devastated by numerous fires. The review will serve to address recurring and emerging gaps, in terms of means, in particular by establishing a specific reserve of means of response at European level, and to reassure agility and effectiveness the administrative procedures of the Union mechanism in support of emergency operations. It goes without saying that the mechanism for functioning will have to receive adequate budgetary appropriations and Member States will have to carry out preventive actions to maintain sufficient national means to deal with disasters effectively. I congratulate rapporteur Gardini, who has done a great job indeed.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the debate on the European Civil Protection Mechanism is particularly timely, especially at a time when climate change is leading to natural disasters, floods and fires. Greece, of course, has a bad experience of natural disasters. First of all, it is hit by earthquakes. As you know, in June 2017, we had disastrous earthquakes in Lesvos and, of course, today the European Parliament can tell the residents of Lesvos that, with today's decision, it allocates 1.3 million euros in order to support the repair of the houses, to support the businesses and infrastructure of the island. The same does not apply, of course, to the 23 victims who drowned in the Mandra floods. It is therefore obvious that coordination is needed, the civil protection mechanism needs to be supported, while, of course, preserving the sovereignty of the Member States. A mechanism that should have extra money and not the 200 million it receives from the budget itself. It is therefore necessary to intervene and on that basis we support this effort.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: — Mr President, I personally have nothing against the effect of solidarity between European States at a moment when one of the Member States is affected by devastating fires. However, I am concerned that the European Commission proposal was sewn with a very quick needle, as it also lacks impact assessments, which I do not consider standard and reasonable. The European Commission proposal also acknowledges, for example, that it is key to focus on disaster prevention. In doing so, only 10% of the total amount raised will be spent on prevention measures between 2018 and 2020, and I simply find that a mockery. The European Commission's proposal is fraught with unanswered questions. It increases the administrative burden on member states, appears financially costly and puts too much authority in the hands of the European Commission. Intentions may be good, but significant design flaws can be reflected in the loss of life in the experts posted, and we simply need to prevent that.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I want from the outset to congratulate the Commission on its proposal and, obviously, the rapporteur and the improvements that have been made. Who would not agree to have an integrated civil protection system. We know well, each of our countries has faced problems, catastrophes. My colleague was setting an example of my country with the floods of 2010. I lived an earthquake in Romania in 1977, where thousands of people died. I think it's a first step. We need to cooperate. You were saying, Commissioner, that civil protection starts at home, and the rapporteur colleague said that subsidiarity exists at local level (municipalities), but in some situations we need this integrated mechanism. I think we also need to think about how we can allocate funds, because in the face of earthquakes a lot of buildings, especially in the countries of the East, are unconsolidated, and we are practically useless to intervene after the buildings have collapsed. It can also inform citizens so that they know how to prevent and act in the event of a calamity. I believe that we still have steps to do, but I congratulate the Commission and the rapporteur and hope that it is a report voted on.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, the root cause of these major disasters that cost hundreds of people lives is mainly due to climate change and, of course, to the inability of states to defend their citizens. Thirty years from now, ladies and gentlemen - too many people know this in this Chamber - the land will not be what we know today. The European Union is doing a lot to defend the climate on the planet, but it seems that we have not yet been able, as a global community, to see the major problems that follow, be it droughts or floods, due to climate change. Having said that, and in support of sovereignty, I do not accept the view that forests in Portugal should be burned, with so many hundreds dead, and that there should be no support and fire fighting mechanism from a neighbouring state that may have this potential. Coordination on problems that go beyond our borders is therefore something that must exist.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, dear colleagues, thank you so much for your reflections and remarks. I completely agree with the vast majority of your remarks and, above all, thank you for your commitment to taking action as soon and as far as possible. This is quite important. But let me repeat once again that recent natural disasters and emergencies have taught us two important lessons.  Firstly, the need for more European solidarity in practice: tangible solidarity. That means enhanced response capacity where the European Union can add value. This is also quite important. Secondly – many of you focused on this – without proper prevention and preparedness, Member States will continue to suffer the consequences of natural disasters and emergencies. There is a clear need for more responsibility, and with my services and my colleagues here, we use this as a sort of slogan. Solidarity comes with responsibility. I think we have to focus on this. Self-reliance should not be taken for granted. We need unity in effort, and we need to be ready to act quickly and decisively. The European Parliament now has a key role in the process of adopting the revised Decision. I am happy to know that we are all working towards an ambitious solution. The European Parliament is delivering today on its commitment to move fast and decisively towards more protection for European Union citizens.  I count on your continuous support and am looking forward to starting trilogues as soon as possible. I can assure you that the Commission will do its best to facilitate the discussions to reach agreement with Parliament and the Council as soon as possible. My final point. I heard some misunderstandings, so I am ready, with Elisabetta Gardini, to have many personal meetings in order to clarify these misunderstandings and to explain to you in detail what the proposal is.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very happy and also a little excited because all the speeches I believe have gone in the same direction. You are right, some details perhaps should be better explained because there are concerns that really shouldn't exist, because this work was done in that direction to respond to these concerns. I regret that there is no Eickhout, because, for example, we have absolutely not broadened the purpose of possible terrorist attacks, it is just explicitly spoken in the purpose of the mechanism voted in 2013, So, despite this, we wanted to put in place a slim proposal so that it could be quickly voted on. I am sure that the future of European Civil Protection will go far beyond that because the world changes, there are always new needs and, unfortunately, disasters not only natural but also those brought by man they will continue to be a threat to the safety of our citizens. Sendai, well, we also mentioned it because we have to create more and more resilient territories and therefore prevention is a fundamental chapter that is very stressed here too. So the Commissioner has often said that we must also create new financial instruments, facilitate and unbureaucratise those that already exist precisely because we must first and foremost prevent. Civil protection must be more and more prevention. Where prevention has failed we must be prepared to fight back. Then Mrs Cabezón Ruiz is right, this is to do more Europe, but to make the Europe that the citizens like and therefore I really hope, as the Commissioner said, that the Council will allow us to continue to work with these rapid rhythms, so you have this tool right away because, as you said at the beginning, the next catastrophe could be around the corner. So thank you all again, no country needs to be left alone to face no catastrophe, good work.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 31 May 2018.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Ismail Ertug, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, containing recommendations to the Commission on handling the odometer in motor vehicles: revision of the EU legal framework (2017/2064 (INL)) (A8-0155/2018).

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Today, in fact, it is about tachomanipulation, so to speak, odometer fraud, which is a deliberate and illicit change in mileage. This phenomenon is more widespread within the European Union than we mean. Why is that? Firstly, because it is technically very simple. Secondly, because it is very favourable and because it is only considered a cavalier offence in many Member States, not as fraud. And this leads to the fact that up to 12% of all used cars are manipulated on national markets, and even between 30 and 50% are manipulated in cross-border trade. This will cause economic damage to the European economy, to consumers, of between six and nine billion euros. In addition to this economic damage, we must, of course, also deplore the fact that it is at the expense of road safety, but also at the expense of the environment. Why we in Parliament are quite Community here and have voted by a large majority in the Committee on Transport is because it would be quite easy to change and eradicate this situation throughout Europe. There is best practice, there are good examples, for example in Belgium the so-called car passport system, or even in the Netherlands this national car passport. In fact, at each visit to the workshop, at each main inspection, the mileage is recorded and transferred to this national database at each service, which ultimately means that every used car buyer in Belgium is allowed to request a certificate that ultimately provides information on the mileage. This would, of course, be the best way to tackle the problem at the root of Europe if it were to be cross-border. What do we want to do? We originally wanted a European database solution. But we moved away from that. And now it is the case that we want to have national databases in the Member States, which we then also want to network across borders — this is the most important issue on this issue, on this issue. And then the point is that we expect a legal framework to be established on how which data is collected and stored, when, and how to access it. Again: It should then be the case that the mileage is recorded every time you visit the workshop. This model is simple, it is cost-effective and quick to implement, and would save consumers eight billion euros in one fell swoop. We also want to think about the technical improvements at this point. The technical improvements are obvious. Even today, manufacturers already have the opportunity to use safe technology. There are so-called hardware security modules that could ultimately have a precise effect. They don't cost much either. The study shows that it would cost around one euro per vehicle. In the type-approval regulation, too, we already have an obligation that the data for the newer cars must now be transmitted to manufacturers. Commissioner, we now expect the European Commission — and there is no excuse for me and many in this House that there is no pretext for why we should not do this — and from the Member States, on your initiative, a legislative measure that ultimately translates tachorigulation as fraud. recognises that, and ultimately, legislation comparable across Europe will be created to tackle this problem. Finally, I would like to thank all my shadow rapporteurs for the constructive work they have done in recent weeks and look forward to the debate. (Applause)

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN), and particularly the rapporteur, Mr Ertug, for taking the initiative of drawing up this important report. I absolutely agree with you. Odometer fraud is a long-lasting problem, and we need more effective solutions to fight it. It is also clear that we need to continue to work at all levels to protect our consumers and honest businesses from becoming victims of this fraud. Let me pick up on a number of issues in the report that are of particular importance for our current and future work. First, on the roadworthiness aspect. I agree with you that the cross-border exchange of odometer data is a must to enhance the measures against odometer fraud. Let me be very clear: we are ready to propose the necessary amendments to the relevant legislation as soon as possible. I am very pleased that your report also recognises the key role of Member States when it comes to additional occasions to check the odometer data. Indeed, the current roadworthiness regime has its limitations when providing means against odometer fraud. For example, the first test is four years after the first registration. More frequent checks are likely to reduce the possibility to cheat. However, going beyond regular inspections exceeds what is possible within the roadworthiness framework. The good example of Belgium and the Netherlands shows how important it is that Member States use their competences to introduce additional measures. The Car-Pass system, for example, seems a good example that others may consider following. The roadworthiness legislation has been in application only for ten days as I speak, and it is the very first European legislation to introduce measures which can fight against odometer fraud. Obviously, it is too early to evaluate the impact that this legislation has. On the second topic – the type approval aspect: EU legislation in force since 21 July 2017 includes already requirements for the manufacturer to effectively deter reprogramming of odometer readings. This has to be done by introducing systematic tamper-protection strategies and right-protection features. With the new developments on connected cars it will be even easier for manufacturers or independent operators to keep and provide information on odometer readings. While you can never entirely exclude the possibility of odometer tampering, the Commission will explore amendments to the legal framework to further reduce this risk as part of the monitoring of the implementation of this legislation. The third topic: as regards the consumer protection aspect, odometer fraud or tampering is a problem for buyers of cars in general. This means companies, especially SMEs and also other businesses, such as insurers and car-hire operators. It is also a risk for a very large number of consumers. About 25% of consumers in the Union bought a second-hand car in the last three years. In the European Union, consumers are protected against criminal fraud by specific national laws, and odometer fraud is usually committed by criminal gangs. However, we know that it is very difficult to prevent such fraud, and when the car has changed hands, often with payment in cash, it is too late. Consumers will most probably not get redress, because the vendor will have disappeared – even more in the case of cross-border transactions. On the other hand, when the car has been bought from a retailer, the consumer is protected by EU legislation on unfair commercial practices. However, it has to be enforced by the national consumer authorities. Therefore, it is vitally important that these authorities regularly monitor the practices of economic operators in the second-hand car market. Every two years the Commission publishes a consumer market scoreboard, which shows that this market is one of the least performing for consumers. The last reported that we issued stressed the importance of enforcement and awareness-raising of consumers. The Commission regularly reminds consumer authorities of odometer tampering, and the Commission also funds the network of European consumer centres, and the centres regularly issue guidance on second-car buying and assisting consumers with cross-border problems in all Member States.

name: Georges BACH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I am pleased, Commissioner, that you have recognised the problem, which means that you have quite rightly described that there is a billion-dollar damage to the economy. You have pointed out the importance and fraud — consumers are being bounced by thousands of euros and road safety is very vulnerable. These illegal machinations are rarely punished, and in three Member States tacho fraud is not even considered illegal. You realized the problem, but I feel a little bit that there is actually no will from your side. I do not understand you, even many citizens and many members here in the House do not understand you. You say that it is too early to evaluate the proposed measures. I would say: it's not enough! We need to focus on the Belgian system, where every visit to the workshop, every tyre change, every intervention on the vehicle must really be recorded. Belgium shows that the number of tachometer manipulations has decreased by 95%. We therefore call for the use of hardware solutions at the outset, but also for a legal framework that is urgently needed to ensure the exchange of data across borders. And there must finally be a regular recording every workshop visit. Counterfeiting must finally be punished and penalties must be imposed across the EU — the manipulation of the odometer must no longer be a cavalier offence.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, defrauding the odometer to create the false impression that vehicles are less used is a very widespread phenomenon across the European Union. Thus, the correct assessment of the technical condition of the vehicle is influenced, which creates unfair additional costs for consumers, car traders, leasing and insurance companies, as well as manufacturers. It is also worrying to note that this phenomenon has serious implications for road traffic safety, as it is a cause which contributes significantly to the increase in the number of accidents. Virtually incorrect assessment of the technical condition of a car can have serious consequences for road users, putting their lives at risk. As a representative of Romania in the European Parliament, I believe that a quick solution must be found to solve this problem, especially since Romania, my country of origin, has become a profitable market for the sale of second-hand cars. Given that a large number of used cars sold across borders have the odometer handled, I believe that this phenomenon contributes significantly to the increased number of road accidents in my country. Under these circumstances, the European Commission must come up with strong measures to protect the lives of European citizens. As a legislator, but also in the context of debates on the mobility package, we must do everything we can to stop a phenomenon that endangers human lives. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue-card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question asked by raising the blue card. — Madam colleague, I have a question for you: Why do you think that the European Commission, which so very vehemently defends various consumer matters, is in the case of cars, and in the case of scumbags who rewind speedometers, in this one so liqueous? Why do you think the European Commission, over a four-year — or perhaps even longer duration — criticism, will not take action and do something about this phenomenon that is destroying the European used vehicle market?

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: Answer to a blue-card question. — Indeed, it is a question to the committee. What I can tell you as a member of the Committee on Transport in the European Parliament is that, together with my colleagues, we have raised this issue and we strongly support the fact that it is necessary for the Commission to come, as soon as possible, with a legislative proposal in this regard, and I have the confidence , on the basis of the good cooperation we have with the European Commission and the fact that we are also discussing the third part of the mobility package, which also contains safety and traffic security features, that it will come up with a proposal to this effect.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Commissioner Bulc, you are sitting or appearing here alone as Commissioner for Transport, and that already largely indicates the problem in this dossier. The fraud involving odometers continues to plague the European second-hand car market with an annual economic cost of as much as EUR 8.77 billion. You cannot solve this alone, because the manipulation of odometers is not just a problem of European transport: it also affects the internal market and consumer rights. However, your colleagues will still be absent today. Nevertheless, the solution is obvious. Together with your colleagues, you could propose a realistic framework, recording mileage readings and sharing information with Member States and consumers. Reference has been rightly made to Belgium and the Netherlands. With us, the introduction of the simple Car Pass has reduced fraud cases by 97%. You hear it, there is unanimity in Parliament on the urgency and the solution. Now there is unanimity in the Commission, where the various Commissioners continue to push through the hot potato. I have listened carefully to you and you have opened the umbrella a little by referring to existing instruments, such as the driving test directive. Please be aware that this will not solve the problem of billion-dollar fraud, Commissioner. More frequent registrations are needed, and the consumer must also have access to the data. This is not so much a technical dossier, it is primarily about consumers and citizens. The good news is, we can solve the problem without interference, regulation or complicated procedures.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, things are simple. They were presented by my colleagues. Firstly, it is easy to traffic a meter; second, it is a theft; thirdly, this theft not only ruined consumer money, but puts their safety at stake and has implications for the market both new and second hand. However, solutions seem simple and inexpensive, at least technically, since they have already been proven, particularly — as has been said — in Belgium, with the Car-Pass, and in the Netherlands. Nine billion is a considerable volume, not taking into account, moreover, the side effects I have mentioned on safety in the new market and even on the car maintenance market. We therefore have a very big problem, which is absolutely established, the solution of which seems simple, and to which, oddly enough, the Member States which, for the most part, are not concerned, do not react. This is extraordinary, because it is one of the only offences not characterised by a number of Member States' courts. We can therefore be quite surprised at this position of the Member States and, for once, the Commission has the opportunity to find a solution to all European citizens. Europe's ways to shine are not so common with our citizens. I think, Commissioner, that there are simple solutions. The car manufacturers could be asked to do better, but we know that this will not be a definitive solution and that we will never be assured of the inviolability of the meters. I think, Commissioner, that all garage passages, as for the Car-Pass, do allow meters to be raised and that there is no need for an additional administrative mechanism, which is an incentive to be obligatory. I would simply say that the Commission should put in place a new instrument and not seek to improve existing instruments, and that this instrument is biblical simplicity. I propose, Commissioner, that you make a regulation which is made in two articles. (He agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: question asked by raising the blue card. — You said two very important things that intrigued me. First, that the effect of turning the meters is a threat to safety, life, health. I am interested in whether this is in some sense an estimate and whether it falls within the amount, which the Commissioner also talked about. And the second element frightened me a little: imposing on manufacturers the need to produce meters that can't be reworked, twisted, could trigger a much greater cost than the possible reductions we're facing today. Can that be estimated, too?

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: answer “blue cardboard”. — I do think there are ways to greatly improve the safety of electronic kilometer meters — since they are now electronic — nevertheless, there is no absolute way to guarantee that they are inviolable, since we know that it is a race — indeed, in digital, it is permanent — between attack and defense capabilities. On the other hand, as the Commissioner pointed out, the fact that the vehicles are connected will make it possible to have a real time report with manufacturers, to the maintenance services, which would allow for real-time monitoring of kilometer meters. Therefore, inviolability is unlikely, remote monitoring, for example, would most likely be possible.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, it was a great honour to work on a document entitled “Handling the mileage counter for motor vehicles: revising the legal framework of the European Union” . I am glad that many of my amendments have been passed and managed to find a solution to the situation. Speedometer handling for motor vehicles simply has to end, as it aims primarily against consumers — that is, all of us. At the moment, up to 50% of the cars sold cross-border have a rewind speedometer. This issue will become increasingly up-to-date for Central and Eastern European countries, as government-backed diesel cars from Western Europe come here. The manipulation of speedometers will not wane and therefore it is necessary to take inspiration as quickly as possible from long-functioning systems, such as the now mentioned Car-Pass in Belgium or Holland. There is nothing to wait for when so many citizens are victims of fraud that can be easily prevented. We must be able to stand up for them and end this disgraceful practice.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — I am always in favour of resolutions that allow to defend the interests of all states, and my citizens of Lithuania and their rights. When the actual mileage data displayed on the vehicle odometer are deliberately unlawfully replaced, this is a serious problem throughout the European Union. Mileage data has a significant impact on the value of the vehicle, it is not difficult to falsify them, as has been said here, so I support the proposal to treat odometer counterfeiting as a crime committed by both the person ordering such counterfeiting and the person replacing the data. This should be subject to effective, proportionate, dissuasive and non-discriminatory penalties throughout the European Union in accordance with a similar standard. Adapting the electronic vehicle information system to the needs of consumers in the European Union would make it possible for the buyer to know the true history of the car, to assess the incidents of the car, to assess the degree of damage to the car before the repair.

name: André ELISSEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, every year there is massive fraud involving the reversing of mileage readings of vehicles. Especially in eastern and southern Europe, fraud with the odometer appears to be the rule rather than the exception. The Netherlands has had its own system for a number of years to reduce this fraud, and successfully. When selling vehicles in the Netherlands, there is hardly any question of reversing the counter. We do not need any more European interference. It is up to the Member States themselves to solve this problem. The Netherlands has proven that it is possible. Why should new directives be imposed on the Dutch motorist from this Parliament? This is a typical example of superfluous European drift. I would like to call on Parliament and also the European Commission to leave the Member States alone. Often more European intervention is not the solution to a problem, but rather part of the problem.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I think we need to deal with this issue, to protect consumers in their own national country but also on a cross-border basis, because it is fundamentally an issue of fraud, an issue of safety. Fraud, because of the economic cost to the economy – and those who are purchasing second-hand cars don’t have the same information as the vendor, and it is cheating and the cost will be more expensive for a car that is not what they think they’re buying. Of course there is the safety issue. We know that there are regular checks in terms of maintenance of the car, and if the mileage has been tampered with, those checks won’t be administered, leaving those who have purchased the car in a very dangerous situation. I want to thank Mr Ertug for his report. It’s had strong support in the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Something needs to be done, and we have pointed out how that can be done, pointed to the success of the Europass system and how that works, and indeed technology today can certainly help us in ensuring we have a solution for consumers across Europe.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: - Mr President! The title of the report sounds very elegant. I will remind you — these are recommendations for manipulation and the most important word is the word about manipulation. And the reality here is much worse and ruthless and you would have to be called as it in essence is. We are dealing with large-scale knowledgeable fraud in the sale of used cars in Europe. This fraud strikes first and foremost on buyers because they end up paying higher prices, after all, they incur the costs resulting from poor condition when it comes to safety. In Poland, it is estimated that up to eighty percent of used cars imported have reduced mileage on the meter. I support with all my power the fight against these crimes, because this reprehensible phenomenon should be called as it is.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! Manipulating the condition of the car meter is a practice that is not only illegal, but should be punished severely. Poland is in a group of countries where such manipulations are prohibited and actions are taken to reduce the scale of fraud. Using the website, it is possible to obtain a free report on a vehicle registered in Poland, including obtaining information on the condition of the vehicle meter, which was noted during the last technical test. I believe that this type of solution should be the standard in force across the Union. Only in this way will we be able to protect car buyers and users from the effects of fraud and manipulation of vehicle operating history. Mr Ertug, we fully support your report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: – Mr President, from time to time there are problems which need cross—border solutions and the issue of odometer tampering is one of those times. If 30% of cars sold across borders in the European market are having their odometers tampered with, then we are dealing with a massive problem costing innocent citizens billions of euros.  Clearly this cannot continue and people must be protected from the criminal activities of a few unscrupulous crooks. A database containing the mileage details of every vehicle would be helpful, but how would this be maintained and checked for accuracy? Where would the mileage details come from, and who would be inputting that data? It is all very well having more and more data kept on our citizens, but criminals don’t care. Our citizens do need strong and effective enforcement of existing laws designed to tackle this issue. Make this a priority and make the penalties far more severe. Anyone found deliberately tampering with vehicle odometers for financial gain should face lengthy prison sentences and hefty fines.  (The speaker refused to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andor DELI
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleague Ismail Ertug. But I will turn now to English. Mr President, mileage fraud is a widespread phenomenon. I do not exaggerate when I say that when buying a used car, everyone will remember that maybe you tricked the odometer. In addition to significant damage to consumers, this widespread phenomenon also threatens road safety. Due to the very easy access to restore devices and the relatively easy use of them, the odometer of almost every second car is counterfeit data, false numbers are found in the national markets, and in international sales and purchases, according to the data known to us, almost every second car has a counterfeit data, false numbers show. Thus, fraud can increase the market value of a vehicle from 2000 to 5000 euros, mainly affecting those who want to buy a car for small amounts. The situation is even more devastating for the Member States acceding after 2004 compared to the Western European average. We cannot allow our region to become a depot of cars that have already been scrapped in the West and show false numbers. We must do everything we can to ensure that this practice is eliminated. We need legal and technical barriers and we need to create a database that will allow cross-border tracking of mileage of motor vehicles.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: — Mr President, first of all, I want to thank rapporteur Ertug for the report, which not only describes a serious problem in the used market in the European Union, but also takes a close look at the solution. I fully support his proposals. The proven methods already established by some Member States have been known to the European Commission for a long time, so I don't see what is waiting for. Last term, I worked as one of the rapporteurs of the vehicle technical competence package. We already called for the mileage status to be recorded during technical checks and the European Commission examined the possibility of exchanging such data between Member States. Four more years have passed since then, and the speedometers are cheerfully bottling on. That this is not only causing huge harm to consumers, I don't need to repeat. It's unacceptable. Indeed, the European Commission must come up with a concrete proposal for a solution as quickly as possible. The European Parliament has an idea and will certainly support you, Commissioner.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, cars whose mileage has been tampered with are at the disadvantage of consumers, traders and the environment. Unacceptable. We are losing approximately EUR 9 billion in Europe to this fraud. This is literally a cross-border problem, because more and more cars are being traded from abroad. It is nice that the Commissioner has listened to Parliament's proposals, but please do not reinvent the wheel. There are good systems in the Netherlands and Belgium. These are effective and proven. Now make sure that these are copied and imported throughout Europe. Let us not invent additional Brussels rules, but simply copy a proven system and, together with your colleagues on the internal market, make sure that one of these systems is applied throughout Europe as quickly as possible. Ready is Kees.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just two days ago, here in this House we were discussing the third mobility package, with which the Commission believes that it can conclude its legislative actions in the field of transport, but as we can consider concluded our work, when despite three packages on mobility and numerous pieces of legislation aimed at preventing fraud, two-thirds of the car market Does used continue to grow in complete lawlessness, without retention for our efforts to ensure transparency for consumers? Until there is harmonisation of Member States' national law, all our efforts will be incomplete. How can we hope for the effectiveness of European regulations if each Member State maintains penalty schemes that are completely conflicting from each other? Why is tampering with an odometer punishable by prison in France, while it is only sanctioned by a €220 fine in Slovakia? Not to mention even more unlikely national situations, where the same offense is not even considered such.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. With our recommendations to the Commission on combating tacometer manipulation, we are taking an important step towards increasing protection for European motorists and tackling a long-term problem. Such manipulations are not isolated cases. The ADAC, Europe's largest transport club, points out that one in three used cars in Germany is affected by tacho-manipulation. Therefore, such a legal framework as we are discussing today is crucial to ensure greater transparency and consumer protection. It's not just about the economic damage. This also means that information is lost on maintenance intervals and control intervals, and this also threatens road safety on our roads. Technologies are available, we have Member States that have already introduced systems. Only an encryption technology such as hardware security modules can make a contribution here. That would be an investment of only one euro per car. This investment would make it easier to prevent such manipulations. I can only call on the Commissioner to take up our will, which we will also be expressing tomorrow with an overwhelming majority for our colleague, Ertug, and to present a legislative proposal as soon as possible.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, today's report confirms that the European second-hand car market includes a number of risks to consumers and that it is absolutely mandatory that measures be taken to protect the interests of car buyers. Although this report focuses only on one issue, namely the handling of mileage, in reality we are all aware that there is much more falsified data, which is related to the history of used cars and which are put up for sale. The falsification of this data leads not only to a situation where buyers are fooled financially, but also to one where their physical integrity is directly threatened. It is appropriate, at Member State level, to implement a technical and legal mechanism providing for the history of all machines on the European market so that they are registered in a common database. I propose, Commissioner, to establish an identification platform and this common database, which will provide consumers with free information about the history of a car. I welcome this report, which proposes similar solutions, and I think it is important that discussions towards introducing such a measure take place as quickly as possible at the level of the European institutions, but also at the level of the governments of the Member States.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, it may seem a little special that this plenary session of Parliament is discussing the manipulation of car travel meters. But as we see from this information, there is a very broad problem: the trade in used cars is up to two or three times larger than the trade in new cars, and as we know, especially in cross-border trade, it is extremely common for travel meters to have been manipulated even every in the third or second car. For consumers, this is a big economic problem and also safety problem, because for the ordinary consumer, in general, that mileage driven by car is the main criterion on which the condition of the car is assessed. This has big implications for what kind of purchasing decisions consumers make, and we know it will have a negative impact on safety as well. The price of a car is naturally tied to what amount the car has been driven. Of course, you have to wonder that the actions outlined in this report do not create extra bureaucracy, but we have good examples that records from which the history of the car can be reliably verified have been sought to organise nationally, either voluntarily or by force of authority. I think it is important to think now about how we could create such a registry system on a Europe-wide basis. There have been references to the opportunities brought by blockchain technology — the block chain chain chain — but that naturally takes time. But this is a very important issue for the functioning of our internal market and consumer confidence.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: — Odometer fraud costs Europeans billions every year. This is a problem well known in Bulgaria, which has one of the highest import values of used cars in Europe. Studies show that between 40% and 80% of cars in my country are manipulated. This is a serious problem and not only a problem in the market, but also of competition. This is also an economic loss of EUR 8 billion for the whole European Union. I am therefore pleased that we are proposing a European solution to a European problem and I hope the Commission will stick to the measures and solutions in this report. The cases of car odometer manipulation have a direct impact on both the self-esteem of European consumers and on the trust of our voters and consumers. Manipulations can be stopped. There are such solutions, as solutions found by the Netherlands and Belgium, and have led to an end to the counterfeiting of the odometer of cars. Let us not make our European consumers regret their purchase. Let's make sure they're better protected.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! Perhaps I will see a bit of the role of devil's advocate, which is someone who would like to defend the Commission and the Commissioner, because I hear about such unilateral direction of the charges against the Commissioner and the Commission. The proceder we're talking about is absolutely punishable. This is simply a crime. I myself once fell victim to such a crime. I practically lost the car I bought, because it was no longer usable at all. But I want to say that, after all, this is one of the many crimes that are being carried out against consumers purchasing cars. And, for example, the issue of post-accident repairs? After all, practically speaking, most of these cars in the second circuit are after an accident, but they are all sold as accident-free. We will also be building an IT database on whether or not these cars were once involved in accidents. I want to say that it is undoubtedly right to expect the Commission, but also the governments of the Member States, to find an effective way to prosecute criminals. By contrast, it is proposed ways that will be directed at honest vehicle owners, because they will be the ones who will be surveillance, investigated, for example, in terms of their mobility. Let's look for a way that will be rational.

text: — Sur President, at the time of the year, in which FL-unjon Ewropea, fil-fatt, speedy jalment dawk li jkunu żgЂażag, jispi Dan huwa suq li, anki f'dak il-livell, huwa kkalkulat li huwa madwar tliet darbiet aktar minn dak tas-suq ta' karozzi U gŵyl alhekk hemm bżonn il-protezzjon gallowaliex hawn qed nitkellmu fuq is-sigurtà fuq it-toroq, qed nitkellmu wkoll fuq spejjeż żejda li persuna li mingo ffrankat biex xrat dik il-karozza jkollha tagknomel gdylaraliemel x ma jkollhiex ir-record preiż ta' kemm-il mili kienet instaqet galihom dik il-karozza . Dan huwa wkoll il-mod kif Il-parliament Ewropew jagmel differenza vera fil-enajja tan-nies.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate my colleague Ertug on the report. I think you have realized that Parliament's majority position is in support of the report, so the Commission needs to get to work. In the TRAN Commission there was only one vote against, it was almost unanimous. It is clear, no longer revert on effects, on consumers, on people's lives, fraud. All things have been said. I want to add, however, to keep in mind that the most vulnerable are people with lower incomes. They buy, as a rule, second-hand car. Children, their family can be endangered. After all, it is an inequity and can only be resolved across borders. We cannot solve this way, let every country have a different rule, because, Commissioner, we are talking about connectivity, digitalisation, the single market. Why should we not have rules here too, when we have so many negative economic effects, people's lives, obviously accidents on the roads of the European Union. Please, Commissioner, maybe you can give us a time limit in your reply on what you are going to do with this proposal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, falsifying the mileage meter is a carabine fraud. It creates enormous damage to consumers themselves, but also to traders. We have, as stated, a loss of around EUR nine billion. It is very dangerous because it is related to road safety and creates problems for the protection of the environment. An exemplary punishment of those who tamper with the speedometer is imposed. This should apply to all Member States. If there were exemplary punishments, if there were, in the present case, regulation on a criminal offence, it is obvious that very few would attempt it. If, in fact, we had the imprisonment and confiscation of the vehicle as an ancillary penalty, I believe that no one would dare to proceed with this process. Harsh penalties are therefore needed and, of course, the use of good practices, such as those mentioned in Belgium and the Netherlands. It is therefore necessary to make use of good practice in all the Member States of the European Union.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Ismael Ertug, not only for bringing an important issue before the plenary, but also for having managed, perhaps entirely, to unite the whole plenary in favour of the views he has expressed and which, of course, have also been mentioned by the Commissioner. I, too, argue that this thing should be considered a serious offence, considered a fraud. However, we must see that this fraud also causes many accidents. This is a much bigger issue than the very issue of the financial damage suffered either by the Member State or by the citizens themselves. The accidents and the deaths that are often the result of the fact denounced in this debate. I therefore agree that information and correct records must be transmitted from one country to another, so that the buyer has knowledge, and that the necessary legal framework can be created in this direction.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this most engaging and important debate. I have taken good note of all your comments. Odometer fraud is indeed a major problem, and we clearly need even more effective solutions to fight it in the future, but please acknowledge all that we have done already up to now. I am sure that that will have a very positive effect on the market. Please inform all of your voters of the activities that have been done. Let me go through the major points again.  We now have new roadworthiness rules which oblige inspectors to collect odometer data, and they have been in force for only 10 days. I hope everybody in Europe knows that. We will assess the implementation, as required by the legislation, by 2020 and propose additional measures if we find that they are necessary.  Secondly, we have new type-approval rules that were set and adopted last year with new obligations for manufacturers to address the odometer fraud issue. The Commission plans to review their application and then decide on future steps if necessary.  Thirdly, cross-border data exchange is the next step. As I said before, we will now use the budget allocated by Parliament in pilot projects to prepare a proposal going in this direction. Beyond legislation, awareness-raising is essential. Member States must exchange experience and good practices, and this is what we promote in the Commission’s roadworthiness committee, which pays special attention to automotive topics.  So as you can see, there were four clear actions that we have taken just in the last few years. We will be very much directly engaged with you to take the next steps, but let’s see how far we get through the implementation of these four elements.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner. First of all, thank you for the broad support here in the House for this proposal. Commissioner, let me be clear once again: yes, the last regulations we have carried out in recent years are a right step in the right direction. Only, this will not solve the problem of tachomanipulation. For example, in the road worthiness package, Article 16 states that the Commission should assess the feasibility, costs and benefits of setting up an electronic platform for vehicle information and the exchange of information. This is a 2014 directive, what has happened so far? Nothing! Nor will what you have described help if we fail to achieve what we have described as the next step, precisely the exchange, the interconnection between the Member States. What does all that is in the current regulations help if the data is stockpiled somewhere? No, they need to be networked so that anyone on site has the ability to access this data. Otherwise, all that we did is good practice, but it will not lead to the goal. That is why there is no reason not to do this, even economically. According to the study, this tamper-proof software costs just one euro per car. Well, that can't be the problem. Again, it's clear that we don't want any new rules. We only want to bring together the existing systems that have proved their worth at European level. For this we need the European Commission. There's no point in waiting until 2020 at all, because now — this is a low-hanging fruit — so these are things that can be done right away when the European Commission internally agrees on who is responsible. And if this step is taken, then all in all this will be a good solution. But just waiting until 2020 is no solution. As I described it: the best practice is on the table, let's build the national databases, let's network them, then the problem will be solved relatively quickly! Thank you once again to Parliament.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 31 May 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — Odometer fraud is a widespread phenomenon which seriously puts road safety at risk, distorts the proper functioning of the internal market and imposes costs additional indebts to consumers, insurers, used car retailers, leasing companies and even builders. It estimates that the resulting economic damage for the Union as a whole is between EUR 5.6 billion and €9.6 billion. In addition to the economic effects, there are also serious negative repercussions on road safety. The problem of odometer fraud should be addressed by taking a tiered approach. Forceding manufacturers to specifically protect odometers from handling is a first step that will better safeguard all new cars placed on the market. It would also serve a solution based on a uniform European database which, through the EUCARIS system and a European blockchain network, would collect all mileage records made in the EU during periodic technical checks and maintenance and control in workshops, allowing cross-border exchange of information.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. — Manipulating mileage meters in motor vehicles is one of the more serious crimes that increase the risk to road safety, and also subject to high, additional costs for citizens of poorer low-income regions. Not only is it massive fraud causing losses in the poorest families, it is also a crime ruining confidence in the used car market, which is the lowest of all European Union commodity markets today. Unfortunately, vehicle mileage rigging is still a very common phenomenon that disrupts the proper functioning of the internal market and generates burdens for consumers, insurers and car dealers in the secondary market. It is estimated that 80% of cars imported for example into Poland have reduced mileage. Illegal reduction in the number of kilometres travelled increases the value of the car by an average of €3 thousand. We cannot continue to tolerate impunity and put citizens at risk of loss. My country, Poland, is today in a group of countries where such manipulations are prohibited and actions are taken to further reduce the scale of fraud. We plan to have total vehicle mileage tampering soon treated as an offence punishable by imprisonment ranging from 3 months to 5 years. I would like to see such high standards apply universally in all EU countries. Creating legal, technical and operational obstacles that make reversing meters impossible should be our top priority today.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. — The manipulation of odometer status records is probably as old as the counter itself. A person ignorant of the matter might believe that there is no fundamental problem. After all, it's about what technical condition the automobile is in. On closer discussion, everyone starts to realize that tyres, all sorts of seals and, perhaps, plastics get older with age. This is true, but looking at the prices of used vehicles, we find that there are two almost equivalent factors that determine the price of the car, that is its age and mileage. In view of current estimates of the number of vehicles subject to national or cross-border trading, so-called mileage bottling is an absolutely fundamental problem. If up to 12% of the vehicles on the national market and 50% of the vehicles imported have been through odometer handling, this is a fundamental problem that deserves resolution at EU level. That is why I support proposals to create a linked database of all vehicles operating within the EU. Furthermore, I consider the introduction of a system of automatic transmission of information on the number of mileage, the estimated price of EUR 1 per car. After linking the databases of stolen vehicles and their documents, this is the next major step leading to eliminating unfair trades and deceiving customers.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: in writing. — Falsifying the mileage of automotive meters is now a widespread phenomenon that has an absolute negative effect on the functioning of the used car market in Europe. According to current statistics, this procedure, only in the case of Poland, applies to approximately 80% of cars brought to our country, thereby affecting the reduction of road safety and making the decisions of people buying cars on the secondary market are made on the basis of untrue information given by rogue sellers who premeditated understate the meter's indication to get a higher, more favorable price to themselves. Only financial losses associated with this alone are around EUR 9.5 billion. Therefore, we cannot allow for a situation where consumers when buying a car are overtly cheated and losing their hard earned money. It is important that, in addition to the financial account, we also have safety considerations in mind. Suppose that someone buying a dozen years old car whose mileage is underestimated by up to 100 thousand kilometers, usually does not realize that the technical condition of this vehicle can leave much to be desired and most importantly pose a risk to road safety. I am pleased that the European Parliament has given a clear message that there is no place in the EU for this type of illegal practice and that we have taken steps together to tackle this illegal proceder.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question on extending the scope of Chapter I of the Brussels IIa Regulation to include registered partnerships (recast) addressed to the Commission by Lidia Joanna Geringer of Oedenberg, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs (O-000027/2018 - B8-0023/2018) (2018/2551 (RSP)).

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Deputy author. — (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. On 18 January this year, we took a very good decision, on a very good basis by the European Commission, on the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters and parental responsibility. I was very pleased with this legislative proposal, which was made, especially since some of the proposals I made in a previous report had also been included. That's a good law. There is greater legal certainty, faster decisions are taken, and this is very important, especially when it comes to custody issues. However, the European Commission's proposal has a very important catch, namely: it applies only to married couples. Registered partnerships are left out. And this is simply unbearable. Unbearable, Commissioner, because there are more and more registered partnerships in the European Union, and fewer and fewer people are making a marriage. Society is changing, lifestyles in the European Union are changing — but the European Commission has simply closed its eyes to it. This is ungrasp, and unfortunately it is a recast. For citizens who do not know what that is, this means that the European Parliament can only amend the articles that the European Commission has also amended. This means that we were not allowed to table any amendments on the scope. We, as the European Parliament, have not been able to ensure that this very law is also extended to the registered partnerships. And this, I think, is very backward, very backward by the European Commission. And look at your own numbers! Take a look at Eurostat figures collected by the European Commission: there are fewer and fewer marriages. More and more people are living in registered partnerships. Why should these people who choose a registered partnership not have the same rights, the same access as spouses? Why are the people who, after all, can already make use of the right to registered partnerships in 19 countries of the European Union and are in many cases even recognised for adoption excluded from this right, which is very good? That is why I also ask the European Commission: why did you not include registered partnerships in your proposal on Brussels II? Does the European Commission not see any regulatory requirements for registered partnerships in relation to Brussels IIa? Does the European Commission not see discrimination in the exclusion of registered partnerships? I say: yes, this is discrimination and you are actually the guardian of the Treaties of the European Union. In the Treaties, non-discrimination is one of the very essential points that we are discussing again and again. Will the European Commission intend to make up for this failure to exclude registered partnerships in the foreseeable future? If no, why? If yes, when? After all, this is also an important question, unfortunately, a great opportunity was missed. I am also very much looking forward to the comments made by my colleagues on the right of this European Parliament, who have tried to prevent this question to the European Commission from coming to plenary. And I find that intolerable: why do you not accept that people who have opted for registered partnerships do not have the same rights, even though it is already the case in our society. Commissioner, you are considered to be one of the progressives in the field of digitisation, as one of the cosmopolitans, as one who says: yes, we need to adapt our social order to the realities of today. I am now very curious to see how you will respond to this question, because what we are seeing on this issue is simply backward and unacceptable.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the European Parliament for raising the issue of registered partnerships in connection with the Commission’s proposal for a recast Brussels IIa Regulation. This proposal facilitates the resolution of cross-border legal issues in family matters and provides protection to children. Our proposal focuses on the shortcomings regarding parental responsibility matters. Parliament has also flagged these up in the past. They now require our urgent action. As Parliament has noted, we did not propose changes to the provision on matrimonial matters by addressing, for example, the possibility for couples to choose a court for divorce, or extending the regulation’s scope to same-sex couples or registered partnerships. The results of the public consultation undertaken by the Commission did not provide sufficient evidence to justify making urgent changes in the area of matrimonial matters. Our assessment was that it is not the right time to change these rules. The key objective of the Brussels IIa revision is to propose significant improvements for children facing difficult situations. These need to be addressed urgently. I am happy that Parliament and the Commission have a common goal. In cross-border cases we want to prevent children from ending up as hostages of long legal disputes. We also want to facilitate cross-border legal proceedings for families by various means, including by reducing the length and cost of procedures. Very importantly, both Parliament and the Commission want to provide the same level of protection to all children. I would like to stress that, in our proposal, we have ensured that the improved protection of children applies to all children, irrespective of the civil status of their parents: that is, regardless of whether or not they are married or in a registered partnership. A prompt agreement on this proposal, requiring unanimity in the Council, is within reach. The Commission is committed to engaging closely in the negotiations with a view to finding a good outcome for the benefit of children.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: on behalf of the EPP Group. Mr President, the main objective of the European Union is to maintain the area of freedom, security and justice, and it is essential for this to have judicial cooperation, especially in family matters, in the European Union. That is why the recasting which we presented in January with the rapporteur, our colleague Tadeusz Zwiefka, as a compendium, a recast of all that cooperation in the field of family law, was a step forward in order to have greater legal certainty, so as not to have many gaps and many unnecessary delays and many confusion and, above all, became the cornerstone of such judicial cooperation. Uniform procedures were established with regard to separation, divorce, matrimonial nullities and also parental responsibilities in cross-border situations — which, as you know, are increasing. Thus, there was a free movement of decisions, judgments and documents, and also that there were no delays that always hurt the child, who must be the main object of that regulation. It is true — the Commission has said — that there are 19 Member States which have de facto couples regulated, but in Europe there are nine States that do not. And it is true that it is a growing reality: there are more and more children born to couples who are not married and there are more and more couples in fact. And that is why the question we are asking the Commission is: do you think that regulation of that reality would jeopardize that agreement which is necessary in order to have such cooperation? And as long as the goal is to protect the child.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
