text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Commissioner, this question is very important and very important for the citizens of Europe. There are very few subjects and possibilities that the European Union has to intervene on the civil status laws of individual countries. One of these is the regulation of “Bruxelles bis”, that is, the regulation dealing with jurisdiction, recognition and implementation of legal decisions on matters of marriage and parental responsibilities. Well, I think that having eliminated and not wanting to encompense within this jurisdiction, within the “Brussels bis” regulation, unmarried couples or couples who have not contracted a marriage because they chose it or because it is not possible in their country to contract a marriage — I think same-sex couples, same-sex couples — is an ethical state idea. We cannot afford to have a Europe that legislates as an ethical state, we need a Europe that protects its citizens, and in particular, as you also said, protects especially the children and children who are in these couples. There is still too much discrimination on our continent, Commissioner, and we need to discuss and fight these discrimination. We often talk, always, about the rule of law in this House. We have talked about it and we talk about it at every plenary session, and this is one of those occasions when Europe can really do something. You said, Commissioner — and I am closing with this — that this is not yet the time to discuss this recognition. Look, Commissioner, that the right time to recognise a right is always yesterday, is never tomorrow.

name: Marek JUREK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! A family based on a monogamous marriage geared towards parenthood is the foundation of society, its physical, moral and cultural duration. The state should not put this social institution next to unions focused solely on individual satisfaction. Such relationships are inherently private in nature. Fidelity to this truth is a matter of preserving the common good and the future of our nations. I expect a clear declaration from the Commission that the Commission will not engage the policy of the European Union against countries maintaining these principles, that it will respect the decisions expressed directly by the societies of Croatia or Slovakia — decisions which are, moreover, coincide with the legislation that functions in very many of our states. The European Union has assured our nations that it does not engage in contestation of the ethics of family life and we expect the European Union authorities to be faithful to this commitment.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to add my voice to the point made by my colleague Mr Viotti that now is the right time: we have to practice what we preach. We are so concerned about the rule of law and the rights of citizens: we cannot waste time. And I would say that the Commission has artificially bound Parliament’s hands by using the so-called recast technique. This absolutely forbids us to solve this problem, and I think that is not fair. The Brussels IIa Regulation is outdated. It is supposed to help the free movement of judgments in matrimonial law, but it’s 15 years old. Is it not time to modernise it, in accordance with the changes that we have seen in our societies? Registered partnerships may not have been a big deal in 2003, but now they are an established part of matrimonial law. So let’s act. The EU must protect the rights of registered partners too.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: - Mr President! A child-friendly EU is a good EU for all of us. Recasting the Brussels II regulation is extremely important so that family law in the EU takes into account the best interests of children in disputes over marriage and custody issues, especially given that more citizens are having children across national borders today. We must remember that the number of children of unmarried or same-sex couples continues to increase in the EU. It is distressing to see how the EPP and also the conservative, Swedish politicians in this assembly fight time and time again against proposals that would strengthen the rights of these children. On Monday, they even voted against this debate. Unfortunately, the new regulation does not include registered partnerships, even though 19 of the EU's member countries, including Sweden, already allow such partnerships or, as in Sweden's case, marriage. Due to marriage often being defined exclusively as an opposite-sex covenant, the state of law becomes unclear for children within registered partnerships. But this is how we can't have it! In the light of this, I wonder what the Commission intends to do in terms of registered partnerships? How to ensure that children are protected? Does the Commission intend to extend its scope to registered partnerships in order to increase citizens' access to justice in the EU? And in such cases, when? The kids can't wait.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, I must say that, unfortunately, still today, not all Member States of the European Union have introduced equal marriage for same—sex couples, and it’s true that we are not to legislate on this. But until the time comes when we have full equality between same-sex couples and couples of different sexes, civil partnerships and registered partnerships should be treated as equal in European Union legislation. Mr Commissioner, none of the arguments that you have given now rule out including registered partnerships in this legislation. Actually, the only real argument that I can see that is on the table right now is that the Commission is backing off vis-à-vis right-wing governments who do not want registered partnerships to be included, and I can only agree with the colleagues speaking about this. We stand up for the rule of law, we stand up for equality, we stand up for freedom in this European Union. Now would be the time for the Commission to actually show this commitment in real terms. So introduce registered partnerships, because they should be equal, because all citizens deserve the same rights.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Mr Chairman, the Commission's decision to approach the partial amendment of the Regulation is only acceptable to Member States and citizens of the European Union as it has been shown that the existing scope of the Regulation in family law regulates these sensitive issues satisfactorily. Since the Brussels IIa Regulation also determines in its content the recognition of judicial judgments of one Member State in another, the extension of the scope to registered partnerships which are not known to all the legal systems of the Member States shall not be authorised by the Council because it would thus directly affect national legislation in the field of definition of family and marriage which would constitute a precedent breach of the principle of subsidiarity and legal trust with respect to the European Union. I urge the Commission not to approach the extension of the scope of the Regulation, as this would create twofold regulation and widen the gap between the governing countries and those who do not know the institute of registered partnership, and in particular on the adoption of children. The European Union needs harmonisation of the legal system, not additional division, duplicity of legal provisions or political pressure on each other.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate Mrs Gebhardt, who has put forward strong arguments on the question we are waiting for an answer. Things, after all, are in motion, society is evolving. We have, and I know in my country, a lot of partnerships, families that have been created, especially in the younger generation, now, and which do not formalize marriage, but result in children. After all, we have to think about what happens to those children, because there are situations where after 5 years, 6 years, 10 years, and the children remain in a fuzzy situation. Commissioner, I wanted to ask you - you argued that you did not think about amending the regulation because from a study it turned out that it was not necessary. Can you present us in Parliament an impact study related to this situation? How many partnerships do we have in the European Union? What's the share between marriages? How many children are there in these partnerships? I mean, having a foundation for what you stand for, so you can come and tell us that there's never a need for change.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mrs Gebhardt, too, for having brought a very sensitive issue to Parliament. I have really been surprised to hear that the legal status of children raised with parents with a cohabitation agreement is not regulated in the European Union. But I was much more surprised by the Commission's response, which I have to say I did not fully understand. As if the Commissioner was saying that this is not the case, because children from a civil partnership are included, but then as if I heard something about the agreement of all the Member States. I think this needs a clear clarification and I do not need to repeat that thousands of more children are born without their parents being married in the standard way.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: — Mr President, we know that, as in 2015, even today in the Council, there is no unanimous support for extending the scope of the regulation on cooperation between Member States in family matters and registered partnerships. I repeat the reasoning of the states that opposed, and I quote: no Union initiative in this area should conflict, even indirectly, with the fundamental principles of family law in the Member States. The reason why we are dealing with this issue today is obvious: to create political pressure on those Member States that do not want to adapt their idea of marriage and family to fashion trends. Fortunately, this parliament has no authority on this issue. That is why I wonder that we are giving room for such debates.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me say thank you to the House again for your continued support for the Commission’s proposal and for raising significant points about its contents. At this stage the Commission does not have sufficient evidence to justify making a proposal to amend the provisions of the Brussels IIa Regulation on matrimonial matters. However, we have ensured that all its provisions that aim at improving the protection of children will apply equally to all children, regardless of the situation of the family where they live. Children are at the heart of this reform. The separation of their parents is difficult enough. They deserve proceedings that clarify their situation as quickly as possible and take their best interests into account. So we need to speed up cross-border cases, and we need these new rules quickly for the sake of children’s welfare. To be absolutely clear: I was among the initiators of the civil partnership law in Estonia and, of course, I voted in favour of this law in Estonia. But now our aim is to help our children as quickly as possible, because they are in a difficult situation and, as has already been said by Members of the Parliament and as I said in the very beginning, in order to help our children unanimity in the Council is needed. Knowing that it is quite hard to reach that unanimity in extending our proposal, why do we have to put our children in a very difficult situation? This is my question. However, we have to work with these issues. I fully agree with you: we have to respect same-sex marriages too.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: in writing. — The question submitted to the European Commission, without undermining its legitimacy, can unfortunately have only one answer. The Brussels IIa Regulation on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters and parental custody matters and on child abduction abroad is a regulation applied directly in all Member States. This means that the ruling issued in one country is applied in all countries of the Union. Since not all EU countries have an institution of registered partnership in their legal systems, but also politically, it is not possible to extend the application of this regulation to partnerships. We already have instruments of EU law that deal with the issue of the distribution of the assets of couples who have entered into a partnership, but this is a specific formula for enhanced cooperation that only a part of the Member States have joined. If the EC had compounded on the question, I believe that, unfortunately, the Member States would never have come to an agreement. With family law, unanimity is required. We are already seeing that, with — it would seem — important and supported by all changes, the Council is very slowly working out its position. I am not in favour of encouraging the use of the Facility of Enhanced Cooperation, but perhaps in such cases the EC should think this step not to block cooperation in the field of family law between Member States.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission Declaration on the impact of relocation on workers and regions (2018/2674 (RSP)).

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are gathered here today to talk about the impact of delocalisation on workers and regions. It is clear that our policies are geared towards the creation of jobs in the European regions. The Commission has presented an industrial policy strategy to help our industries to stay, or become, strong on innovation, digitisation and decarbonisation. Some regions benefit from globalisation and demographic change but others are struggling with this industrial transition process. The need to strengthen the abilities of local communities to cope with and adapt to social or economic change was also emphasised in our renewed industrial policy strategy. It is at regional level that the effect of the industrial transformation is greatest. That is why our industrial policy aims at empowering regions to benefit from the opportunities of industrial transition. In a single market, companies are free to establish factories anywhere in the European Union. Freedom of establishment is a basic principle of the Treaty and the Commission cannot interfere in such investment or disinvestment decisions by private companies. When it comes to location, it is also the role of the regions to provide an attractive environment for investment and growth. However, we are, of course, very vigilant if relocation decisions involve public funds. We are aware of the high political sensitivity of the few cases in which public funds are used to move an economic activity to another Member State, causing substantial job losses. That is why in the 2014—2020 period, we have strengthened the rules in the fields where the Commission can act: state aid and the European Union funds. We react immediately whenever we are alerted. The Commission has no power to interfere in companies’ reorganisation plans. Nevertheless, we urge companies to follow good practices on the anticipation and socially responsible management of restructuring. The European Union state aid rules provide safeguards to prevent Member States from using public money to incentivise the relocation of existing jobs from one European Union country to another. In addition, the European Union has several instruments to support workers’ employability in order to mitigate the adverse social consequences of restructuring, for example the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. There is a strict regulatory framework that imposes obligations on companies concerning the provision of information to, and consultation of, workers, in particular with regard to the opening of social dialogue in order to mitigate the consequences of reorganisation. Even more importantly, cohesion policy support from the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund is available in all European Union regions to mitigate its potential negative effects, and in the context of cohesion policy we have included additional safeguards to avoid those funds being used for delocalisation. I can assure you that, in the proposal for the new post—2020 regulations, we will include prevention of the use of funds to support delocalisation. Cohesion policy support can also be used for industrial transition, training and skills development as well as other measures to mitigate negative effects. The Commission has also launched pilot actions in order to work with a selected number of interested regions to master the challenges of industrial transition. One of these regions is the Piedmont region, the home region of Embraco. Other examples are Hauts-de-France and Wallonia. You surely remember the Caterpillar and other similar restructuring cases in these regions. We will support these regions with the aim of accelerating innovation uptake, removing investment barriers and facilitating reskilling and preparing for industrial and societal change.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President! One of the greatest European achievements after World War II was the creation of a single market within the Union based on freedom of movement of workers, goods, services, capital and entrepreneurship. Thus, one of the largest markets in the world was created, within which we build our shared competitive advantage. Member States differ in the level of socio-economic development, which has a translation into the level of remuneration and legal environment. In this situation, we will not avoid cases of de-ocalization in the Union. Of course, delocalizations also carry negative effects, mainly for workers and their families. This is the problem we should address first: it is important that the delegation decision is announced appropriately early and that workers have a chance of new employment. In the European Union, we have funds that serve this: the European Social Fund and the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. What, then, to do to make the delocation less? First and foremost, we should level the level of development in the European Union, which will follow the equation of salaries. We can achieve this through greater integration of the common market, greater exchange of goods and services and sensible investment of European funds. Member States should also create conditions suitable for business operators, a fair and sustainable social policy, a friendly legal environment, predictable and easy procedures, access to financing and development opportunities. Let's also remember that our main competitors are China, Russia or the United States. We must do everything to eliminate delocalization to third countries. Only in this way will we be able to maintain our position in the world economy and thus the high standard of living of our citizens.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, three very quick remarks. In the meantime, I believe that this House should apologise to the workers of the Embraco, because this debate on corporate social responsibility does not arise by chance, but is born from a concrete fact that was the risk of dismissal and closure of a business that was functioning, making profits, whose owners wanted to relocate to another EU country just to make even more useful. While we have been debating in this Parliament, because of the EPP who did not want to arrive at a resolution, for months, the Italian Government fortunately initiated procedures for which these days workers and these female workers are safe. But on the specific topic, you have to add two more fast things. One: we have a Europe that does a lot for industries, but does not have its own industrial policy, and above all fails to give an industrial policy with a social responsibility for companies. Secondly, we must help them, of course, but we must first of all express solidarity, be close and have at heart the future of workers and women workers, not multinationals that only want to make more profits.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President, the fact that a factory plans to move production from Italy to Slovakia is not the cause of the disease, but only the consequence of it. This is a logical result of the fact that producers in Italy have much worse business conditions than in Slovakia. Therefore, the solution is not to blame Slovakia, but to think about Italy's competitiveness, the enormous regulatory burden, the taxes, the stability to which the new government does not contribute every year. And, of course, over public debt, which is the second highest in the European Union. These are the real reasons for the departure of producers from Italy. And one more negative factor has to be called openly, which means that the euro is too strong for Italy and the impossibility to compensate for the shortcomings in competitiveness by devaluing its own currency. Italy is one of the richest countries in Europe, but it has been stepping on the ground for two decades because of eurozone membership and its current unwillingness to do so-called internal devaluation.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, thank you very much, Commissioner, from the ALDE Group we would like to recover some fundamental ideas and not go to a more or less demagogic trade. Let's see, that there is a displacement of businesses within Europe, whether we are European, if we believe in the single market, it is as if there is within a Member State. In my case it is as if one from Asturias goes to Malaga, and in the case of Italy, as if one from Turin, where my grandmother was born, goes to Sicily. Let's be serious. Either we believe in the single market or not. That said, business and workers' mobility is an inalienable right and an absolute instrument for prosperity and cohesion. If we try to stop this, if we try to put internal barriers, my gentlemen, Europe is over. Let it be known. Having said that, the characteristic of European society, of European democracies is that, in this absolutely free dynamic, there are obviously moments of space for workers, for businesses, and so on. Unlike other societies, we believe in cohesion and solidarity, and therefore we do everything we can to protect these workers, to help them at those bad times to get ahead again. That is the European model, not putting internal barriers. That's the record. One last thing I want to say: the allocation of resources must be respected. If not, Europe will not work and will never be competitive. Finally, we talk about Embraco. But Embraco is a model of the benefits of European mobility. We have created quality jobs in a more disadvantaged area, which was Slovakia, without, for the protection of workers, those who were in a more favoured area than Turin have been damaged. Mobility works in Europe. With solidarity. (He agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: question of 'blue card'. — Mr Calvet, I do not know what your origin is or where you worked before, but if you were a worker in the Vigo car sector or in the textile sector in Ordes who have been left out of work because of the relocation of businesses and had to move or go to another Member State with your whole family, perhaps the comment would be different. That is, one cannot cover up with the effects of economic neo-liberalization which also means the displacement of workers. Mobility is very good, but not to destroy jobs, and that is why I also wanted to clarify, from the point of view of an area which is heavily affected by economic globalisation and by the relocation of businesses in services, cars and textiles, this consideration.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: answer from “blue card”. — I worked in the mining sector, but also in the naval sector, and have been to Vigo for a long time because of the problems of the naval sector. Let's see: of course that moving is not easy, although it is the history of mankind, and that we have to help, or recycle, as we did with the naval, by resorting to other attached companies. What you can't do is build Europe by saying 'I want my company, my university, my hospital at the door'. And, therefore, what you need to do is help people when they have no choice but to use mobility, and I have used it many times in my life.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, I must tell you that you have served us an infamous soup to bring all European workers to revolt. The relocations only make the prosperity of large companies, not that of the workers, who live in suffering and misfortune, as long as they suffer it. This is inherent in your European policy, which sanctifies the free movement of capital and free competition in the Treaties. Another logic must emerge, and this would be possible, by moving towards tax harmonisation on capital from above, by harmonizing labour remuneration upwards with a proactive policy of catch-up for workers in Eastern and Southern Europe, by inventing a system for all European employees innovative social security for work and activity, combined with lifelong learning for employees, and, finally, a commercial policy including the fight against social and environmental dumping and enabling the renewal of industry and agriculture, as well as public services.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in a globalised and interconnected world it becomes increasingly easy for large companies to relocate where labour costs are minor. This is done within Europe and outside of it, thanks to agreements and treaties. And me dealing with international trade, I know that well, unfortunately. However, we must not oppose trade, we must be able to manage globalisation, one must support with a citizenship income who loses their job, train them to a new job and invest in those sectors that generate new jobs, obviously in places where people live, and don't force them to do thousands of miles. Our most advanced trading partners have been doing this for some time, and just this helps them make international trade more just and acceptable. Because it is normal for trade to create winners and losers, but it is not normal to abandon the losers to themselves, as you do here in Europe. Above all, however, European countries must be prevented from having tax and economic competition with each other by attracting companies from other States to their own territory. We are already in competition with the rest of the world, we don't need fratricidal war.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this affair of the Embraco gives us the opportunity to put the European Commission in front of its heavy responsibilities, because it has not supervised — contrary to what he tells us in the answers to our questions — to prevent the funds, cohesion funds in particular, being used by multinationals to move work out from the natural seat. The Embraco case is a case of school, and we must respect this great battle that the workers did, not very supported in fact, because there is a history of disinterest of the union forces, at least Italian. I must commend instead the role of the UGL, which has supported so many throughout Italy. It is a shame that in ten years 27 000 Italian companies have had to move with mirage, for multinationals and also for other reasons, to find in Europe — because they moved 90% to Europe — of the most advantageous conditions, perhaps on a tax level. Where was Europe, where did he watch? It's a big fault because there was job theft, job theft! And it's your fault exclusively.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President! The best regulation is lack of regulation. We, on the other hand, and in the European Union, and in the Member States, are moving in the very opposite direction. A new law, new procedures, new rules, new responsibilities are created almost every day. By doing so, we do not create an environment that is friendly to doing business. The effect is that Europe as a continent, the European Union as an organization are losing competitiveness in the world. No longer just towards America, but also towards Asia. Another effect is precisely the subject we mention, thus delocalization. And not only within the borders of the European Union, but also outside the borders of the European Union. It is necessary to fight this, but by the right means. Above all, deregulation, primarily reducing the burden — and financial, and bureaucratic — for entrepreneurs. If we create friendly conditions for investing and then doing business, no one will move either to a neighbouring country in the European Union or outside the European Union. And that's the key we need to use to achieve the right goal — not only for entrepreneurs, but also for citizens, also for employees of these companies. All or almost all of the votes that have fallen here today have been votes in favour of the opposite solutions to those that are needed and necessary.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we must avoid discussing abstractly the mobility of capital and labour, we must start from the concrete data. The Embraco case, which has been remembered not casually several times in the discussion we are having, is one of them. It was not about the displacement of a business in the collective interest, but simply in the interests of the company to the detriment of the workers. For the time being it settled and stabilized, for a series of positive coincidences that occurred. But business mobility in Europe comes from social dumping and tax dumping. You have to correct these criptures, you have to make sure that the tax conditions for businesses are the same everywhere and not that a country can say to a business: “come to me because I will not charge you the taxes owed “. And the same goes for labor, applies to social guarantee and protection that must be given to labor conditions and applies to wages. This is the work we need to do, we have to impose rules that allow everyone to face tomorrow without the anguish of those in a company who suddenly decides to go somewhere else. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question pursuant to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. — I wanted to ask: in view of such a case that we are to standardize everything in the European Union, does it mean that you want to standardize the conditions of doing business at a very high cost, on a very high bureaucracy, at a very high level of responsibilities, or vice versa — on the principle of deregulation, reduction of bureaucracy, reduction of fiscalism, reduced responsibilities, better lawmaking and friendly conditions for entrepreneurship? It's interesting what you have to answer to your own properly thesis.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Answer to a question “blue card”. — I believe it is very important to give uniformity to conditions that are: the rights of people, which must be considered inalienable, whatever the country in the which they work; material conditions, which must be uniform and which must meet their professional capacity and not to market conditions in the short term; environmental conditions, which are fundamental for those who work, but for those living in European countries. I consider them processes of uniformity upwards, then eliminating bureaucracy is not an assumption of low uniformity, indeed there was a willingness to simplify and erase bureaucracy, we would have a system much more productive and competitive in the global market.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Madam Chairman, the freedoms on which the Union is founded have a price. The facilitated movement of companies, capital and workers across Europe leaves serious social consequences in those local communities and countries that lose, while some others prosper because of it. The process is not irreversible, so states can reverse negative trends by implementing reforms and creating a positive investment climate. Unfortunately, politics often avoids reforms. Closing jobs to politicians is reflected negatively and they would be happy to force entrepreneurs to operate unrecklessly on their terms. Luckily that's not possible. Union membership significantly complicates such arbitrariness and forces national politicians to work to attract workers and capital. Some want to prevent this competition by introducing common tax rates and additional regulations, and I believe that it would destroy Europe as we know it and leave weaker developed members in a permanent lag.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I want to reiterate my solidarity with the families of workers and workers who have been in distress and under threat for days of dismissal, and apologise for the delay with which this Parliament faces this debate. It has already been said: the Commission should respond to the fact that Parliament already voted in 2006 a resolution against relocations, should answer that it has not avoided in the Union European forms of social dumping and tax dumping, of failing to defend and build social and wage standards in defence of labour. Look, the Embraco case is just one of the many cases we should discuss. We should discuss a European Union based on neoliberalism, the freedom of movement of capital and companies, but which does not defend the rights of workers and women workers, even the right of workers and women workers can stay in their country. Someone said we will no longer know the EU as it is, if we intervened on this. There, maybe that would be good.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, this debate is primarily triggered by the case of Embraco producing appliance components, which has already been said here, whose management has decided to move production gradually to Slovakia. Production in Italy has not been paid for this company for a long time despite, and I want to stress, financial assistance from both regional and national governments. Therefore, this firm decided to close its factory in Italy and move to Slovakia. First of all, we should recognise that this is a manifestation of the functioning of the European Union's internal market, that is, freedom of establishment, which is a fundamental pillar of European integration. It is natural that if a firm decides to do business where it has better conditions created — and the amount of labor costs is one of these legitimate aspects — such a firm will move its production within the internal market of the European Union to another country. It's her free decision. The decision to move production to another Member State is a strategic and managerial decision of that firm, which the State, and therefore the European institutions, should not in some way interfere more significantly. Undoubtedly, states can offer different incentives to firms to avert their decisions, but the final decision must be up to those firms themselves. These incentives must, of course, be in line with the European Union's competition policy, and I would like to underline that, in fact, the oversight of this policy has a privileged competence. also the Commission. If a firm's decision to relocate production to another Member State of the European Union has a negative impact on employment in the region or on the development of the region as such, it is up to the government, where appropriate regional authorities to implement this assistance under employment policy.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. I am very pleased that the issue of plant closures and relocations of multinational companies has put it on the agenda. Finally, I would like to add, a request from my group to this effect was rejected by the majority of the House in January. So now we are discussing the example of Embraco. We might as well talk about the cases of Coca-Cola, Siemens, Opel, Bombardier, Caterpillar, and whatever they are all called. The principle is basically always the same: often profitable works are closed by multinational companies to increase profits at the expense of the workforce. Employees are put on the streets and the regions are deprived of their livelihood. The main thing is that the cash register rings, and after the multinationals, the deluge. That is why, as the Left, we are calling for a ban on collective redundancies in profitable companies. We also call for companies to repay public funding in the event of plant closures. Both measures should cool down the multinations' desire to make their Reibach at the expense of workers and the future prospects of entire European regions.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are discussing the impact of relocation on European workers and regions, because there is a regulatory framework within the European Union that continues to overly promote economic freedoms, particularly that of establishment and free movement of services and capital, at the expense of the fundamental rights of its citizens. We are here to discuss, thanks to the extraordinary mobilization by workers, trade unions and political forces who have reacted to the closure of the Embraco plant in Riva di Chieri. A closure decided by the Brazilian multinational solely for the purpose of bringing down labor costs. Solutions cannot be purely national, the European Union must promote an ambitious bill on corporate social responsibility, it must set up appropriate instruments to support workers suffering negative consequences from unfortunate decisions. Europe must bring social rights back to the heart of its project, it must be prevented from using European resources to promote relocation. We need to make a clear choice in favour of work in order to give a future for European integration.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Madam President, the main ones affected by relocations are workers and regions who suffer depopulation in the absence of a future. You say that you cannot interfere with companies and yet permanently interfere with workers' working conditions by making recommendations on labour reforms, wages, pensions, etc. If they really want to do something for industry and regional development, what they have to do is to adopt tax measures that prevent unfair competition between States, harmonize working conditions to avoid and curb the undue desire of companies for profits, where work has become exclusively a product more. But, above all, bet on production models, innovation, because the States have precisely budgets in this area, consolidate industry in our regions and, of course, eliminate the industrial imbalances that exist in Europe and which are unfortunately leading us to this failure in the Union European.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we are discussing the effects of business relocations, adverse effects on workers and regions. I should point out that all the cases we have discussed have nothing to do with the transfer of companies because of the natural conditions of production. In practice, relocations are done because there is social dumping, tax dumping and environmental dumping. This is why multinationals are mainly leaving certain regions and regions in certain Member States and going elsewhere. Because there they will find either tax incentives or tax rulings, that is, specific decisions that enable them not to pay taxes. This is reality. At the same time, these companies - usually multinationals - are also using European funds, whether they have received European funds to settle in the first country and then, using these funds, they leave and go to other areas where they receive better tax treatment. Stop dumping of any kind.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Madam President, we are well aware that we are discussing the possibility of relocating a company from one country to another, from one region of Europe to another. I am, however, genuinely surprised that arguments are being invented to defend the view that, together with the company, workers should also take their gear as tools, as machinery, as buildings, and move where the company wants. Workers are people, they're not tools. The ability to move from one state to another, freedom of movement, is a right. It can't be an obligation. And much more, perhaps, and under conditions much worse than the conditions under which he worked in the state he previously worked. I think that MEPs, if they have a duty, are to defend workers.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Madam President, Mr Arias Cañete, taking advantage of the fact that you are here, I would like to tell you that Galician and Galician women know a lot about job relocations. Under these words from the global market, the Commission hides social dumping, unfair competition at work, but also at the tax level, from many multinationals which have no mercy to go where it suits them best. This relocation towards social disprotection is the norm of many companies in the automotive industry — the case of Vigo — telephony, water supply, electricity and gas, or the textile sector, also in the Galician case. And more—I tell you with knowledge of cause — because they have no choice. This relocation is the visible face of economic neoliberalism to which the Commission is so friendly. The problem is not only relocation in effective terms, but also the permanent threat of many multinationals to relocate, often to collect economic aid from the European Commission. Because it is very surprising that there are certain alms, such as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. How curious! You're allowed to relocate first and then pay for it, right? It is therefore very important for the Commission to legislate on the economic, social, territorial and human impact of this relocation.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank all the Members who have participated in this important debate for their different contributions. Reorganisation of companies can always mean that jobs are relocated from one region to another. This is normal in a market economy and the Commission has no competence to interfere with such company decisions, but we do care about the regional impact of such issues, and the European structural funds and state aid should never be used to support delocalisation. At the same time, we will work to continue the process of building economic, social and territorial cohesion in Europe for the benefit of our companies and citizens. This is what we are doing with the work on smart specialisation and industrial policy to strengthen the economic resilience of regions, empower regions to adapt to industrial change and provide the framework so that no region and no citizen is left behind.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate has ended. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: in writing. — Embraco: Torino company at risk closure to relocate to Slovakia. If you experience the meaning of the word relocalize (Transfer of the production process, or some phases thereof, to geographical areas or countries where there are competitive advantages, which consist generally in the lower cost of inputs and especially labour.) we realize that it is precisely the opposite of what we want to implement in our country, through socio-economic policies . Considering also that there is already a sharp disparity in tax treatment between European countries, due to the various socio-economic policies of the individual Member States and that, to exacerbate the situation of inequality, the European community itself grants aid to those same states (in this case Slovakia which received funds of around 20 billion from the EU in 2018) increasing dumping wage, I ask that the European Commission undertake to bind the Member States which receive the funds to aid, to invest them directly in the elimination of these inequalities and not to increase situations of unfair competition, starting from favourable wage and tax conditions. Sorry to see that in the hemicycle was present at the debate only one of the Democratic Party honourable to defend Italian workers.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – It is true that free establishment and the free movement of capital and workers are key pillars of our European Single Market. But where is this leading? In a competitive single market, the best—endowed regions in terms of infrastructure, geographical and natural characteristics, and institutions attract companies which become European champions and thus attract new enterprises. These areas will continue to grow and new companies will be established. When discussing delocalisation of companies we focus too often on its impact on workers, their families and the region of destination. What happens to the region of departure, its social class and industrial fabric? There is an impoverishment in all sectors. In a single currency area, countries and regions have very few tools to change this trend. Ultimately, other workers and enterprises will relocate from these regions and the process continues, increasing the asymmetries across the EU. New redistributive policy tools are needed, such as a European unemployment insurance. Structures that have been established to ensure the competitiveness of countries are too complicated and bureaucratic and should be adapted to globalisation, without abandoning the European social model. In its industrial policy, the Commission should also strengthen the way to provide technical assistance to help local and regional communities to adapt to social, economic and environmental changes.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: . — The next item is the Commission statement on the use of IPA funds in Turkey (2018/2716 (RSP)).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this opportunity to discuss the use of Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA) funds in Turkey following the strategic dialogue on the mid—term review that was held on 20 March in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Over the past years, our relationship with Turkey has faced many challenges, especially with the continued backsliding on the rule of law, democracy and human rights, particularly in the aftermath of the attempted coup in July 2016. The analysis in the Commission’s annual report on Turkey shows that the country continues to move further away from Europe. In the context of the mid—term review of IPA, we have proposed significantly to reduce IPA funding for Turkey on the basis of objective criteria, in particular the country’s lack of progress towards the EU and its low absorption capacity. I thank honourable Members for their support on this. We will reorient our assistance even more towards areas of higher priority – democracy and governance, the empowerment of civil society, the rule of law and fundamental rights. We look forward to the formal endorsement of this proposal by the Member States in the IPA Committee in July. In this current debate, it is important to emphasise that IPA funding remains a valuable instrument for the EU with which to underpin its relations with a breadth of stakeholders in Turkey. Turkey is a key partner and it is in our interest that this partner is stable and democratic. Recent thematic evaluations have also confirmed the relevance of IPA for longer-term reforms, despite important challenges in Turkey. IPA funds aim to improve Turkey’s modernisation and development and to provide support for a wide range of crucial segments of Turkish society and its development. We must use these funds in the most effective way. In its special report on Turkey, the European Court of Auditors concluded that assistance to Turkey is generally well designed and that projects deliver outputs. Nevertheless, it has also been rightly pointed out that there is much room for improvement. We take these issues very seriously and have already acted to address many of the report’s recommendations. We are focusing more on conditionality in our approach. For example, in the area of the judiciary we have halted several projects with the Council of Judges and Prosecutors due to serious concerns about the independence of that body. We have also taken steps to increase the share of funds managed directly by the Commission. Lastly, let me point to the fact that cooperation on home affairs and migration remains a top priority for both the EU and Turkey. This includes support for the development of an integrated border-management framework in line with EU standards and with full respect for fundamental rights and international law. The objective here is to prevent and combat cross—border crime. This involves the provision of effective tools for modern border surveillance systems. Let me reassure you that any equipment delivered for civilian purposes is used only for civilian activities and it is clearly defined and closely monitored. Therefore, concerning the armoured (the word in German is gepanzert) vehicles, some of the excitement seems to stem from the fact that they are referred to in the press as military vehicles, and are sometimes even confused with armed vehicles, which they are absolutely not. The fact is that, for example, any EU officials visiting the Syrian border drive around in armoured vehicles: so the Turkish authorities can do so, and I think this is understandable. This false debate also casually overlooks the fact that some EU Member States actually continue to sell arms to Turkey.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: for the PPE Group. — Madam President, Turkey is our strategic partner, which is why we are troubled by government policy and the development of a situation where thousands of people, journalists, academics are still in prison. Turkey is the biggest recipient of our financial aid. Auditors of the European Court of Auditors note a lack of progress in supported areas such as independent justice, the fight against organised crime or freedom of the press. The main reason is the lack of political will on the part of Turkey. The commission must give a clear signal to President Erdogan that the European Union will not support his dictatorship. We must consistently conform our assistance to respect human rights and the rule of law. We need to direct it into supporting NGOs and media freedom. The European Union must give Turkey the terms of our partnership. Commissioner, you have allies in the European Parliament. We have finally resumed after two years of negotiations with members of the Turkish Parliament and expect that there could be much more intense cooperation after the June elections.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his introduction. I have to say that, looking at the severity of this topic, I do hope in your answers that we will get more specific. I also want to say to the EPP that this is not a debate generally on Turkey. This is a very specific debate on IPA funds that were used, and we are very concerned about what happened to those funds. Keep me in Dutch. Mr President, almost EUR 36 million: that is the amount that the EU contributed in 2011 to the purchase of armored vehicles in Turkey for more effective border surveillance. Let me make it clear that Turkey has sufficient reasons to monitor its external borders properly. We can all imagine it. But when the Cobra II vehicles were delivered in 2011, they were intended to be deployed at the eastern border. The war in Syria had not yet begun, no wall had yet been built on the southern border. In 2018, that situation has changed dramatically. In recent months, several reports have come from both human rights organisations and journalists that dozens of refugees have been shot at — sometimes with death — during an attempt to cross the Turkish border, partly with the use of armored vehicles. (The President interrupted the speaker because of a problem with the interpretation) The contract concluded in 2011 states that armoured vehicles may only be used for surveillance. If Turkey wishes to depart from this, it must seek written permission from the European Commission. Hence the questions to Commissioner Hahn, with the shocking stories of Human Rights Watch, among others: has Turkey asked the Commission for permission to equip the armoured vehicles with heat-sensitive cameras? Has the EU launched its own independent investigation into the findings? I don't hear that. And if not, do you intend to do so immediately? Indeed, the painful conclusion may be that the EU is implicitly co-responsible for very serious human rights violations on the Turkish-Syrian border. The fact that, at the request of my colleague, Mr Schaake and myself, all the political groups in this House have agreed to a debate on this subject shows how seriously we take it in Parliament. This really needs to get to the bottom of it. The resources of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) are intended to support a candidate country to adopt EU standards in a variety of areas. Funding armored vehicles from EU money — even if it does not have military targets — is questionable in itself, but if it also turns out that Cobra II is being used to prevent refugees from crossing a border by brutal force, then all the alarm bells go off me. (The speaker answered a blue card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: question raised by raising the blue card. — I would just like to ask: You were talking about the European People's Party group not mistaking the general political debate, probably in allusion to performance by my colleague Šojdrova. But I think she really talked about the fact that she certainly did not support these activities of Turkey, but she was talking about the situation in Turkey in general. I want to ask you, do you agree that the situation in Turkey is extremely disturbing, in fact, as my colleague Shojdrova referred to it?

name: Kati PIRI
text: blue-card answer. – I think, as rapporteur on Turkey, having drafted a report every year, which your Group supported with a large majority, I think it’s clear that we are concerned about the situation in Turkey. But I just want to make clear that we have here an oral question asking the Commission about investigating its responsibility about how EU-financed money was spent in Turkey. The conclusion could be that actually we are implicitly co—responsible for very serious human rights violations in the country. I just hope that in this debate we don’t turn it into a general debate on Turkey, but we ask the Commission to answer specifically the various serious allegations that are in the media and reported by human rights organisations.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Turkey’s prospects of joining the EU anytime soon now seem all but impossible. Erdogan’s continued drift towards authoritarianism has seen the rule of law, a free media environment and Turkey’s role as a reliable NATO ally undermined. Nevertheless, Turkey remains an important partner, and despite some calls in certain quarters to do away with IPA funding altogether, I believe that this would be a step too far for now. But it must be kept under review, as also is the case with suspending accession negotiations for EU accession – that also must be kept under review, particularly in the way Turkey chooses to treat Cyprus. IPA II allocated about 40% of its budget to Turkey. I hope that IPA III will see a greater share given to the Western Balkans, (The President interrupted the speaker) which are in greater need and are much closer to EU accession. As was highlighted in the recent audit report of IPA funding to Turkey, there are mechanisms, such as the recourse to greater oversight of the distribution of funds, that are currently under-used. So I sincerely hope that such mechanisms will be used in future to avoid any potential alleged misuse of IPA monies by Turkey, because that is a very serious allegation indeed.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, firstly, we are here today to discuss the EU pre-accession funding to Turkey and how it was used. So I am interested to learn from the Commission how much money the EU has, from 2014 until today, provided to Turkey, not just under IPA II, but basically broadly during those years. This would provide important context to the amount of money we spent. Secondly, we requested this debate because it was reported that the Turkish military has used EU-funded Cobra vehicles to shoot at and forcefully push Syrian refugees back across the border. Now, if confirmed, EU funds would have been illegally used and the EU could be indirectly complicit in human rights violations. So has an independent investigation into these allegations been undertaken and, if confirmed, what will be the consequences? Would Turkey only have to pay back the money or would parts of the accession funding to Turkey be suspended as a result? In other words, what kind of accountability mechanisms are there? Because what we know is that the Commission has often been hesitant to use conditionality. It took amendments from us in this House to the 2017 budget to make sure that funds to Turkey were decreased as a direct response to the significant backsliding of the rule of law and democracy. Freezing and redirecting funds should be a proper policy option. What is also clear is that there is a lack of transparency, monitoring and clarity on objectives when we look at funding. No one seems to know exactly how much money is spent, where, why and to what effect. The Court of Auditors – and our colleague mentioned this – drew similar conclusions in its May report and I am actually still waiting for answers to my written questions about this report.  The Commissioner is proposing new plans for EU pre-accession funding on 14 June as part of the broader budget package and of course we are happy in this House to push for making EU spending more transparent, accountable and effective. So we need to learn how funds will be governed and how Parliament can apply its scrutiny. We certainly will not want to see a repetition of the statements on migration and the hastily assembled trust funds over which this scrutiny is lacking.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President! Yesterday we talked about border controls at the internal borders. The context of the discussion was: in order to return to open borders within the EU, we must protect external borders against migrants and potential terrorists. While we Greens do not agree with that conclusion, we all in this House agree that the protection of borders must not be at the expense of human rights. We also have a major problem with the candidate country Turkey being given great financial support from the EU to align it with the EU acquis, and Turkey has also been supported to be able to take care of the immensely many refugees who have taken away from the war in Syria and which the EU wants to stop from reaching Greece. So far everything is okay — that money comes to — but when EU-sponsored military vehicles are used to instead forcibly stop migrants from entering Turkey, and when refugees are even shot while trying to cross the border, it is rather that we in the EU can be accused of having contributed to committing serious human rights violations. The Commission believes that the Turkey agreement has been a happy one; I see that it contributed to human rights violations and that people were shot dead. It is extremely serious and we want answers to our questions.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, it is always a great challenge and temptation, when you talk about Turkey, to broaden the issue. I won't do it. I will dwell on the subject we are discussing, which is pre-accession assistance to Turkey, which is given for very specific objectives, namely to harmonise the country with European issues. Here, however, there is the information that has already been received by some colleagues so far - I think this will continue - that this pre-accession aid is being used by Turkey for the purchase of charians, which then effectively combat the potential of refugees. to enter the country. If the information does not apply that these tanks, which have been bought with European Union money, have been used to murder people, then I think we are also jointly responsible in a situation in which we should not be in any way. The Commissioner has said something different - I have heard - that it is not these tanks, it is something else, but there is also the information that I and colleagues have referred to, and I think you have every right and obligation to clarify what information you have in particular on the allegations that refugees were murdered with European Union money.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Turkey is now the main beneficiary of pre-accession assistance funds, over 9 billion with which we fund part of the facility for refugees, son of the illegitimate agreement signed two years ago. This money would also be served for the purchase of military and armored vehicles, surveillance equipment and ships, used to patrol those 900 kilometres of wall dividing it from Syria: three meters and half of concrete rods to stop thinking about the problem of immigration, violating human rights. It does not end there: according to the European Court of Auditors, funds are ineffective for lack of political will and extremely limited use of conditionality. How much longer will we continue to make a mockery of Turkey, increasingly distant and increasingly authoritarian, where internal crackdowns and human rights abuses know no respite? There must be an investigation from the Commission, a clear and precise response, not the usual deafening and therefore conniving silence. Otherwise we sacrifice not only our values, but also the courage of Turkish civil society. The “business as usual” makes us complicit.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, almost EUR 10 billion in the last two multiannual financial frameworks of European citizens' money has ended up in the pockets of a scheme authoritarian, who makes these funds what he wants. I believe that Europe should give a strong and citizens' protection response to Turkey and the Erdoğan regime. If the European Union imposes sanctions on Russia, imposes sanctions on Syria and proposes to tie the disbursement of some funds to Eastern European countries especially to respect the rule of law, I think then a Deep reasoning and concrete action on IPA funds to Turkey must be done. No longer a euro of the money of European citizens must end up in the pockets of a regime that does not abide by the rules and has not made any progress in its path to Europe.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: — Madam President, according to the European Court of Auditors, the billions of euros of pre-accession financial assistance to Turkey have had limited results. Because of the “Sultan” Erdogan, the funds provided did not satisfy fundamental needs, such as the independence and impartiality of the judiciary, the fight against high-level corruption and organised crime, freedom of the press and prevention of conflicts of interest . The minimum that the Commission owes is to adopt a clause to stop pre-accession aid while Turkey openly violates the principles of democracy and the rule of law. The policy of appeasement and granting paid powers to countries such as Turkey has failed. Peace and security cannot be bought with money. It has not worked in the past and does not work today. The good causes and the gentle power of humanitarian values are not a mound against cruel physical violence, when borders and sovereignty are destroyed and illegal immigrants are promoted as another Trojan horse. A strong and straightforward response with fait accompli and actions is required against any threat and not subjunctive compliance with all kinds of requirements.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, Commissioner, it is proven every day that as long as the European Union continues to tolerate and finance Turkey, Turkey will continue to disengage, cause, multiply problems and leave the European Union exposed as well. Commissioner, Turkey's funding comes solely from the pockets of European taxpayers. Did you ask European citizens whether today they want to give even one euro to finance Turkey? I assure you, if you asked them, the answer will be clear: no funding in Turkey because European citizens firmly believe in the principles and values of the European Union, and these principles and values are violated and are violated every day by Turkey. It is an oxymoron to fund and reward a country that essentially despises, trampling all human rights, provokes and threatens Member States of the European Union. Where is European solidarity in Greece and Cyprus, when they are threatened by the country being financed, when they are threatened by a country which continues to receive funding? You rightly said that Member States of the European Union continue to sell arms to Turkey. The US House decided by a majority to stop arms sale to Turkey because Turkey does not respect principles and values, because it violates rules. The European Union will take such a decision to ban the sale of arms to the Member States of the European Union, when America itself stopped it while the European Union had a thousand reasons to ban Member States from selling arms to Turkey. Commissioner, at last in this sitting, and I shall conclude, you must answer clearly today in this plenary, in the European Parliament. Do we want a country like this to continue to reward and finance it or not?... (The President removed the speaker from the speaker.)

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to recall President Juncker's words: a country's accession process is not a simple matter, it is a decision taken for a whole generation. Dear friends, our attitude towards a country is not a switch to turn it on and off whenever we want. At a time like this, before a critical upcoming election, they don't talk about money. What is important is to ask the Turkish Government for equal and smooth elections. An important Turkish politician said yesterday (the speaker speaks Turkish) or to put it European: “Which way? To Europe. How? With democracy and personal freedoms.” I would like to hear this from all Turkish citizens or politicians and add next to this 'peace and security in our region'. To the Turkish citizens, this 79% claiming the European perspective of their country, we must state clearly that we are not abandoning those who are looking to us for help. The European Union must declare itself present.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Madam President, it is no secret to anyone that Turkey is not a democratic state, on the contrary. It is no secret to anyone that the Turkish president is a dictator, he violates freedom of speech, freedom of expression, of journalism in his own country. It is no secret to anyone that this country interferes inadmissibly in the internal affairs of its neighbouring countries and is a threat to them. It's no secret to anyone that this country finds and buys maintenance anywhere in the world. It is no secret to anyone that here and in this Chamber there are colleagues working for Turkey's cause — an undemocratic, non-European country. Of course Turkey uses the money given to it to buy equipment and crackle all those who disagree with it (i.e. military equipment, we all know it). And it's about time we stopped burying our head in the sand. It is no secret to anyone that this country is not European, it will not be European and cannot be part of the European Union. Therefore, honourable Members, it is high time to put an end to hypocrisy. It is time to stop paying European taxpayers' money for a dictator. It is therefore time for the negotiations to be disrupted and things are said honestly.

name: Nadja HIRSCH
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. As the official candidate country, Turkey is receiving financial support to drive forward political, economic and civil society reforms with at least nine billion euros in the period 2007-2020. The reason for today's debate is the current alleged abuse of EU funds by the Turkish government. We are not concerned here with the purchase of material to secure the external borders, but rather with the inhuman intervention against refugees on the Turkish-Syrian border. We need full information and investigation here so that credibility is not called into question. The case shows another fundamental problem: EU accession aid to candidate countries continues to flow even if the process has de facto been on hold for a long time. This dependency on formal accession status needs to be changed. If a country like Turkey leaves the path of European values, funds must be reduced or cancelled altogether. This is also a question of credibility.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Mr President, I am the fourteenth speaker. At the outset, the Commissioner made a contribution in which he said that this debate was actually based on a misunderstanding. I still wonder why this misunderstanding has not been cleared up when the European Commission is funding Turkey for the purchase of two Cobra vehicles, a kind of light tanks that can also be easily equipped with a missile launcher. By the way, those Cobras were created by a Turkish defense company, so we're funding a Turkish defense company for Turkish light tanks that can be equipped with rocket launchers. Then where's the misunderstanding? Was the misunderstanding in 2011 when we did that, or was it a misunderstanding when the missile launchers were actually set up? If we know that Turkey is shooting refugees at the border and pushing them back to Syria, then I think we have a misunderstanding here. But it's not in those tanks alone.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: — Madam President, the common observation of the competent bodies of the European Union, such as the European Court of Auditors, the Commission and others, is that the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance for Turkey is not delivering the expected results. Instead of progress, there is a serious setback in that country with regard to the independence and impartiality of justice, freedom of the press, political corruption, etc. Many billions of euros of Union aid to Turkey have been wasted over the last decade. The only result is that the Erdogan regime is increasingly deconstructed and that it is now pursuing practices of a terrorist organisation, as was the case in the case of the two Greek soldiers being taken hostage with the aim of exchanging them with Turkish fugitives. The European Union must stop paying financial assistance to Turkey so that the Turkish leaders realise that they cannot mock us with impunity.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: — Madam President, the European Union has decided to pay several billion euros to Turkey over the period 2014-2020 to prepare for accession. Turkey's accession to the Union has been a bad idea since the outset because, historically and culturally, Turkey is not a European state, it is rather a traditional opponent of Europe, which, moreover, continues to occupy part of Cyprus in violation of international law. Since July 2016, President Erdogan has also taken the pretext of an attempted coup d'état to violate press freedom, the right to security and all European values. Finally, the European Court of Auditors revealed in 2018 that Turkey has never used the money paid by the Union to bring its legislation closer to European standards. Under these conditions, continuing to pay money to Turkey makes no sense. I call on the European Union to put an end to Turkey's accession process and stop providing aid for Turkey's pre-accession.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, three months ago I raised with a written question the subject we are debating today. But still, Commissioner, I have not received a reply. The use of European funds to finance the purchase of armoured identification vehicles by the Turkish Government violates both the spirit of the European treaties and common sense. Turkey is a country where human rights are constantly violated. Such vehicles can be used in internal security operations against its citizens. They also serve needs to identify manoeuvre formations in military operations, such as those currently being conducted in Syria. It is incomprehensible that, at a time when Turkey continues to hold two Greek soldiers illegally imprisoned, violates Cyprus's sovereign rights and has illegally invaded Syria, we should fund the purchase of such vehicles. Turkey cannot use pre-accession funds in this way with your tolerance. This has to stop. Otherwise, you will be jointly responsible for Turkish provocativeness. This money should only be used for social purposes.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Turkey has found a cow that it milks. It has found the European Union and receives six billion euros for the refugee, while it is harboring the slave trade and fills Greece with thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants. It utilizes the European Investment Bank's low-interest loans, receiving €2.3 billion for 2016. It makes use of the pre-accession funds and uses these funds for armored vehicles for non-political purposes. From then on, he does all this while threatening Greece, threatens Cyprus, continues until now to have the two Greek military prisoners. Are we going to put up with all this? That is why we are saying: a halt to the accession negotiations here and now, a halt to the payment of European Union funds. Sanctions against the “sultan” and his company. A ban on the sale of arms to Turkey.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Madam President, the IPA funds are investments which contribute to both the accession countries and to the Union. While these funds help our partners to implement political and economic reforms, they also help the EU to reach its objectives regarding a sustainable economic recovery, energy supply, transport, environment and climate change. The modal sector approach of IPA II promotes structural reform that helps to transform a given sector and reach the EU standards. The ECA assessment of the pre-accession assistance to Turkey shows that it has been well designed but encountered difficulties in supporting sector-wide reforms. Assessing the implementation in three priority sectors – the rule of law, governance and human resources – reveals a mixed picture. Despite the difficulties in the implementation of IPA in Turkey, it is indisputable that, without this programme for our partners, it would be more difficult to fulfil EU membership obligations and support the political reforms, economic, social and territorial development. Concerning the use of conditionality related to the implementation of IPA, there is a need to assess what would be the impact of the pre-accession fund if negotiations are suspended. In this case, under IPA2 there are no explicit provisions for suspensions of the funds.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Madam President! The indecision and inertia of the issue of Turkey are particularly remarkable. Either the Commission is pursuing a particularly elaborate strategy here, or it is simply sheer helplessness. Because we are here — and this is going through the whole House — constantly concerned about the situation in Turkey, and we are discussing it for the umpteenth time. The situation in Turkey is also truly untenable, both in terms of democratic and civil rights and freedom of the press. No action is ever done. Empty words are swung here in the house. We have heard this on several occasions: a total of EUR 9 billion is being paid to Turkey as pre-accession aid. And what happens to this money? No control! On the other hand, we would have a good opportunity to fill the gap in the budget that the British leave with these nine billion. The only thing to say is that the request we are making remains: immediate termination of accession negotiations and immediate suspension of the payment of European taxpayers' money to Turkey.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, according to an inquiry in which several newspapers participated, Turkey would have used armoured vehicles financed by the European Union to carry out forced rejections of refugees to Syrian territory. It's very serious. It was not enough is the cynical agreement that blocked 14,000 people in inhuman conditions on the Greek islands, but military instruments are provided that can be used against people. We know that according to the agreement they should only be used to control borders, but, Commissioner, how can you control the real use of these means? Are you willing to interrupt, to suspend these funds? And how can you put us in a position to check how the money of the citizens of Europe is spent? This Parliament is sick of seeing its prerogatives trampled, just as it happened on the agreement in open breach of the treaties.

name: Ana GOMES
text: — Madam President, the 2018 report on Turkey sets out the profound, fundamental problems in the implementation of funds under the pre-accession assistance instrument aimed at building civil society capacity and promoting Turkey's social dialogue. Nothing surprising. None of these objectives is in Erdogan's interest, too busy destroying democracy and the rule of law and violently suppressing the Kurdish minority, the opposition and anyone who dares to stand up to it. The Commission and the Council cannot allow themselves to be blackmailed by what they disgracefully say is Ankara's good work on migratory flows, as emphasized in the report, and they cannot put a stone on Afrin and the crushing of Syrians and Afghans by the Turkish army at the border, allegedly through the use of Cobra II military vehicles funded by the European Union. If this is confirmed, it's a disgrace, it's a disgrace to all of us. The Commission and the Council must respond on these very serious allegations. There are no conditions for continuing Turkey's accession process to the European Union, but the European Union must more than ever continue to support the courageous Turkish civil society. To do so, IPA or other support must protect those who are supported, but it must also be thoroughly scrutinised. Who are European taxpayers' funds going to today?

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I want to express my concerns about Turkey's future and join my colleagues with regard to the serious suspicion of the unforgivable, illegal use of European means.
