I think this thing needs to be investigated thoroughly. Every state, of course, has the right to protect its borders, but it must be done in a way compatible with the protection of human rights. At the same time, I would like to say that I wish for the continuation of the agreements with Turkey, but the other party must also want to fulfil them according to the negotiated terms. I really have very serious concerns about Turkey's future and whether we really do not see the birth of a new authoritarian regime or even dictatorship here, but we are not helping it either. I would very much like to see history ask what the European Union was doing at this very decisive moment for Turkey, so that we don't have to be ashamed.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the subject we are debating today illustrates the overall attitude of Turkey towards the European Union. Money is given to guard the borders and this money is used to murder unarmed and civilians on its borders. Turkey is given money to bring it closer to European principles and values, and at the same time we see it moving further and further away. Money is being given to Turkey in the hope that it will become a democratic country and follow the path of Europe and, on the contrary, we see competition between Mr Erdogan, which is not the only problem, and the opposition along the way of nationalism. Maybe it's time to take another road? The path of sanctions against Turkey in the same way as with Russia? I think the answer should be given immediately.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it should be clear to the Commissioner that this Parliament rejects the idea that pre-accession funds can be continued. If the Commissioner is not enough, the massacres in Afrin, the massacres against the Kurdish people, what happens constantly in the repression of teachers and journalists, what happens, reported by the NGOs, harm of refugees, firstly Syrians, perhaps it could wake up the Commissioner's memory what the Court of Auditors of the European Union said about how Erdoğan uses these funds. I believe that it is a disgrace, a disgrace, the money we give to Erdoğan, now more than 6 billion to block migration flows, that it is a real crime against humanity. And I would add, there has been talk of democratisation: why does the European Parliament not send, why did Erdoğan not invite European Parliament observers to the next elections? I will go to Turkey to observe the elections, but I will go there without the possibility of covering this Parliament. This is democratic Turkey.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that we need to put democratic conditionality in all the agreements with Turkey.  The abuse of power in Turkey is really a scandal. Journalists, teachers, human rights defenders and politicians like the HDP leader, Mr Demirtas, are in jail, as are MPs. I am a member of the parliamentary delegation to Turkey in the European Parliament and we are very worried. The bad use of European money to suppress human rights is a scandal. Trapping millions of refugees to stop them from entering the European Union is terrible. We cannot have this complicity in the possible violation of the international rights of refugees. We cannot pay to kill.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, MEPs from all across the House have expressed their concern at the misuse of funding from IPA funds in Turkey, and that is understandable because funds should be used for proper purposes and especially not for military purposes. However, I would like to ask Commissioner Hahn, in his regard, especially in relation to migration, when Jean-Claude Junker first announced funding here in Parliament we were almost overwhelmed in Europe by the migration crisis. It threatened to bring down Europe. Have things stabilised since? They seem to have and how much is that attributable to funding with Turkey?  I know that we have to be hugely concerned about the disrespect for the rule of law, the lack of freedom of the press, judiciary, etc., in Turkey and I can safely say as a result of that that nobody in this House will be here the day that Turkey walks in here as Members of the European Parliament.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, Commissioner, you can ignore the point of view of European citizens. You will agree with me, however, that neither of us, nor you, can ignore the European treaties, which provide that, in order for a Member State to be in accession, it must meet the well-known Copenhagen criteria, as they have been called. I will read to you just one, the first criterion, which is mentioned in the Treaties: 'for accession negotiations to begin, the country must fulfil the first criteria', 'stability of institutions guaranteeing democracy, the rule of law, human rights and respect for and protection of minorities”. If you believe that today's Turkey fulfils them, tell us, if not, tell us how we are going to get back — not only to end the granting of new funds, but how we are going to get back — those that the Erdogan regime is abusively using against the citizens of Turkey and against the minorities, first and foremost, against the Kurds.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, regarding Turkey’s journey on the European path, it’s important to talk about ongoing Turkish attacks on the Kurds, including recent attacks on the peaceful citizens of Afrin, which have resulted in mass displacement and many deaths. One body that still lies under the rubble is that of Anna Campbell, a young fair—minded British woman who was moved to join the Kurdish Women’s Protection Unit last year. Anna was killed 11 weeks ago whilst helping to evacuate civilians. Her bereaved family are suffering immensely. Meanwhile, the Turkish authorities refuse to give access to Anna’s body, and Theresa May shakes hands with President Erdogan. I visited Kurdistan many times, recently with the Women’s Delegation for Peace in northern Syria. I have met with bereaved Kurdish families, and I know that Turkey frequently refuses to allow them to give the victims a proper burial. I therefore urge the High Representative to take diplomatic action to help Anna’s family and demand an end to the vicious Turkish attacks on peaceful Kurds.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the situation in Turkey is getting worse. The dissolution of the rule of law, the violation of human rights and basic freedoms, the intensification of the Kurds and the gagging of journalists make up the inhumane conditions that prevail. Mr Erdogan, under the pretext of the attempted coup d'état, state terrorism which continues to imprison and torture illegal thousands of people, while Turkey continues to violate international law and owns illegally and by force a Member State of the European Union and, moreover, through pirate offensive actions to challenge the sovereign rights of Cyprus in the Cyprus EEZ. No funds from the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance can therefore be justified. Pre-accession assistance is provided to support the European Union countries in implementing reforms to bring them into line with the European acquis. It is unacceptable to call for any financial support to be given to Turkey when, not only is it not working to implement its contractual obligations, as a candidate country, it is brutally violating the principles and values which the Union proclaims.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. — Madam President, Thank you for the many speeches, which also give me the opportunity to clarify various things. Whether I'm successful with this, I don't know. First of all, these IPA funds. It is a miscalculation or incomplete knowledge to believe that this means that a certain amount is transferred to Turkey, and that is it. No, pre-accession aid is based on programmes, on certain projects that are agreed with us, which are financed and which are not paid until it is settled. Just so that's clear. It is also repeatedly confirmed by the European Court of Auditors and by other supervisory institutions that things are going well here. Just as a basic understanding once. Secondly, I believe I have heard just over 30 speakers who have mostly been critical to rejection of pre-accession aid to Turkey and have said that these pre-accession aid should be stopped. I can tell you that there are currently 26 Member States out of 28 which are in favour of maintaining the status quo — suspend or failing to pursue the negotiations — and to adjust pre-accession aid accordingly. Of the speakers who have spoken today, a single one from Austria, one of the countries — Austria and Denmark are the two — was in favour of ending the accession procedure. All 26 others are for the status quo I just described. As long as this status quo exists, pre-accession aid will also be available. What I did is that, in response to the request of the European Council, I made a proposal to adapt these pre-accession aid to the circumstances. And I can tell you that I have gone much further on this proposal than the budget that this House, together with the European Council for 2018, has adopted for Turkey. This House has agreed a much smaller cut with the Council than I have proposed. And I hope that you will also support my proposal for a reduction from 2018 to 2020. If I may follow your speeches, I can probably assume that. We have also often discussed in this House that Turkey has a significant part of society — and if we take on the result of the constitutional amendment referendum, that is about half of society — that has a different view than Erdoğan and his party. It has always been the view here in the House that this part of society should be supported, not least through appropriate measures by the European Union, for example in the context of pre-accession aid. In this sense, we are also trying — and have already done so — to divert the funds massively into the contribution to the promotion of civil society, and here also in the way that we move from indirect management to direct management, so that the funds are managed directly by our delegation, so that we can directly manage the funds. cooperate with civil societies to ensure that the funds are used properly. Now, perhaps to the actual occasion of this debate, I said in my introductory statement: it has also been the view — again and again — here in the House too — that Turkey should be supported when it comes to protecting external borders in order to stop illegal immigration or simply to limit the borders. control. For this purpose, financial support has been provided for the purchase of armored but unarmed vehicles. In English, this sounds similar, and possibly this has also led to this confusion. We have investigated matters on the basis of the allegations, and I can tell you here today that we have no evidence that equipment we financed was used to shoot at refugees. If you can provide me with evidence on this, I'm very happy. Our research, our checks have not provided any evidence. Of course, I cannot rule out the fact that one of these vehicles was also shot. It can also be shot from a non-armored vehicle. But what I want to capture is: we have been with EU funds do not finance tanks, but armored vehicles, which also provide the protection of civilian personnel in border management, just as used by our staff. I would ask you to take note of this. And I would like to invite you once again: if you have concrete evidence, evidence, I am more than grateful because, like you, I have an interest in clarifying things and once and for all to ensure that things have been used correctly. At this stage, with current knowledge, I can note that there has been no abusive use in this regard. As I said, we now have this status as far as pre-accession aid is concerned. I have proposed to cut them overall by about 40% for the remainder of 2018—2020. A large part goes to civil society projects and also to the completion of certain infrastructure projects, such as a railway link to Bulgaria, for example. That is what I wanted to say, and thank you again for the debate.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, Commissioner. I am sure that if my colleagues have evidence, they will pass it on to you too. The debate is closed.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Linda McAvan and Dubravka Šuica, on behalf of the Committee on Development and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on the implementation of the Joint Working Document (SWD (2015) 0182) on gender equality and gender equality Strengthening the role of women: changing the lives of girls and women through EU external relations (2016-2020) “(2017/2012 (INI)) (A8-0167/2018).

name: Linda McAVAN
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the report that we are debating tonight is an implementation report on the EU’s Gender Action Plan for external relations 2016-2020 – the so-called GAP II report. What we are looking at is whether or not we are delivering on the pledges we signed up to. What we are not debating tonight is whether or not we need gender action in our external relations. We had that debate two years ago and we agreed we needed a much stronger focus in this new programme, not just in development policy like the last Gender Action Plan, but right across our external relations: in trade, in our neighbourhood policy and in our global strategy. That is why I am pleased, Commissioner Hahn, that you are here tonight as well, because it is not just Commissioner Mimica who is involved, it is all our Commissioners, in external action. What did we find when we looked at how we are doing so far? It is, of course, early days. We based our work on year one of the Gender Action Plan, but I think so far, we are seeing some very positive progress. It is never easy to engineer cultural change, and to get gender action taken more seriously, that is what we need. We need to move away from the days when the gender responsibility was given to the youngest, newest member – often female – of our delegations in our partner countries. What we are seeing now is that it is now the clear responsibility of the ambassadors in our delegation, and of senior officials in our services, who are responsible for gender action, and they have to give an annual report to make sure that they can be held to account. So far, 81% of delegations of our embassies have submitted their gender reports, as have 22 Member States, because our Member States have also signed up to this plan. We have seen an increase in the number of projects specifically aimed at women, and we are also seeing that all projects have to have some form of gender screening. We have seen the creation of gender focal points and gender champions in our delegations, but I would like to see further progress inside the Commission’s headquarter services in Brussels as well, to see them focus more actively on this. We have seen some good practice in some embassies in some of our delegations, and we need a platform, a mechanism, to make sure the good practice and the good projects are exchanged. Of course, the real point of the Gender Action Plan is not about collecting data or nominating gender focal points; it is really about making positive changes to the lives of women and girls in our partner countries, many of which are some of the poorest countries on our planet. I saw one of these projects a couple of weeks ago in Uganda, where we met women and girl refugees from South Sudan living in refugee settlements, and they were receiving psychological support because they have been victims of conflict and victims of appalling sexual violence. I have seen the work we are supporting in the Panzi Hospital in eastern Congo, which is run by Dr Denis Mukwege, our Sakharov Laureate. It is also about supporting women’s political voice, like in Kenya, where I met a group of women – local councillors – who were receiving funding and training, funded by the EU. Yes, it is about giving women control of their own fertility, about our sexual and reproductive health rights, and allowing women and girls to make their own choices about what happens to their bodies. I think that women in our partner countries deserve the same access to family planning services as we expect in our own countries, and when I meet the women who are victims of sexual violence, and the girls – often 12, 10, 11 years old – they in particular need our support in this respect. Thank you, and I will come back with further comments later. (Applause)

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Rapporteur. — Madam Chairman, Dear Mr. Hahn, dear colleagues and colleagues, today it is my great honor to present to you the implementation report on the implementation of this Action Plan for Gender Equality 2016-2020. I want to initially thank the co-rapporteur, Mrs. Linda McAvan, for her valuable work and support during the drafting of this report, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs. Dear colleagues and colleagues, we all know that the principle of equality between women and men is one of the fundamental values of the European Union embedded in the Treaties on the Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and we work daily in Parliament to empower the role of women and to achieve equality between women and men. This Action Plan for Gender Equality was created on the basis of Parliament's recommendations focusing on changing the institutional culture of the European Union at the level of seats and delegations in order to achieve systemic change in how the European Union approaches gender issues as well as focusing on Transforming the lives of women and girls through four key areas. In the first year of action plan, a number of positive trends were noted. I welcome the choice of four thematic pillars, in particular ensuring the physical and psychological integrity of girls and women, promoting economic and social rights, empowering women and girls, strengthening their voice and participation, as well as the transformation of the institutional culture of the European External Service action. This report highlights that greater participation in both the public and private sectors is key to advancing women's rights and their economic empowerment in the economic sectors as well as the need for women's involvement and presence in new economic sectors that are important for sustainable development. We also stressed that it is important during the political dialogue to improve women's participation in education, economic activities, employment. In view of the early phase of the implementation of the plan, I support recommendations aimed at further improving it, but I note that it is too early to adopt a full impact assessment or to send criticism to the Commission. Furthermore, I am convinced that the report of the European Parliament should be strictly focused on the practical aspects of its implementation. At the level of the committee, as a co-rapporteur, I decided to invest a minority report or minority opinion, precisely because in my own report I could not support changes of ideological nature that largely go beyond the scope and purpose of this report, as well as unrealistic requirements regarding development European Union cooperation with third countries or excessive budgetary requirements. As a rapporteur from the European People's Party and as a strong advocate for women and girls' rights, I felt a responsibility to invest an alternative resolution which once again welcomes the positive trends of the Action Plan in the first year of implementation, support and make recommendations to the Commission and the Service for external action for further progress and the necessary steps. The text of the Alternative Resolution covers all areas of application as the original text of the report and does not ignore the problems we have in the field, but at the same time does not criticise the Commission only one year after the Action Plan for Gender Equality, putting a burden on EU taxpayers with extensive budgetary requirements, ideological aspects not directly related to the implementation of the action plan. Dear colleagues and colleagues, this report should not be a place for ideological conflicts, this report is a strong message from the European Parliament that the Union can and must, by its external action, influence the transformation of the lives of women and girls every day. I stand at my disposal for further answers to questions during the hearing.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first thank, on behalf of my colleague Neven Mimica, the rapporteurs Ms Linda McAvan and Ms Dubravka Šuica, for their joint work and welcome Parliament’s report on the first year of implementation of the second EU Gender Action Plan in external relations 2016-2020.  Our evaluation of the first Gender Action Plan had been a useful guidance in the preparation of the second plan. Based on lessons learned, we wanted to address all the identified weaknesses, such as limited capacities to tackle gender equality and women’s empowerment issues in external actions, limited high level political support and coordination among the services and on the ground. This learning process will also continue in the implementation of our second Gender Action Plan.  The annual reporting requirement by all external relations services is an important tool in this regard and an opportunity to do things better together and more efficiently. Let me stress here that our second Gender Action Plan, covering not only development but also all external actions more widely, is mandatory for all Commission services working with partner countries, the European External Action Service, as well as EU Member States. The management’s commitment and ownership of the second Gender Action Plan is therefore crucial. This would be facilitated by the requirement that each report has to be endorsed by either the Head of Delegation or the relevant Director and headquarters.  We also need a strong political buy-in from the highest level, including Parliament. This is about understanding that gender is fundamental and a key driver in all sectors when it comes to sustainable development. All our staff must also be more sensitive to this across the board.  We also need adequate funding. The recent midterm review of the external financing instruments has been, as you suggest, a great opportunity to measure the scope of gender-sensitive initiatives in our development cooperation. Following this analysis, EUR 50 million has been reallocated to provide additional funding to this key priority in the period 2018-2020.  Our overall financial support to gender equality is increasing. From the data already available for the 2017 report, around 65% of EU Official Development Assistance (ODA) has been committed in gender-sensitive ways. This covers all sectors, from education and health, to agriculture, transport, justice and employment. This is a visible increase from 2016 when the percentage was 58% of EU ODA.  With regard to data collection and targets, it is now mandatory to measure the impact on gender equality of all EU-funded actions. A big effort has also been made to align the monitoring framework with the 2030 Agenda. The 2016 Gender Action Plan Report provided us with a solid basis for measuring quantitative progress made. The ensuing 2017 report will allow us to go even deeper in the analyses, also from a qualitative perspective.  Overall, gender analyses are increasingly informing our new initiatives. Awareness raising and training of Commission staff have also been promoted.  Finally, let me recall that last September, together with the United Nations, we launched an unprecedented Spotlight Initiative to eliminate violence against women and girls. The Initiative focuses on particular forms of violence against women and girls that are prevalent in specific world regions: femicide in Latin America, trafficking and economic exploitation in Asia, sexual and gender-based violence, including harmful practices, in sub-Saharan Africa, domestic violence in the Pacific and the Caribbean. Despite the large amount the EU has dedicated to this initiative – EUR 500 million – it will not be sufficient to tackle all forms of violence. So we have invited other donors to join forces with us.  With regards to the women, peace and security field, let me just underline that it is highly important when working in conflict prevention and peace building processes to integrate effectively a gender perspective in all operations and missions from the inception phase. This year we have been making an effort to harmonise reporting requirements and leverage as much as possible the coordinating mechanism at the country level.  I hope you will agree that we still have a lot of work ahead of us to deliver and I sincerely hope that together, by using all our voices, policy tools and financing instruments, we can indeed make a lasting difference.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. — Madam President, Commissioner, Nadia Murad received the Sakharov Prize for freedom of conscience in 2016 with his fellow countryman Lamiya Aji Bashar. The Daesh terrorists razed the region they lived in, Sinjar, and carried out a genocide against the Yazidi community. Nadia was taken as a sex slave. Kidnapped, tortured. But he managed to escape, and since then he struggles to achieve justice for his people. I am talking about Nadia because her example illuminates what Europe must do in the field at hand, at that crossroads between development, human rights and gender equality. The Union cannot deal with its own problems alone. We have an obligation to use our influence to defend what sets us apart: our values. If we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Nadia, it was because we have made her cause ours too. But it's not enough to do justice. Our first duty is to prevent the injustices suffered by women around the world. And that is what this report is about, Mrs Šuica, not about ideology. Of course, we must set an example, and to that end it is imperative that all Member States ratify the Istanbul Convention and incorporate its provisions into legislation. But getting involved also means providing funds, because without money all we say will be hollow words. One example of what we need to do is the Spotlight Initiative, by which the Union, together with the United Nations, allocates a specific budget against gender-based violence. And I'd add something else. We need a strong common foreign and defence policy, which will enable us to ensure stability in those regions where women are most vulnerable. The values on which Europe is founded are universal, and our role here is to export them all over the world to prevent what Nadia Murad has suffered from recurring.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President! Commissioner! Dear ladies! I would like to thank both rapporteurs for this report on the implementation of the Gender Equality Action Programme by external policy. In our day-to-day work in Parliament, we talk quite often about the unsettled problems of women in the European Union, the pay gap and the pension gap, the pace of promotions, violence against women. Knowing the problems of citizens of the Union, which occur despite decades of equal legislation and despite the pro-nationality declarations of the great majority of European politicians, the more clearly we see and understand the tragedy of girls and women from developing countries where equality agendas are disregarded or non-existent at all, and women are treated like second-category citizens. Not only their rights, but often their lives are directly threatened. The European Union, being the richest and most equal political organisation, has a responsibility to use all available tools to initiate and support equality policies in third countries as well — and does so through the programmes evaluated today. In my opinion, the prerequisite for their success is the full integration of equality objectives in foreign policy by all its contractors, thus politicians, diplomats, officials, their associates, advisers and consultants. The essence of effective implementation of equality goals is the political will and the actual involvement of all actors of the process at all levels. Otherwise, this change appears and remains only on paper.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Madam President, the change in the institutional culture of the European Union in relation to gender equality and the empowerment of women in its external relations is important, but it is also important that the Commission commit itself to drawing up a future communication on this subject. The report adopted by the Committee on Development and the Women's Committee includes important recommendations for improving the second Gender Action Plan with regard to sexual and reproductive rights as a condition for equality and empowerment of women, the possibility of using abortion for rape victims in conflict situations, the rights of LGBT people and the Global Gag Rule, among others. We must have concrete objectives and activities, linked to a rigorous schedule, as well as a qualitative evaluation of data demonstrating the real impact of the measures implemented in the beneficiary countries. Otherwise, this gender action plan will be a mere tool for internal reporting. Everything we have advocated here reaffirms the European Parliament's position of a decade. That is why I do not understand the presentation of a minority resolution by the PPE, which eliminates many of these recommendations. The PPE accuses the report of being too ideological in the action plan. But isn't conservatism in the plan of action also ideological? Isn't that against equality? Doesn't it become a tool against women's rights? Does it not become another tool against the rights of LGBT people? What is the PPE's position on abortion in case rape? I do not believe that all Members of the PPE Group will see themselves in this position, not least because gender equality, as the rapporteur of the PPE has rightly said, is one of the pillars that underpin this Union. For us, defending equality and the empowerment of women in the world is a matter of justice. Tomorrow, our aim will be to keep the text as approved in committee. I therefore ask colleagues to vote against the minority proposal tabled by the European People's Group.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! More than a year has passed since the second EU Gender Equality Plan was implemented, which does not allow a fair analysis of the effects of its functioning. As the assessment is too early, the report presented is an extremely ideological document that treats on almost every point about reproductive rights, the Istanbul Convention or sexual minorities. My prespeaker talked about introducing reproductive principles as a condition for equality. What are we talking about? About the fact that abortion is supposed to be available at any point? Do you ladies really think that the basic prerequisite for equality is the introduction of accessibility for abortion? Not in this direction and not through the prism of gender ideology together as a Union, we should support gender equality and women's empowerment. Women really need real support, they need to be heard and to be able to act in this way, to support them through education, to change their fate, but certainly not by a systemic change of approach on gender issues.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, promoting equality through the cooperation and diplomatic activities of the European External Action Service is an obligation and the best contribution we can make to ensure that many of the activities we are promoting abroad other paradigms of development. I am also pleased that concrete measures are identified to promote cultural change in European programme managers. But above all, I am pleased that this report is a deep, horizontal and complete commitment to women's management. It is proven that empowered women with equal access to finance and entrepreneurship are able to promote stable, open and fair development much more difficult to achieve in situations of inequality. I therefore stress my agreement with this report and agree that guaranteeing the physical integrity of girls and women, promoting their rights and empowering them as civic, economic, social and political actors are key to transforming the lives of women and girls in the world through the Union's external action. That is a great contribution to making the world a much fairer, less unequal and, ultimately, more humane place. Because there is nothing more inhuman than to despise or, worse, keep 50% of people subjected.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President, the Gender Action Plan is a key tool for ensuring the Union's contribution to strengthening women's rights worldwide. As recognised by the Commission's working paper on gender equality, the Commission and the European External Action Service can and should do more to place the rights of girls and women at the centre of the Union's external actions and thereby improve their lives. In the preliminary report of the document we are discussing, we identified different points of improvement, such as the poor understanding of the concept of gender mainstreaming and the need for specific training on gender perspectives; the fact that priorities related to sexual health and rights and are systematically relegated in terms of funding and programs; the situation of women in conflict zones; lack of qualitative reports or lack of funding. We are pleased to have made these improvements in the final text and I thank the other rapporteurs for making this possible. But I do have to regret that, despite a broad consensus in the FEMM Commission, and despite lengthy negotiations on this report, the European People's Party does not support the resolution — of which, in fact, it should co-author — because, in its view, it contains problematic language in the area of sexual and reproductive rights. I regret to see, once again, that the bodies of women and girls remain an ideological battlefield.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, let me give some information which will help us to know what we are talking about and how much is at stake. At least one in three women have suffered or will suffer physical and sexual violence. Fourteen million women are forced to marry each year. Many are minors. And today there are at least two hundred million women and girls in the world whose genitals have been mutilated. We are half of humanity, and the gender perspective must be integrated and promoted in all, absolutely all the Union's political activities. Otherwise, they're turning their backs on the middle of the world. We therefore welcome the fact that the Gender II Action Plan contains aspects that have been a priority for us for years. For example, promoting sexual and reproductive health and rights is a prerequisite and necessary for gender equality. And this involves providing all the necessary medical help. And I will say it clearly: this includes access to safe abortion, as provided for in international humanitarian law. Gender equality is not an ideology. It's justice. (She agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. — Madam colleague, you are already next in the order calling for us to allow women to have abortions as a solution to rape. Do you actually believe that abortion is the best solution to prevent further rapes? Isn't there another solution to prevent women from being raped? Wouldn't that be a better solution?

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: “blue card” answer. — Yes, of course, that prevention should be dedicated to men who rape and, perhaps, to have controlled ejaculations, right? So if the man can't control himself and he keeps raping women, we'll have to act on that, right?

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this report discusses many aspects that I wholeheartedly support: gender equality; access to education; eradicating discrimination; and the prevention of violence against women. But more importantly, what this report touches on – which I definitely condemn – is the absolutely horrific human rights violations which take place in Libyan detention centres. Women at the hands of Libyan coastal guards are subjected to gang rapes, men are beaten to death, there is no food, no basic amenities, and appalling unimaginable living conditions. These are the same coastal guards that the EU are training. One cannot begin to imagine the fear, terror and despair of these victims. This is despite prior warnings from human rights organisations that warned of the exacerbation of such crimes. The UN human rights chief stated that the EU’s policy of assisting the Libyan coast guard was inhumane and that increasing interventions by the EU have done nothing to reduce the level of abuse suffered by migrants. What checks does the EU have in place to oversee this operation? Has the Commission investigated this, and what are they doing about it? Are they reassessing the collaboration with the Libyan coast guard?

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, this report is a long series of conditions that you make an alpha and omega of the action of the European Union in its external relations. The Union must not be able to conduct its own foreign policy, and even less it can condition its aid or action on the ideological delusions of yours in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. You want to apply in the Union's partner countries the same rules that are gradually destroying our civilisation: quotas, systematic opposition between men and women, empowerment of women for strictly economic purposes, and I do so. But more seriously, you are asking these peoples to change their culture and call for their overpaid re-education — I quote you — “in patriarchal structures, sexism, homophobia, transphobia, gender normativity and again — and that is the best — heteronormativity.” My group will support your minority position, Mrs Šuica, and will even vote against this report. You could have helped women in these countries in a practical way, but the ideological shift that the text underwent when it was drafted makes it inoperative and dangerous.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! I also congratulate the rapporteurs Dubravka Šuica and Linda McAvan on this report — as we see after this discussion the topic is not so easy. As highlighted in the report, ensuring gender equality is particularly important in the context of EU external relations. Institutions, agencies, Union delegations should promote a stronger role for women in developing countries through appropriate social programmes and actions. At the same time, they must maintain an organizational culture that guarantees equal opportunities for female and male workers, thus providing an example to follow. Very significantly, the progress assessment criteria in the Second Gender Equality Action Plan 2016-2020 are clearly linked to the corresponding indicators within the Sustainable Development Goals. This solution allows for the Union's efforts to remain consistent with the 2030 Agenda, including in line with the recommendations of the new European Consensus on Development. Also, the original draft report in a tangible way assessed the progress of the second action plan and, despite some changes in the text that distract attention from the merits of the document, we will certainly follow the progress of the second action plan. For the promotion of gender equality is crucial that sustainable development takes place with the participation and benefit of everyone.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, in all my parliamentary work I speak up for women’s rights and true gender equality. As a member of the delegations to Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo and ACP countries, I know how important this is. Women, girls and LGBTIQ+ people suffer disproportionately because of inequality and if we truly want to stand shoulder to shoulder with our sisters, then we need to be bold and inclusive. As someone who was recently awarded a Master’s in Education and International Development at Newcastle University, with world-class experts teaching me, I know that including an efficient gender perspective in foreign policy is crucial if girls are to succeed.  This report highlights some progress that has been achieved, but underlines many shortcomings that must be addressed. The report calls for greater consideration of the gender dimension in conflict and post-conflict situations. Women, girls and trans people are likely to be the victims of sexual violence as a weapon of war and our policies must address this issue specifically.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Madam President, Commissioner. After I visited the fishing sector in West Africa, I am even more involved in working to ensure that EU sectoral support in the fisheries agreements will also go to women. Women in the fishing sector are very vulnerable. They often have to bring their children with them when they smoke the fish, and throughout the day they inhale a toxic smoke at the fireplaces that gives them major health problems, like damage to lungs and respiratory organs. In order to access raw material, women are forced to sell their bodies as the oceans have been fished out at a very rapid rate and the price of the fish has risen. Today we are debating the role and conditions of women in the external relations of Europe, such as development work and trade, and the report really calls on us to be better at equality. We need to shift culture. We still live in a world where women's lives, experiences and leadership are downprioritized and invisible. Being able to support oneself, getting to decide over your own body — it's a fundamental right.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as rapporteur, together with my colleague Malin Björk, of the report adopted by this Parliament on gender equality in the trade policy of the The European Union, I am absolutely aware and convinced of the importance of what we are discussing today. It is really hard to hear in this House, in 2018, still denying basic human rights, women's human rights, and among them the right to sexual and reproductive health. I believe that there should be no need for the European Parliament to defend women's self-determination yet. Unfortunately this is still necessary, so I don't want to shirk. I defend the self-determination of Italian women who demonstrated forty years after the passage of Law 194, I defend the self-determination of Irish women who won a historic referendum in Ireland a few days ago, and I take advantage of it to congratulate them, the self-determination of the Argentine women who are demonstrating for the legalization of abortion these days, and are with them. Self-determination always.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: — Madam President, I appreciate Mrs Šuica's efforts to put forward an alternative resolution, but I also have reservations about it. The World Health Organization ranks medical abortion among reproductive health services. In other words, every time we talk about reproductive health, we also talk about the termination of pregnancy, which is carried out at the request of a woman. Reproductive health is mentioned by both motions in a resolution. They differ in that the proposal approved in the committee mentions it nine times, while the alternative proposal five times. Both texts also pay great attention to the protection of the rights of LGBTI persons. But the theme of the resolution should be to improve the status of women and girls, regardless of their sexual preference. Both texts contain ideological passages. They go beyond what they should express themselves on. Therefore, I will not be able to support either of them.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, no development strategy will be effective if women and girls do not fully play a central role in society. Whether it is political, economic or social in nature, gender equality, emancipation and self-determination of women are essential to achieving the goals and goals of sustainable development. This parity goes through scopes that are closely related. First, the physical and psychological integrity of women and girls, and hence our strongest condemnation against all forms of gender-based violence. Later, through the promotion of economic and social rights, as well as the increased participation of women and girls in decision-making processes, such as elective equality. Finally, the change in institutional culture, to ensure that the commitments of the European Union are met more effectively. Let us never forget that the principle of equality between women and men is a pivotal value of the European Union. We are also here to defend him.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I think we agree that women's support and protection against violence is an important part of external relations activities. I beg that we respect that we have different opinions on some sub-issues. I agree for the outside service to be active and financially support women's education, ensuring women's rights, their dignity, their health care, their employment, of course with all of this we can only agree. But I see more ideology rather than concrete proposals to help women in the draft report. Societies that do not recognize human rights, where uneducation prevails, there we must fight above all for human rights and safety for all people. Where violence and rape is part of everyday life, lady colleague mentioned it, we can say Sudan, Syria, there support for abortion really isn't the solution. The solution is to fight violence, peace and protect every life. The solution is to change governments that perpetuate themselves with violence, such as the government of Bashar al-Assad.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to stress that no development strategy can be effective without women and girls playing an important role in it, and that the principle of equality between women and men, the fundamental value of the Union, must be fully integrated into all of our political activities. While recalling that women's equality and empowerment are autonomous human rights goals, I would like to emphasize that these are essential to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals, and I would like to emphasize, inter alia, the fifth Sustainable Development Goal, which aims to achieve the gender equality and empower all women and girls worldwide. The report, the content of which I welcome — and I congratulate the two co-rapporteurs — provides an update on several positive developments observed after the first year of operation of the action plan, as well as on gender equality, while highlighting various avenues for improvement. I share the view that the action plan should include a comprehensive agenda to address the main factors and causes of discrimination.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Madam President, importantly, this report recognises what the EU has already achieved to change societies by supporting and involving women. But there is so much more to be done. We are not doing enough to explicitly involve women in peace negotiations, and the gender dimension is frequently sidelined in crisis situations or difficult conflicts. The report also recommends significant actions in relation to sexual and reproductive health and rights, including in conflict situations, specific regions and combating the consequences of the deeply damaging global gag rule. Commissioner, please also take note of the need to empower women in our political work in our neighbourhood countries. The EU is already delivering change through this programme. Delivering the considered recommendation in the full report will deepen that change long into the future.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, indeed, all gender rights start with girls’ and women’s physical and psychological integrity: the right to determine what to do with their bodies, the right to be educated, the right to have sexual and reproductive counselling, and the right to economic and social rights as part of their human rights, and this is highlighted in this report. Yes, it means that gay girls and women’s voices and their participation have to be strengthened, not for them, but by them. We have to listen. There has been a lot of discussion about LGBTI rights. Yes indeed, girls and women can be LGBT and I, and they do have rights as well, and we should respect them.  Last but not least, I am very happy to hear that EEAS has the principal adviser on gender in the field.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, first of all we should congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on this report. We have all made a point today: girls and women are systematically being oppressed and their rights are being trampled across the globe. We cannot be satisfied if half the population is left behind. There has been progress indeed, but in some places, unfortunately, the situation has deteriorated. Something has already been mentioned which we have all experienced and cannot forget: what the girls of the Yezidi community suffered at the hands of ruthless jihadists. Last night, in fact, we talked about the protection of crime victims, including within the European Union, which is why I think that, if we want to act as a model, we cannot accept compromises on the rule of law within the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, gender equality and the empowerment of women can really be supported by the European Union in its external relations. This clearly means that it should send a message to various countries with which it has trade relations, for example Pakistan and Bangladesh. Labour rights are not respected there. There women, even little girls, work. They work in the factories of the multinationals. However, if the European Union wants to send out a signal, it must ban imports into the European Union of products produced there. Secondly, we have fisheries agreements between the European Union and third countries in which there is essentially slavery of women. Why should these countries be rewarded? Development aid to countries that violate women's rights to stop. Practical measures and not much theory. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. — I have a question. What do you think these women and girls working in factories in Bangladesh will do when you prohibit the importation of the goods that they produce? What happens to these factories and what are they going to do next? Let the Lord think for a moment what the Lord says.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: answer to a question with a blue card. — Dear colleague, what are you saying? That we must allow human rights to be violated, accept that there should be child labour in Bangladesh in the name, supposedly, of receiving a 'dry', of receiving hunger wages. This perception is unacceptable. We must not accept a violation of labour rights and child labour. That's view vertical. So do you want child labour in his name, supposedly, these children to get a “dry piece” to live?

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Madam President, I congratulate the rapporteurs on this important report which empowers or will seek to empower women in the European Union's external relations. How can we be impassible to feminicide, to women raped, to human rights defenders in areas of conflict killed and displaced, to women forced to marry, to women without financial resources or girls who cannot go to school? There is no ideology when it comes to human life and when it comes to women's lives. I tell about the case recently lived in Colombia. On the occasion of a delegation from this Parliament's visit to the Colombian elections, we had the opportunity to visit a project financed by the European Parliament, a pilot project in the Popayán area in Cauca. Women coffee makers who would never have access to creating projects and who were financed with these support. But above all, they gave them the possibility to empower themselves, as they said. That follow-up we did by that group of MEPs gave us the reason that investing in gender is a value and is also an investment for human rights.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very pleased to see the genuine commitment, joint contributions and collaboration in the implementation of our second gender action plan. So far, good progress has been made, but we cannot forget that changing social norms and gender power relations require long-term efforts and continuous high-level engagement. A lot of work still lies ahead of us, and the results of all our efforts will only be fully visible at a later stage. Finally, let me recall that in less than a week we will have the European Development Days under the main topic of ‘Women and Girls at the Forefront of Sustainable Development: protect, empower, invest’, and I hope many of you will be there, because putting women, girls and gender equality at the forefront of sustainable development is key for ensuring a brighter, more inclusive and more prosperous future, and we fully count on your support.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner Hahn said this is the beginning of the process. Indeed it is, and we suggested that this Parliament comes back to this in about two years’ time and looks again. Of course it’s not just the Commission that should be doing things – we should do things as well. When we go on missions, for example, we should ask the Commission for their gender analysis of the country, and we should be asking questions as well, and also in our work, taking this very seriously and showing our partners that we take it seriously. It’s getting late, colleagues. I just want to thank everybody, thank Ms Šuica in particular for her work on this. I know there are some difficult issues where we disagree. When we have disagreed we have done so in a good spirit. I know there are some areas where some colleagues disagree on bits of this report. But please don’t use that as an excuse to reject it tomorrow. It’s got some very important elements in this report, and I hope that as many colleagues as possible will support it in the vote.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Rapporteur. — Madam Chairman, I want to thank everyone who participated in the drafting of this report and this discussion tonight. I understand that there are some differences between us, however, given that it is only one year of evaluation of this action plan, I feel that we should not have been too critical because I believe from this presentation by Mr Hahn that the Commission is making maximum efforts. We are all aware that these are long-term processes and that it is not easy to change habits. I regret that some ideological themes should have become dominant in this report and that is why we are getting rid of, not from the report but from these ideological issues — we don't think that's where they are, but in any case we accept most of this resolution and therefore we have expressed all of its points in alternative resolution. I hope that tomorrow you will think about it a little, that you will accept it because in any case we should continue with this effort, we should continue to work on gender equality and I am sure that by our work here in Parliament, our missions, we will strengthen the lives of girls and women in third countries and that the external action of the European Commission will certainly improve the status of women and girls in the four pillars which we mention in this report. In any case, I hope our thoughts are positive, and those small differences we will surely, hopefully, overcome in the future.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 31 May 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. — I have made it clear before in plenary on this: it is time for all of us here in the European Parliament to put an end to the declarations, stop talking and take immediate action. The role that the EU can play in gender equality can and must be a crucial role. Equality between men and women is one of the basic principles and values on which the European construction was founded. It must therefore be implemented and integrated into all EU activities and policies. We therefore call on the European Commission to propose targeted actions. In conclusion, I would like to repeat my undivided respect, appreciation and admiration to every woman, worker, mother, fighter.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: in writing. — (NL) Recently, the story of the Kenyan Nice Leng'ete went viral in the media. She managed to end the ritual of female circumcision in the Masai community in Kenya and Tanzania. However, these and other women's practices are still widely present in the world. Much remains to be done in the European Union on gender equality, such as closing the pay gap. Nonetheless, we are not doing bad worldwide in terms of equality between men and women. Instead of reclining, we should not forget the rights of women and girls in other continents. Violence against women must stop. They should not be married off as a child to an unelected man. They must be given the opportunity to occupy the same positions as men. Only then will they be able to develop and exploit their talents. That is why it is very important that we continue to actively promote women's rights both inside and outside the Union.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: in writing. — Mr President, the GAP II Action Plan for Gender Equality covers the important three pillars — the promotion of physical and psychological integrity of girls and women, the promotion of economic and social rights, the promotion of empowerment — and in addition, a horizontal pillar to change the institutional culture of the Commission's services and the EEAS in order to take better and more fully into account the improvement of the role of women in their activities. It is essential that the EEAS strives consistently to promote these aspects of its everyday activities. Improving consumption opportunities for women and girls and participation in the labour market is key to improving their health and financial position. Women's participation in economic activities is important for sustainable economic growth. The EU should actively seek to develop tools to improve the status of women in third countries. Trade treaty negotiations are one such important tool. The subject must be displayed in political dialogue in order to find country-specific ways to increase the participation of women and girls in education, employment, business and other economic activities. SMEs and women entrepreneurs should be supported more, including through micro-loans. The EU External Action Service plays a key role in this and uniform policies are necessary.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item is the debate on the report (A8-0162/2018) by Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the implementation of the EU Strategy for Youth (2017/2259 (INI)).

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, young people account for around 17% of the Union's population. One in three is at risk of falling into poverty or social exclusion. More than 11 per cent, aged 15 to 24, are not in education, in employment or in training. The unemployment rate remains on average above 15 per cent and in some countries, such as ours, exceeds 30 per cent. And for the first time since World War II there is a real risk that today's young people will live worse than their parents. And I refuse to accept that this has to be the case. Last week the OECD published a report warning of the growing frustration of young Europeans and that this resulted in a rejection of institutions, which we are already seeing in several countries. Too many university students do not find employment or who chain one precarious job after another, without a clear future. Austerity measures taken in the context of the crisis have had a negative impact on citizens in general, but above all on the youngest, who have been the most affected by cuts in education, culture and social services. Europe cannot afford to disconnect its young people or their social exclusion. Nor, of course, waste your talent. We cannot overlook the potential and creativity of 90 million young Europeans. We cannot afford such a prepared generation not to participate actively in social and political life. It is imperative that young people feel listened and committed to strengthening the European project. It is essential that they have spaces for participation. This is one of the main demands of European youth, and therefore it is so in my report. I wanted to positively highlight European cooperation in the field of youth, the implementation of the structured dialogue to ensure youth participation, the method of open coordination and, of course, some of the proposals and political initiatives such as the 'Investing in European Youth' initiative, the new European Solidarity Corps and the Youth Employment Initiative. However, much remains to be done. And, for example, we need clearer links between the implementation of youth policy and all European programmes; an improved framework for transparency and monitoring of youth policies; a central coordination involving all relevant actors in different sectors; a strategy with better tools for youth policy. communication and participation and, of course, increased financial support from all programs. And, to achieve this, we have established four key recommendations in this report. The first is to give young people a voice, make it easier for them to participate in decision-making and policy development, so that their needs and ambitions are reflected and we also take into account the diversity that exists in European youth; we must explore alternative forms of participation both individually and collectively. The second recommendation is to reduce inequalities, ensure sustainable inclusion in the labour market and ensure a dignified and autonomous life for young people; further work must be made to ensure that job offers are of quality and consistent with their training. The third recommendation is that we need to pay attention to all key areas to ensure a sustainable future, from modernizing education to paying special attention to the mental health of young people. And finally, of course, a financial commitment; we cannot increase participation in programmes such as Erasmus or strengthen the European Youth Guarantee if we do not put the necessary funds; we cannot finance some programmes if we have to cut others; and of course, we cannot accept a cut in the European Social Fund, which is key to the acquisition of new skills for unemployed persons and, above all, in the fight against social exclusion. Commissioner, this gloomy future that I was talking about at first is not inevitable. Everyone here has a responsibility to change things. I hope that the new European youth strategy will contribute to building a better future for them. If we accept that our youth has to be one of our priorities, let us put every means at our disposal to ensure that this generation does not live worse than the previous ones. It's just a matter of will.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I am happy to be here today to discuss your report on the European Union Youth Strategy. Only last week, the Commission adopted its proposal for a renewed youth strategy, and you will be pleased to see that the key elements of the Commission’s proposal correspond closely to the recommendations made in your report. Let me first of all thank Ms Gardiazabal Rubial and the other Members of the Committee on Culture and Education, but also the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. We are grateful for your hard work on the report and your constructive recommendations. To prepare our proposal for the new Youth Strategy, the Commission spent a full year listening to young people to better understand their views on Europe. We held stakeholder consultations and carried out an in-depth evaluation of the current strategy. We also engaged in an open dialogue with you to make sure we could take your ideas into account. The Commission proposal is therefore solidly based on stakeholder opinions and evidence. The Commission proposes three main areas of action for our future cooperation in the field of youth. They are captured by the words ‘engage’, ‘connect’ and ‘empower’. First, ‘engage’ is about fostering young people’s participation in civic and democratic life. The biggest priority for me will be to reform the dialogue with young people. We want to make sure we make it more open and inclusive, less formal and rigid. The current format has achieved positive results. Since 2010, we have reached over 250 000 young people. But we agree with you that we need to reach out to a broader range of young people, including at the local level, and that we have to focus more on those young people with fewer opportunities. Young people who are struggling with disadvantages tend to be less active citizens and to have less trust in institutions. Let us try to change that. Second, the word ‘connect’ underlines our intention to bring together young people across the European Union and beyond. The Commission wants to foster volunteering, learning mobility, solidarity and intercultural understanding. For example, we want to build a policy framework for volunteering and solidarity activities, which will underpin the activities funded through the European Solidarity Corps. The Commission also agrees with you on the need to clarify and reinforce the link between European Union youth policy and the related European Union spending programmes. Indeed, we are proud that the Commission proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework places a strong focus on youth – the Commission is proposing to more than double the budget of Erasmus and the European Solidarity Corps. This is a clear sign. We are committed to investing in youth. We must be ambitious in this area: our young people deserve nothing less. We count on you to defend our proposals in the tough negotiations ahead. Third, the word ‘empower’ is about supporting young people through a youth work agenda. The focus is on quality, innovation, digitalisation and recognition of youth work and non-formal learning. We must ensure that the youth sector is ready to fulfil its potential in times of change. But this is not all. We want to ensure that young people are heard when decisions are taken across policy areas. We have taken on board your recommendation to better coordinate the different youth-related initiatives in order to make our youth activities more visible and improve their outreach. The Commission is therefore proposing to create the position of an EU Youth Coordinator inside the European Commission. This person will be a contact and reference point for young people across the continent. This unique position will be an important signal of the importance we attach to the young generation and help us enhance coordination and coherence. We also want to be much more transparent about what the European Union does for young people. To this end, we propose to track how much funding from the European Union budget is devoted to youth, looking at a wide range of programmes. Finally, we also want to introduce more flexibility. That is why the Commission proposal suggests that Member States set ‘national action plans’, translating European Union-level youth priorities into their own plans. Young people face quite different challenges in each Member State. National action plans can be most helpful in fitting specific national contexts. These are just some highlights of the Commission proposal for the new Youth Strategy. I am now looking forward to hearing your views and to discussing how we can best make this Strategy a reality as of 2019. Let us work together to make it as effective as possible, because we owe it to our young people.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — One of the most common cliches when talking about youth is that the future belongs to young people. This cliché is much wiser than it seems because it contains the hidden truth that the present does not seem to belong to young people, and indeed it is. Much of the decisions that are made in the present decide the future of young people, but they cannot be involved in making these decisions. I believe that one of the main merits of this report is that it listened to the maximum extent and reflected the maximum amount of voices of young people, their organisations in the European Union. And I think we need to be honest with these young people and openly tell them, “A lot of the key policies that affect your future, which are essentially youth policies related to education, the reforms needed for new forms of training, everything related to successful social integration , countering youth unemployment, actually depend on your national governments. We, at the level of the European institutions, summarize the experience, give best practices, raise the bar, set high standards. Don't let your governments ignore these standards, don't let them casually go under the bar. ' And God forbid that as many European governments as possible exceed those standards.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that today we can say one thing: that today the new generations can be Europe's greatest allies, because young Europeans are not eurosceptic but “euroimpatient”, and they are right. They ask for more opportunities, more social dialogue, more opportunities to participate in political decisions and more willingness to participate. But we also know that inequality has grown, poverty among young people has grown, and difficulties in accessing work have also grown. I think that having included in our report, for which I thank Mrs Eider very much, for having given the input that has been partly transposed, I recognise that, in the new strategy, is the meaning of this. our action, that is to consider young people more central in the social pillar, more central in the opportunities that will be offered in the various policies in a cross-party way, to have a coordination contact on policies for young people, and also provide national plans to verify their progress. But I think there is also more we can offer: the sense of a greater participation, even in solidarity, such as that offered by the body of solidarity, and I also thank you for inserting the e-card for the students accompanying the experience of Erasmus... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for all his efforts in the preparation of this report. Young people in Europe face numerous challenges in the fields of education, the labour market and more. Their status has recently come under pressure with new developments in the EU, such as the ongoing Brexit negotiations, discussions on the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and the future generation of Erasmus+, for example. As a liberal, I strongly support encouraging young people to take an active role in public life. The structured dialogue between youth organisations and institutions in the EU and at national level needs to be continued and reinforced. It is very important to focus on improvement of the status of young people. In addition, we have to improve the quality of offers under the Youth Guarantee scheme, defining standards and improving the Member States’ monitoring, reporting and performing systems, to ensure that the funds from the European Youth Employment Initiative are being used as a supplement to national funds and not as a replacement for them. Lastly, the Member States must continue their efforts on national implementation and validation of the system and provide adequate funding for youth to acquire skills, including through non-formal education and training. We need to step up our efforts and make the necessary changes in the labour world in order not only to facilitate young people’s transition from education to internship and employment, but also to welcome innovation on the labour market.

name: Miroslavs MITROFANOVS
text: On behalf of the Verts/ALE group. — Mrs. President, dear colleagues! This time I will speak in Latvian and express my opinion more than the opinion of the faction. Tomorrow we will vote on a report on the implementation of the European Union's Youth Strategy, and on 1 June the International Day for the Protection of Children will be marked. Maybe it's a coincidence, but maybe not, but on June 2 a mass march will take place in Riga, which is dedicated to the International Day of Protection of Children. I will also participate. We intend to express our protest against the decision of the ruling parties of Latvia to prevent children from learning lessons in secondary schools in their native language. Access and quality of education are crucial prerequisites for a successful youth strategy in the EU. The report on the implementation of the European Union Youth Strategy states that the socio-economic crisis, which has been ongoing in Europe since 2008, is most affected by disadvantaged groups such as ethnic minorities facing barriers to entry and access to the labour market culture, social services and education. The new report is also based on the principles of the resolution of 19 January 2016 on the role of culture in dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the fundamental values of the European Union. I can say with certainty that by destroying the minority education system, the ruling parties of Latvia act against the spirit of the European Union. Thank you for your attention!

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, in ainneoin go bhfuil Rialtas na hÉireann ag rá linn go bhfuil cúrsaí ag dul i bhfeabhas, tá ráta ár n-aos óg atá dífhostaithe, gan traenáil nó oideachas, ag 20 %.  Geall le dúbailt na bhfigiúirí roimh an gcúlú eacnamaíochta. Bheadh sé seo fiú níos measa mura mbeadh an méid sin imirce agus clár gníomhachtaithe fostaíochta san áireamh, gan trácht ar phoist ar phá íseal gan aon gheallúint ar phoist bhuana.  Is mór an náire é go bhfuil Éire ar cheann de na tíortha is measa i dtaobh úsáid a bhaint as an YEI. Is deacair a chreidiúint nach bhfuil ach €8 milliún as €136 mhilliún tarraingthe síos ag an Rialtas, agus níor úsáid siad an t-airgead ar fad a bhí ar fáil dóibh leis na ceithre bliana deireanacha anuas. Tá sé seo scannalach nuair atá an oiread sin dár n-aos óg ag streachailt chun maireachtaint ó thaobh costais oideachais agus costais chíosa, agus fiú costais phrintíseachta, agus dóibh siúd nach bhfuil ábalta deontas oideachais a fháil. Níl tuismitheoirí ábalta na costais ollmhóra seo a iompar. Bhí agus tá seans ag an Rialtas éileamh ar an YEI, níl aon leithscéal acu, ní raibh leithscéal acu le ceithre bliana anuas agus táim ag glaoch anois ar an Rialtas geallúint a thabhairt chun todhchaí dhearfach a chruthú dár ndaoine óga agus stop a chur leis an tseafóid. Tá sé náireach.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, 854,000 young adults and 1.5 million poor minors in France and so many others in Europe, toddled with precarious jobs in makeshift housing and deprived of any hope of social advancement... To this situation, a foreseeable consequence of which is the collapse of birth rates, Europe has responded only with worse -go, jobs helped to volunteer without tomorrow. Still, they are diverted to the benefit of migrants, in defiance of the hostility of public opinion. Even a successful programme such as Erasmus+, which, however, is struggling to ensure equitable access to Europeans, is thus disregarded. “We must have greater charity for those who are united to us by blood,” said St.Thomas Aquinas, and, I would add, “through the love of the homeland.” May these words remind us that at a time when an entire generation is in danger of undergoing a downgrading unprecedented in recent history, the priority given to its people is a Christian, patriotic and moral duty.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the European Union of millions of poor, socially excluded young people who are growing, as it admits, is accelerating its attack with the European Pillar of allegedly social rights and reactionary youth programmes. The aim is the voluntary, participatory integration into the barbarism imposed on it by social dialogue, the poison of business and Euro-Mediterranean conscience. Cheap flexible work for life, opportunities, not a job with rights. Sharing unemployment, forced transition of old workers to part-time work as trainers for young people, as the report says. Instead of education, pseudo-training, informal apprenticeship of ephemeral skills designed by the industrialists themselves for their needs, as demanded yesterday by their association in Greece, and mobility-wandering, alternating unemployment, training with little work, alternating, businesses, occupations and country. That is an uprooted immigrant, not a cosmopolitan European, as you say. Young people in the world of the European Union market and exploitation will not find a way out for permanent work with rights and modern education for their needs, except in their organized struggle to overthrow them.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I am fortunate enough to address policies that are related to youth. Young people are very critical but also honest and I love listening to them very much. We're making a policy here that we should be doing just in consultation with young people. I know that they have been very pleased by the proposal of a multiannual financial framework for the next period, namely the doubling of Erasmus+. I think that's what we really made young people big. And I hope that we can also approve a good framework for the European Solidarity Corps, which should, above all, be a tool for volunteering. They also expect that we will improve the implementation of safeguards for the young in the Member States, we should not confuse a tool such as the European Solidarity Corps and the guarantees for the young. Unfortunately that message we will approve contains things I cannot agree with. I don't know how the youth strategy is related to introducing sex education. I don't think it belongs there.
