Nor should we demand that the European Union vouch for the social standard of every child, that is the guarantee for the child. This is what we are to demand from the Member States, Member States should push for free education, quality health care, but it cannot be done by the European Union.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Madam President, Mr Cañete, I would like to present to you tonight a different point of view. We constantly hear that young people are the future of Europe, that we need to invest in them, that they are a priority of the European Union. However, I fear that these beautiful fairy tales have virtually no real coverage. The reality is radically different. Youth unemployment continues to be very high, and a large number of young people accept jobs that are below the level of their qualifications, only to make ends meet. They continue to be the first victims of the economic crisis. At the same time, the European Union, which claims that young people are a priority, offers programmes targeted at young people such as Erasmus+, which, however, are available only to young people who have the appropriate financial capabilities. My question is what do we do for these young people who dream of going on Erasmus+ student exchanges but cannot afford for the simple reason that scholarships are small and their parents cannot bear such a financial burden. We constantly boast that Erasmus+ is the European Union's most successful programme, but unfortunately it remains inaccessible to many young Europeans. Here, again, we are talking about double standards, not equal opportunities. In the same line of thoughts, the assessment of the current European Youth Strategy shows that the European Union is making policies for young people without the involvement of young people themselves. Mr Cañete, you said that in the last year this European strategy has been drawn up with the participation of young people, but they say that 56% of them is not taken into account at all. I believe that in order to have a well-functioning and democratic Union, young people need to take part and their policies and their voice should be heard. Instead of encouraging their active participation, however — what happened with the European Youth Forum in Bulgaria was that these young Europeans were made to clap on command. That is why in Bulgaria the young people are apathetic to politics.

name: Karima DELLI
text: — Madam President, this is a serious time for our European youth. The numbers are eloquent. The unemployment rate among 18-24 years of age has risen from 15 to 19% since 2008. Dropping out of school rose by two points. One in three young people is threatened with poverty. We are ten years after the crisis. It can be said now, it is an entire generation that has been sacrificed to the dogma of austerity. In 2008, we were able to save the banks. In 2018, are we going to save European youth? All the indicators are red and the only answer we offer to young people is pessimism, it is mistrust in politics, it is porosity to populism with the consequences we know, not to mention the growing disinterest in our institutions. Remember, only 28% of young people voted in 2014. So, let's finally listen to youth. Youth is not just a word, youth is our future. Shake the Member States and the Commission! Try to understand that our priority is here, in front of us. Our priority is youth, and in any case, we will have to invest in it.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Madam President! I'll try to explain something to you on a simple example. If we establish such a rule that marriage should be concluded right after the first date or at all, are we going to have more marriages or less? I guess even the abilities of the average socialist don't exceed the understanding that we're going to have fewer marriages then. And now please imagine by analogy that if young people are employed on more flexible terms than average in the population, it is precisely because for employers they are untested, less sure, inexperienced and employers do not want such a marriage after the first date. If we infect them with hiring young people flexibly, are we going to have less work for the young or more? We're going to have less work for the young because they're going to be even less competitive with older and experienced people. For some reason, in European states, it is increasingly easy to get a divorce from his wife, and it is increasingly difficult to fire the employee. I think already at the moment in some countries it's easier to get a divorce than to fire an employee.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: — Madam President, the report approached me and I have studied it carefully. When reading it, I came across paragraph 8, in which Parliament, I quote, calls on the Commission to develop effective instruments for coordination between departments and to assign responsibility for applying the youth perspective to the Vice-President of the European Commission. If there are reasons for starting to apply the youth perspective in European policies and instruments, then we should also start applying the so-called family point of view. Watch how European policies affect the family in the European Union. It is a family whose interest should be in the portfolio of one of the Vice-Presidents of the Commission. These are family support measures for which the Union should support Member States in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. Why am I saying that? The youth don't fall from the tree. He grows up in a family, in the family builds his human capital, in the family he accepts the basic values on which our whole society stands.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, this is a very timely debate ahead of this weekend’s European Youth Event or Yo!Fest, when 8 000 young people will take over Parliament, filling it with their ideas, energy and hopes for the future. Indeed, this report recommends concrete measures to strengthen and improve the future EU youth strategy, in particular, the inclusion in the labour market of all young people through equal opportunities and also enabling measures to grant young people the right to live in a healthy environment with access to education and culture, which should be considered fundamental rights.  As a Socialist Member, I welcome the focus on the need to always guarantee that employment, training and learning opportunities respect good working conditions and social rights, in line with the International Labour Organisation (ILO) Decent Work Agenda. Colleagues, young people are not cheap labour.  I also welcome the reiteration that the Commission and Member States must promptly adopt a child guarantee. Twenty-five million children in the EU are in a situation of poverty, which is simply unacceptable. Importantly, the report calls for young people and youth organisations to be involved in policy making. Yo!Fest offers such a model... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, youth has the future. It is a proverb that we know in almost all European countries. But is that proverb still topical today? Youth unemployment is still alarmingly high in many European countries. The number of young people living in poverty or social exclusion has increased. In the United Kingdom, an entire generation has been denied a European future against their will. That is why the debate this evening is so important. That is why I am also pleased that the European Commission has proposed doubling the budget for the Erasmus programme. It is very good that young people are a priority and that we focus on all young people. It is also good that we in this House say that cross-border cooperation and cross-border opportunities are an essential part of youth policy. I myself come from a beautiful border region and I am sure that there are lots of opportunities for young people too; opportunities that are still too often missed. We need to ensure that work and skills are more closely connected, and also dare to look beyond borders. Because where a young unemployed person sometimes struggles to find work in his own country, there are always opportunities on the other side of the border. We need to learn our neighbours again. We need to work even better and closer together in border regions, and we need to ensure that young people have access to information, funding and professional guidance. There is a task for young people themselves, for schools, for traineeships, for local and national authorities, but certainly also for us here in Europe.

name: Ivari PADAR
text: — Dear colleagues! The negative effects of the recession are still tangible for young people and have impacted their labour market and learning opportunities. We all want young people to be independent and ambitious so that there is no debate, just as everything is done for them. But in order for them to stand up for their future and plan their lives, opportunities must be given and that is why youth strategy is extremely important. In such a competitive and economically difficult situation, young people often agree to practice practice after practice and therefore it is easy to take advantage of young people by providing them with work experience, but at the same time unfavorable or even non-existent opportunities of compensation, unrealistic working hours and conditions and so on. This practice does not favor the future of our young people, and apprenticeships must be of high quality, with solid working conditions and benefits. Worrying about the future of young people should not only be a topic at national level, but regional and local authorities must be actively involved in youth policy. It would be particularly welcomed if local authorities were to offer individual support to their young people, depending on their economic and social situation, but also on the preferences they want to address and where to be involved.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! The strategy for the young, which we are talking about today, is to help find young people in a world that is becoming increasingly complicated and unpredictable. One tangible evidence of how this program works, one of those outcomes we are looking for is employment, economic self-reliance, that is, a necessary condition for life and for development. So we keep track of the indicators that help to assess the situation, such as the level of unemployment of young people. I consider an even more important indicator the size of the group so called NEET, that is, those young people who don't work, don't learn, don't train. There are now 6 million of them in Europe, and although that number is slowly declining, it is still far too big. It's crucial to understand this phenomenon. The programmes for young people cost billions of euros and we seem to spend them a bit groped. We have the tools, we have the money, but in order to apply them responsibly, we need to better know the sources of the most serious danger to young people and the future of the passivity of young people. So I call for an in-depth debate about the NEET Group, for research and exchange good practices and to get real progress in this field.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we immediately want a new generational pact that clears the mortgage on the future of young people. Their economic exclusion puts social cohesion at risk: today one in three young people in Europe is at risk of poverty. In recent years, the European Union has launched initiatives to tackle youth unemployment, increase youth participation, promote inclusion, promote volunteering, often clashing with the disinterest of many national governments. There are positive results, but still insufficient, and still too uneven. Then we need a more ambitious and more inclusive strategy, with an adequate budget. Education, culture, health, quality jobs, social protection systems, more accessible services, active citizenship, solidarity: these are our priorities for the new strategy, for the next European programmes and for the next budget. The national authorities must accelerate cooperation under the auspices of the strategy to respond to these challenges, together with young people and their organisations, which is necessary and urgently involved for decision-making processes, at all levels. Without a massive investment on younger generations, Europe will not have a future.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! Following the financial crisis, unemployment results across the European Union were very negative. High unemployment affected not only young people, but also workers with more internship. Today, the labor market situation is much better. Unemployment in some countries is at below five percent and even there is a shortage of hands for work. Unfortunately, this significant improvement is very little for young people. It is worrying that still close to a third of young Europeans are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. Among them, the unemployment rate in some countries is in double digits. Since 2010, the European Union Youth Strategy has been implemented, which is a continuation of previous years. But you can see that we need to raise the efficiency of the actions we take. The moment towards this is appropriate. The current strategy covers the period up to 2018. Additionally, we are at the stage of prioritization within the multiannual financial framework. I am extremely pleased that there is a chance to put more emphasis on young people's problems in the new EU budget and increase funding for programmes such as Erasmus+. I am convinced that the new strategy needs to be put on real and defined goals. Above all, we should focus on education, developing interdisciplinary skills, creating stable jobs for young people, developing entrepreneurship and supporting personal development. The responsibility for young policies is held by the countries of the European Union, so it is important to support national administrations. There is still a lack of actual exchange of good practices, which — in my estimation — is crucial. States should draw on others' experiences and adapt them to national realities.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: — Madam President, the youth strategy cannot be reduced to a mechanism of social assistance ineffective in combating precariousness. It is therefore necessary to demand more results. The first objective of this strategy must be the creation of effective employment for young people. This must be the main focus in combating precariousness. The implementation of key European Union programmes, such as the Youth Employment Initiative, Erasmus programmes or the European Solidarity Corps, must be exponenced by minimising disparities between European regions. We need more oversight against abuse, where we have, for example, traineeships that are covering up employment contracts. We need Europe-wide denunciation mechanisms, with the collaboration of local authorities, to protect the anonymity of young people. More monitoring of the real effects of these programmes is needed. Young people cannot be jumping from internship to stage without ever having an effective entry into the labour market. It is necessary to integrate into this strategy the most experienced workers, who play an important role in training young people in the workplace, in transition to retirement, for effective generational renewal. Commissioner, the targets of this strategy are not in line with a 6% cut in the European Social Fund, as proposed by the Commission. This situation will worsen further in the case of the Member States and the most disadvantaged regions. We must combat this proposal.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: — Mr President, I am very pleased that the Commission has invested first and foremost in consulting young people and learning and training opportunities, which are now being added in Erasmus, and in allowing young people to get to know each other around Europe. What is essential is that young people know Europe as their own home, know European politics as their own politics and feel that this is a place where they can influence their own future and that of the world as a whole. We are definitely on the right track, but further measures are needed.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, one of the key themes through this report is the importance of listening to young people, and that is what I have been doing: holding a series of discussions in recent weeks with young people in my region at the Outward Academy in Worksop, the Leicester Young People’s Council, students at Uppingham School and young people in Buxton in Derbyshire, and I will be publishing a report in the next few weeks on what they have to say about Brexit. Because there is a specific context in the UK for listening to young people, and two early conclusions from my report on what they have said to me is this: on participation and empowerment, young people want to be formally empowered, and I agree with those young people who have told me that the voting age should be 16 and not 18 in the UK. And secondly, young people want to be listened to throughout this Brexit process. So the Commission, the UK Government and the Parliament steering group should find ways to engage young people throughout the next few months.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the European Union is full of armies of poor and unemployed young people. Eurostat figures for February 2018 show youth unemployment in Greece 45%, Spain 35.5% and Italy 32.8%. In contrast, youth unemployment in Germany 6.2% and in the Netherlands 7.2%. At the same time, 1.6 million workers are being sought in Germany, as there are vacancies. What does that prove? That the functioning of the euro area, in essence, leads to a bleed out of the European South and trade surpluses in the hard core. If we really want to have support for young people and job creation, austerity and violent fiscal adjustment must be abandoned. The euro area must change its structure and cease to serve German Europe. Quantitative relaxation must be used to support investment and job creation in the South of Europe and in Greece. Brave increase in youth funds.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: — Madam President, I have read with great interest the report on the implementation of the European Union Youth Strategy. Again, I must commend the willingness of self-criticism from the representatives of the right, who are already willing to admit that young Europeans are becoming the first victims of underinvestment in education, and culture, unemployment and cuts in social services. As a result, most of them fear for their future and feel sacrificed to economic interests. Although the left has been telling them this at a time of crisis, the right accepts it only now and amazes tremendously that there is growing support for extremist groupings. The truth is, even Frankenstein wondered when he created the monster. Anyway, a man goes frost on his back when he reads that almost every third young person aged between eighteen and twenty-four is at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the European Union. The sad balance sheet of the politics of cuts, the sad balance sheet of politics of the right.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I have great faith in young people and actually, I think that young people have great faith in the European Union – contrary to what some people have said tonight. How else can you explain the fact that the majority of young people voted to remain in the European Union in the Brexit vote? The old fogies have taken them out. Also, in my own country, in a recent survey a whopping 97% of young people were in favour of the European Union, because they have enough intelligence to distinguish between populist rhetoric and facts. They see roaming. They see data protection. They see youth employment. They see Erasmus+. They see equality between young women and men, and they see the priority that has been given to young farmers in the next common agricultural policy (CAP). Young people are not fools. There are issues: dropouts, ok; unemployment; social exclusion. But in a rising economy, with the Member States, they can be solved. I see a good future for the youth, and I see a great future for the European Union.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this constructive debate. The European Union Youth Strategy has played a crucial role in coordinating youth-related policies at Union level. But I agree that there is room for improvement. Today’s debate showed that we often share the same vision regarding what needs to be done next. This is very good news, as an important element of the strategy’s success is to ensure everybody is on board. That is why we propose enhancing coordination at all levels, through the establishment of a European Union Youth Coordinator and the design of National Action Plans. But most importantly, we need to promote, facilitate and cherish the active involvement and participation of young people themselves through a more open, inclusive and constructive dialogue. We have to do policy with them, not about them. Commissioner Navracsics, and all of us, are happy to count on your support in taking the next steps.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, in my first speech, I was only given time to explain our report and I was unable to make an assessment of the Commission's strategy: to commit, connect and empower. But I think it goes very much in line with what we have debated today in this House — and what, tomorrow, I hope we will approve in the report — because, in the end, it is in line with the demands of young people, who have been working with, although we always have to improve that work and, above all, the participation of young people in the decision making. I would like to point out one idea which I find very interesting, which is the exhaustive monitoring of expenditure on all EU programmes, because in this way we will be able to know exactly how much money the European Union is investing in youth policies. And on the subject of the youth coordinator within the Commission, I think that is a proposal that we have to explore in the future, but the important thing is that every policy and every decision taken always has that youth perspective. Youth has to be a cross-cutting policy and cannot only reside in a coordinator who is aware that policies have that perspective, but must be something far more transversal. But well, I am glad that the Commission is ready to continue to work. Madam President, in conclusion, I just want to thank all the rapporteurs in the rest of the groups for the work of the rest of the groups, because the truth is that it has been easy to work. All the inputs and amendments have been to build the report and add new ideas to this report. So I think we have a great result and I hope that tomorrow the vote will be broadly positive for this report.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 31 May 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. — This report analyses quite appropriately the effectiveness of the EU Youth Strategy in achieving the objectives set out. Thus, on the one hand, the critical issues are highlighted, such as the inhomogeneity of the results obtained and the lack of systematic communication and reliable information on the implementation of the strategy, and other recommendations are provided to the Commission and the Member States. In particular, it is called for increased efforts to increase the participation of young people at risk of discrimination, to facilitate the active participation of young people also through new instruments technologies, to ensure greater representativeness by youth organizations, to develop and implement functional, media and digital literacy policies, to put in place greater efforts to ensure access to culture and public life for young people most disadvantaged or with disabilities. Finally, as regards Youth Guarantee, thanks to our amendment, it has highlighted how Member States have to provide themselves with effective monitoring systems in order to tackle abuse. It is therefore a report containing good indications that should be implemented promptly to respond to the problems and needs of new generations more effectively.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. — The European Youth Strategy aims to give voice to the ideas and demands of young Europeans, by trying to facilitate better access to the labour market and promoting student mobility through training and volunteering programmes. Paragraph 13 of this report — according to which “[the Union] recognises [...] the importance of youth associationism as a space for growth of the person and the development of the sense of active citizenship”, makes me reflect on the situation of young people in Catalonia, as the fact that associations of students who do not sympathize with the independence are victims of assaults and defamatory campaigns. The Autonomous University of Barcelona even intends to eliminate the youth group of the Societat Civil Catalana association from the directory of associations, thus preventing them from carrying out their activities at the university. This is essentially a political persecution against young people, because of their “public position on certain matters of political current affairs”, as acknowledged by the Office of Catalonia itself. If we hope that young Europeans feel truly represented by the Union, they must be listened to, but also to protect their freedom of association and expression, especially in educational and cultural institutions.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – The EU Youth Strategy was a long—needed document which could clearly define EU priorities and goals for young people in the European Union. The MFF presented by the European Commission at the beginning of May emphasised programmes related to youth engagement as one of the key priorities, such as more funding for the Erasmus programme, which I strongly support. It is the best way to share best educational practice between Member States, and introduce young people to potential new skills. Also, it helps to fight youth unemployment as well as strengthen a common EU culture. The focus on education should be the key priority of EU Youth Strategy, with a special emphasis on the promotion of digital skills. I have already talked about this many times. We need to engage young people to learn about the potential of digital skills through formal as well as non-formal educational programmes such as Coder Dojo. In this way, we will help young people to choose wisely their future career paths that will meet the needs of the EU job market.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — We recognise that the economic crisis has had a negative impact on European citizens, especially on the young population of Europeans, who are the first victims of unemployment and lack of investment in education and culture. This is why most of them fear the future and feel sacrificed for economic interests. The report on the implementation of the EU Youth Strategy states that the Youth Strategy should be improved and strengthened, although the results are positive, but the objectives have not been achieved more closely. Figures show that today in the EU almost 1 in 3 young people aged 18-24 are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. The euro area's youth unemployment rate remains above 20%. Working young people face challenges such as unsafe working conditions in terms of wages, stress and contract duration. Sometimes it is very difficult for them to feel part of society. Whether employed or not, a lack of trust in young people leads to, for example, a refusal to give loans. As a result, frustration increases and young people feel excluded, and this has serious negative effects on living conditions, civil participation, emotional life and youth health. Therefore, the objective of this implementation report is to provide elements for a strong, long-term and well-coordinated strategy in the interests of young Europeans.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. — I emphasise the importance of modernising education to ensure young people have the appropriate knowledge, skills and competence necessary to live in an increasingly rapidly evolving economic and social reality. It is essential to change the learning paradigm to more directed at the learner. Educational institutions should be centers of critical and creative thinking, geared towards the personalization of education in order to enhance its quality and efficiency. In view of the above, and in the wake of the resolution, I emphasise the need for a priority approach and guarantee adequate support for education and training in the new MFF programming period 2021 to 2027. Young people must be able to develop throughout their lives. Therefore, it is extremely important to implement the continuing education strategy and to increase and adapt educational offerings at each level to the needs of individual social groups. The role of non-formal and informal education is very important in this context. We must also remember young migrants: providing them with high quality education is essential for their integration and prevention of discrimination and social exclusion.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. — (PT) High rates of youth unemployment reflect a reality that cannot be disconnected from what EU policies have been that have been promoting job insecurity and deregulation, or divestment in social services and benefits. Policies whose consequences are well expressed in the increase of young people living today in poverty and social exclusion. The responses created under this strategy, although palliative, could have a positive impact that is yet to be achieved. In order for this to be possible, in addition to the necessary reinforcement of funds, competences and scope of programmes, it would be imperative that they reject formulations of a “flexibility” which only reflects the deregulation of working hours and employment links or any logic of creating unpaid traineeships, job in precarious conditions or the replacement of permanent jobs by temporary or traineeships. A youth policy aimed at job creation and social inclusion is inseparable from advocating employment with rights, based on collective employment, rejection of any precarious bond, the guarantee of fair and decent wages and regulated hours. But it is also inseparable from policies that promote public, free, universal and quality services or public investment, which boost the economy and the productive and strategic sectors.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — The economic crisis that hit Europe in 2008 left a lot of consequences behind, especially on young people. After the onset of the crisis, it was necessary to make cuts and begin to implement restrictive monetary policy. The first measures of austerity related precisely to youth policy, i.e. reducing investment in social services, education, unemployment and culture. The results of the study suggest that every third young person in the European Union, aged 18-24, is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. The youth unemployment rate is still higher than it was before the crisis, so in 2016 we had an unemployment rate of 18.7%, while in 2008 the unemployment rate was 15.6%. As young people are one of the top priorities of the European Union, the EU Youth Strategy has been launched. The aim of this initiative is to provide as many opportunities as possible for all young people, to promote social inclusion and solidarity of young people. We can make the Strategy so far more efficient and better coordinated so that young people are the first interlocutors when creating policies, that is, listen to their suggestions and their advice. Young people need perspective and opportunity to tailor career and life based on their qualifications, not to fear whether they will have sufficient retirement. Young people are the EU's priority and that's why I stand firmly behind the EU Youth Strategy.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - The current EU Youth Strategy includes a huge number of proposed initiatives in a wide range of activities which, in view of the rather complex mechanism for setting political priorities, do not provide clear targets, while general objectives remain abstract slogans. It is worth noting that the European Union's youth policy lacks a clearly defined comparative analysis. Therefore, the exchange of good practice is still taking place in informing colleagues on examples of actions that are limited in scope due to specific circumstances in individual countries. Thus, the approach identifying individual areas of activity should be strongly complemented by a complex, comprehensive approach, since the issues related to youth policy formation (education, employment, innovation, volunteering) are closely interconnected, as is constantly evidenced by specific the activities of the political documents and the expert groups dealing with Youth Strategy issues. In order to incorporate all young people into the labour market and provide them with quality jobs, we should strengthen our efforts to give young people equal opportunities to ensure long-term integration into the labour market and long-term work. They should be able to manage changes in their careers based on their qualifications and professional interests. Young Europeans should have better prospects for their future professional careers and pensions.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item is the debate on the report (A8-0165/2018) by Frédérique Ries, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the implementation of the Ecodesign Directive (2009/125/EC) (2017/2087 (INI)).

name: Frédérique RIES
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, Europe has entered a new dynamic, that of the circular economy, the preservation of our raw materials, which have already become so scarce. Ecodesign, which we will talk about tonight, is an essential foundation of this. It is about taking into account all environmental impacts on biodiversity, on water, on soil, on air, on noise and, of course, on the energy consumed during the design of the product. Logical, I would say, since this phase of product manufacturing is responsible for 80% of environmental nuisances and 90% of the costs for producers. In 2005 — I was already rapporteur on the first framework directive on the subject — the objective at that time was limited and aimed solely at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by improving energy efficiency. Today, we can no longer focus solely on this issue of energy efficiency. Europe must change its paradigm and act for better use of resources and product recyclability, an ambition that has been widely shared by the members of the Committee on the Environment, who almost unanimously adopted my report on the implementation of the 2009 directive on 25 April. I would also like to thank all the members of the committee, and especially the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I have had an excellent collaboration: Francesc Gambús for the EPP, Massimo Paolucci for S&D, Nikolay Brekov for ECR, Kateřina Konečná for the GUE/NGL, Margrete Auken for the Greens, Eleonora Evi for the European Union for the Greens EFDD and Sylvie Goddyn for ENF. I would like to point out that this is an assessment of the situation, an implementation report. The ecodesign requirements that apply to a range of energy-consuming products have borne fruit: I am thinking of air heaters, boilers, computers, lamps, televisions and household appliances in the broader sense. The numbers speak for themselves. The eco-design policy, coupled with, it must be said, the legislation on energy labelling, generates savings that are greater than Italy's annual energy consumption, nothing less than 175 million tonnes of oil equivalent. If we bring the analysis back to a level closer to us, that is to say to the consumers we are, this represents a saving of €490 per household per year on energy bills. Several studies by the UK authorities confirm this success, including a study published in 2015, which concluded that every pound sterling invested in ecodesign yields 3.8 times more to the British economy and that, therefore, it is indeed a profitable policy. However, this blue sky that I am drawing here, is still dotted with a few clouds. There are indeed a few flags, including unanimous criticism of persistent delays in the decision-making process. The Commission must therefore remedy this situation, Commissioner, and that is what we say in points 7 to 14 of our report. European manufacturers must be able to rely on clear deadlines for implementing measures. This is important for their strategy and for maintaining fair competition with non-European companies. But on the whole, the reasons for satisfaction are here and lead us, of course, to look further and to want, first, to extend ecodesign measures to energy-related products, which have the greatest potential for saving, such as solar panels, refrigerated containers and hand dryers. Secondly, we intend to rely on other criteria, different, additional criteria to set our requirements. This could be durability for our dishwashers, refrigerators, repairability — we have made a lot of emphasis on this — and the availability of spare parts, for example for televisions and so-called all-in-one printers. Also on this issue of the selection of criteria, we consider it essential that, in its work plan, the Commission find a solution — this has been an essential part of our debates — for mobile phones. I know it's not easy given the lifespan of laptops, on average from 6 months to 2 years depending on whether they simply die, or depending on whether they are out of fashion. Their environmental balance must also be improved. Indeed, I am convinced — I am speaking here as a user — that smartphones should be made with removable components, including the battery, and should be accompanied by clear information on their possibilities for reuse and recycling. There is also a need to improve market surveillance. The Commission considers that between 10 and 25% of the products regulated by the Directive do not comply with the ecodesign requirements. The responsibility for this matter lies with the Member States. At the level of the European Union, the... (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Madam Rapporteur! You have five minutes now and a minute at the end. They split it up like this. And now you've been talking for more than five and a half minutes. If, of course, you want to completely refrain from talking at the end, then you are welcome to continue. Is that so? Do you want to take full advantage of your six minutes now? Please, very!

name: Frédérique RIES
text: rapporteur. — I was at 5'30, Madam, if you give me ten seconds here to finish my sentence, I would have twenty seconds to conclude, it seems to me. So I was saying that the idea of creating a passport for digital products seems to me excellent. It was suggested in the December 2017 Council conclusions on eco-innovation.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, Madam Rapporteur. I note that you processed your last minute here too.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, for more than 10 years now, the Union’s ecodesign policy has proven to be an effective instrument for improving the environmental performance of energy-related products.  One of the success factors of this policy framework is the way we go about establishing the requirements; through a robust and transparent process, with the close involvement of all stakeholders along the way. This has resulted in broad support for ecodesign and energy labelling from Member States, businesses, consumer organisations and environmental NGOs. The Commission is very pleased to see that also in this House there is strong support for a continued, and strengthened, implementation of this policy. Let me outline briefly what the Commission is already doing to improve its implementation. Firstly, as regards the decision-making process we are aware that the development of measures takes time. This time is needed to ensure a robust technical analysis and have a transparent process where stakeholders have many opportunities to comment on our work. Moreover, given the sensitivity of this policy in some quarters, the College has decided to strengthen political oversight. This includes, amongst others, political level scrutiny at different stages of the process and the adoption of measures in packages to underline the added value of this policy in terms of monetary and energy savings.  As regards market surveillance, Member States clearly need to do more to ensure compliance of products with ecodesign and energy labelling requirements. The Commission is assisting national authorities with this task, in particular by funding joint surveillance projects and facilitating exchange of information. The product registration database that we are establishing for energy labelling will also help in this respect. Another important way to strengthen ecodesign implementation is in its contribution to the objectives of the circular economy. In fact, our current ecodesign regulations already tackle reparability, durability and end-of-life aspects of certain products in support of circular economy objectives. But more can be done and your own-initiative report indicates many areas where improvements could be made.  The Commission is keen to explore various possibilities, and in fact the current Ecodesign Working Plan 2016-2019 makes a strong commitment to contribute to the objectives of the circular economy. Issues such as durability, reparability and recyclability will be examined in a more systematic way when proposing new regulations and when reviewing the existing ones. For example, we are investigating whether a reparability score for domestic appliances could be included in energy labels in the future. The core idea is to provide incentives to make products last longer and be easier to upgrade, repair and recycle.  This is not an easy discussion: for example, while a more energy efficient product directly leads to money saved for consumers, a product that is easier to disassemble does not necessarily have such direct benefits. Also, if there are circular economy requirements, it needs to be possible to check them. It is one thing to check how a product performs. It is quite another thing to check how it was produced, for example using recycled materials. The Commission is however convinced that these challenges can be overcome and that, together, we can enhance our existing policy framework to drive our markets towards more sustainable products and a truly low-emission, energy efficient and circular economy.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, ecodesign is a fundamental step towards the new European circular and low-emission economy model. Better regulating the design and manufacturing phase of products is essential. This will facilitate the reuse of products, they will be easier to disassemble, easier to repair and we will be able to better combat programmed obsolescence. In this way we will save damage to the environment and reduce manufacturing costs. The importance of ecodesign has meant that the vast majority of groups in Parliament have agreed on the measures to be taken. We have been aware that, in order to move towards a new way of production and consumption, it is essential to regulate all stages of the life cycle of a product. This report deals with the directive already adopted in 2009 under this title. However, almost ten years after its approval, we can not be completely satisfied with its implementation. We must learn from mistakes and provide stronger and more concrete solutions, which in turn are a powerful instrument against climate change. For this reason, we are convinced that the report presented today represents progress and progress towards the circular economy model, which will enable us to pollute less and create more and better jobs in Europe. I conclude by thanking the rapporteur for the work of the rapporteur and the willingness of the other shadow rapporteurs to work together.

name: Rory PALMER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, can I first of all thank the rapporteur and congratulate her for bringing forward this report. Designing products that are more sustainable, that use less energy, is clearly common sense. Therefore it is difficult to mount an argument against the concept of ecodesign, as I am sure some will try to do because if you look at some headlines on this you would think that this was all needless EU red tape, Brussels bureaucrats trying to tell us what sort of vacuum cleaners we can and can’t buy. Of course, it is not that. It is about helping people make better choices as consumers to buy products, whether they be televisions, whether they be coffee machines, whether they be laptops, that are more energy efficient, that are more sustainable, that been made in a more sustainable way.  It is key therefore that we make sure the most sustainable products on the market are also the most affordable products on the market. This must also be an issue of social justice as well as environmental justice. Key to this is the implementation, of course, and that is where I feel we need to see the balance of ambition with pragmatism. Whilst not directly referenced in this report, let me take the case of lights used in music venues and theatres.  If a specific exemption is removed, we will see energy usage of certain lamps. It would mean an immediate waste of existing equipment if that exemption was removed. Whole lighting rigs would need to be replaced, whole lighting rigs becoming obsolete when they could be used for many years. Data from UK Music shows that 35% of live music venues in the UK have closed in the last 10 years. Those venues face many challenges: business rates going up, rents going up, planning regulations. Any further increasing costs will present a real threat to music venues in the UK and across the EU. So I appeal to the goodwill and willingness of the Commission to work positively to reach a sensible compromise on this specific issue, and a way forward, so we can find a low waste, low energy and more sustainable economy and protect live music and arts venues at the same time, because that would represent good, positive, cooperative policymaking and I know that it would be music to the ears of venues across the UK and other Member States.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! I would like to thank Mrs Ries for her good cooperation on the report. I am pleased that the rapporteur was open to arguments about, among other things, taking into account the specific role of small and medium-sized enterprises, which have less ability to adapt to the new requirements than larger producers. I also thank you for accepting my request that any extension of the scope of the Directive is preceded by an in-depth impact assessment, which should demonstrate the possible benefits of the new product categories being covered by these provisions. The introduction of eco-design requirements is a move in the right direction, and I believe that Parliament should support this initiative as it allows for more efficient use of energy. This translates not only to reducing harmful emissions, but also to increasing energy security. Unfortunately, some of the records proposed in the draft report are not a good option. The ethical aspects are of course relevant, but I think the ecodesign directive is not an appropriate place to address these topics. In turn, the provisions that talk about the responsibility of manufacturers for the entire lifecycle of products are too far-fetched. Therefore, I have proposed an amendment that brings them closer to the findings of the waste package.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all I need to applaud Frédérique Ries, not because she is a member of my Group but because I think we have a very good report in front of us and, of course, I know that all the shadows have contributed.  I think ecodesign proves that it is a useful tool. We definitely see that in terms of the reduction in energy consumption and, of course, it also has a positive impact on fuel imports and in reducing emissions. So the policy delivers. I think that that is clear. Consumers also profit and I think that has also been underlined, even though we hear all the time that this is yet another dictate from Brussels. This also shows that we still have a bit of a problem with the mind-set. We hear that in the political debates, campaigns, and I think we need to reinforce and sharpen up a little bit our communication.  Ecodesign criteria should also, in my opinion, be broadened. So far, ecodesign primarily focuses on energy consumption, but that should not be the only criterion. I would say that we have to focus on our resource efficiency and therefore criteria like recyclability, upgradability, durability, reparability all have to be taken into account.  The scope of ecodesign should be extended. The sole scope of the Ecodesign Directive covers energy and energy-related products, but what about other product groups, for example ICT products, which contain a number of precious elements, or furniture, which definitely creates a large part of our landfill? Composition of products has the same relevance as energy consumption, in my opinion, and therefore ecodesign should be considered as a part of the circular economy, and that has been underlined. A last remark: priority, in my opinion, should be given to those product groups which have the highest potential. So there is work to be done, and I am sure that we will progress on that.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, We need to ensure that products in our market are designed so that we save both energy and raw materials. Products need to become more reusable, repaired and recycled, and built-in ageing must be banned. We urgently need to get to grips with the problems of chemicals and microplastics in our oceans and in our everyday lives. It is important that products such as washing machines and mobile phones are included in this directive. We have smart washing machines. Can we stop microplastics from clothes secreted in our sewage that are hard to clean away? A simple, inexpensive and effective measure. We know that our mobile phones contain valuable and rare minerals that are often mined in horrible conditions in poorer countries, so the next step is to introduce ethical and environmental criteria, like origin labelling and extracting raw materials used in our products. Human rights and the environment must be the focus of our legislation within the EU.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, first of all, let me thank the rapporteur for their great cooperation in the preparation of the report. Ecodesign has brought real added value in terms of both energy and resource savings. Indeed, this is recognised by both the industrial sectors concerned, as well as by NGOs and experts from the Member States. The potential offered by the current directive should be fully exploited. All environmental impacts of the products in question should always be considered with regard to their composition, durability, dismantling, repairability and recyclability, already at the design stage. However, this is no longer enough for our increasing consumption and the resulting problems. It's time to think more over the subjects we use daily. This need shows up today and daily. Let's look at what crisis we are currently experiencing in terms of plastics. In doing so, so little would be enough. I am arguing here for the long term that it is a new reform, strengthening and fundamental expansion of ecodesign that is the right key to the development of the circular economy. The new text should apply to a far wider product portfolio, should be properly intertwined with waste and chemical legislation, and the competent authorities should have more competences with regard to compliance with the rules by processors and manufacturers. That's what I expect from another proposal from the European Commission, if not this, at least the new one.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I and many of my constituents are extremely concerned about the content of the EU Ecodesign Directive and I have received many emails and letters about it. Of greatest concern is the effect that the directive will have on theatres and similar venues across the United Kingdom and Europe. Since 2009, retailers have been banned from selling tungsten lighting for domestic use, but they were still permitted to sell it for use in theatres and concert halls, which were exempted from the ban. Over the years, people working in the entertainment industry have approached manufacturers who were still making this type of light bulb, requesting that they continue production. However, the supply of tungsten lamps will now cease as the Ecodesign Directive will end this exemption. Not only that: the legislation will also affect most of the lighting used in this field. The effect of this legislation will be that, by 2020, theatres and other venues in the entertainment industry will no longer be able to purchase new tungsten lamps, while at the same time no suitable alternative will be available. This directive will have a negative impact on theatres and similar venues, especially smaller establishments that would be disproportionately affected. Consequently, we in UKIP believe that the creative industries should be exempted from this legislation.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, the implementation of the ecodesign directive has been delayed, and for good reason the Commission has been very little or badly supporting the Member States in meeting these requirements. Consumers, households and the environment are the first to pay the price. Member States and companies need to be given more resources in order to meet the double requirements of manufacturing quality and environmental and sanitary quality when designing products. A qualitative leap will result from increased compliance of products available on the European market and is expected to stem the arrival of non-compliant products, particularly from Asia. For smartphones and information and communication technologies, the urgency is to reduce our dependence on rare earth and metals. Ecodesign can help us. I will therefore support and vote in favour of this balanced report, which complements other crucial issues, but also and above all because it will make it possible to envisage more frugal and environmentally friendly consumption.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, 80% of the environmental impact of products is decided by design. So already, when the first Ecodesign Directive was launched, there was a great debate that it should not be only energy but it should cover all product classes and all impacts on the environment. This need is even highlighted now that we have the programme on the circular economy and the need to make products more upgradable, reparable, reusable, disassemblable, modular and recyclable as a material at the highest level.  This is important because through the Ecodesign Directive, we can have an impact also on all goods that are imported into the EU. Think, for example, of plastics. You cannot ban single-use plastics in packaging, for example, if you don’t put that in the Ecodesign Directive so that it is compliant with WTO rules and it has an impact on all the goods that are imported as well.  This is a crucial change and I am very happy to see that the Commission is ready to consider changing the scope so that it would cover all products and it would be horizontal, having these demands in different classes. Next comes surveillance: that the goods and products are really compatible with the Regulation also on the markets.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we agree that the Ecodesign Directive was an effective instrument, and the implementation report confirms this. Exploiting the full potential of eco-design helps improve energy and raw material management and accelerate the transition to a more sustainable and low-carbon economy. However, EU ecodesign legislation needs to be open, to cover a wider range of everyday products, must be consistent with related Union regulations and better understood by EU citizens, and design innovation ecological compatibility of products must be stimulated. This will help reduce millions of tonnes of waste entering landfills and incineration and subsequently reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Market surveillance should also be strengthened by a number of measures, with the improvement of the market surveillance system requiring adequate funding from Member States.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. I recently went to a children's theatre: Pippi Longstocking — really beautiful. Nervously, the children were in the spotlight on the school stage. Keyword “spotlight” — we are already on a topic that is becoming important in the context of the Ecodesign Directive. The stage lighting for professionals: lighting according to EN60598217. Stage lights put art and culture in the right light — glittering, colourful, dynamic. We must not subject all of this to a flimsy energy saving dictate. We can't, because we unnecessarily limit the light of art, turn off the juice of the spot. And we shouldn't do that because we are overwheling small stages, associations and municipal agencies. True, no one has to take old luminaires off the traverses because of the directive. Nevertheless, whenever they replace individual luminaires, the entire system is out of balance in terms of lighting technology. There are many lamps and lighting effects that, according to the new rule, would no longer exist. Commissioner Cañete, let us find a way to save the spotlight, not just for the children. Seniors also love the spotlight.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the small and large revolutions that are already happening outside here testify to us a world that wants to change, which wants to move on from the economic model of Unbridled consumption of products to that based on services and collaboration, where people's relationships are the real source of value. The world of social innovation, collaborative economies, makers, are an incredible source of new ideas and solutions for our daily lives. As I come to the report on the implementation of the Ecodesign Directive, for which I sincerely thank the rapporteur Ries for her excellent work, I also hope that this directive will be able to be extended to more and more product categories. Because the correct design of products and services, in their entire lifecycle, brings countless benefits in terms of the use of both energy and matter — and they also remembered it very well. colleagues — and therefore directly on the environment and climate, but it also leads to incredible results in terms of employment and opportunities for businesses. There is a study by the EPA, the US environmental agency, which is illuminating, which tells us that 10 000 tons of waste a job is created in incineration, 6 jobs in landfills, 36 jobs in recycling centres and as many as 296 jobs in the area of reuse, recovery and repair. The question is, is politics ready to give space and support to these new ideas, these new solutions? Is the policy, above all, ready to act for durability, repairability, the possibility of updating and reuse, the contrast to scheduled obsolescence? Will this Europe fully seize the opportunities to become a resilient and sustainable society? The signs are encouraging. I, as an Italian and European, I hope so.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I fully support the report on the implementation of the Ecodesign Directive. The directive has been instrumental in improving energy efficiency across Europe, which everybody must welcome. It has significantly reduced greenhouse gas emissions, has led to economic benefits for consumers, thanks to increased competition amongst manufacturers, and has provided opportunities for sustainable growth and jobs, including in the small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) sector. It is helping to eliminate the least-performing products in the market, significantly contributing to the EU’s 2020 energy-efficiency objectives. This is an area which is extremely important both to me, as rapporteur on the Renewable Energy Directive, and to my constituents. And, incidentally, both Commissioner Cañete and I will be back here at 8 o’clock in the morning for a four-hour trilogue on the same Renewable Energy Directive. Have a good night’s sleep, Commissioner! When inefficient incandescent light bulbs were phased out across Ireland, beginning in 2008, this saw significant reductions in energy usage and gradually lowered spending on light bulbs for our citizens. This has considerably helped low-income households who are at risk of energy poverty. I look forward to a time when products such as smartphones, which are sold in large numbers and replaced frequently, can be more efficient, and I support the Commission’s recommendations on this. This is a topic of major importance to everybody: increasing transparency and ensuring that Irish and European citizens embrace energy efficiency as soon as possible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, the Ecodesign directive, in the first stage of course, was only concerned with energy issues. I think, however, that it is quite right to expand and now it concerns the whole circular economy. This is very important, because we have the following positive actions. First of all, increased protection of the environment. Secondly, the creation of new jobs. Thirdly, rid us of the various rubbish. One understands that, when we have raw materials recycling, product recycling, we are going to a different era, an era that has real issues in relation to the control of the products themselves, their repairability and efficiency. Of course, all this needs to be labelled, the consumer channel itself needs to be updated and, through the marking, one can make the right choices. At the same time, however, consultation is also needed, because the transition phase is not an easy one. We must take into account many aspects of the economy itself and many aspects of the operation of businesses and factories. In any case, this is a positive step, which must be supported. But I would also expect an answer, Commissioner, to the points raised by my colleagues about the filament lamps in theatres.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for your contributions to this debate. I would like to address two specific issues that were raised in the debate. Let me start with the problems of theatre lighting, which has been raised by many Members: Mr Palmer, Ms Reid, Mr Gericke, Mr Marias, amongst others. I would say that for two years the Commission has been reviewing the ecodesign legislation for lighting. This also covers the application of exemptions, as well as the existence of suitable replacements available on the market. In December 2017, revision proposals were discussed in the Ecodesign Consultation Forum, consisting of representatives from Member States, industry, civil society and other partners. The Commission is receiving and analysing comments, including those we received in the context of the Public Consultation, which ran until 7 May this year. The Commission also met with representatives from the theatre and entertainment sector to discuss their concerns. The outcome of those consultations will inform the further development of the ecodesign requirements, including whether a specific exemption for theatre lighting continues to be necessary. Ms Reid, Mr Telička and Mr Kelly also raised the issue of ICT products. I would say that in the Ecodesign Working Plan 2016-2019 the Commission announced a more in-depth assessment of several ICT products with a view to their possible inclusion in the working plan, including gateways, base stations and mobile smart phones. The main reason for a specific assessment of ICT products is that it has proven very difficult to make a reliable estimate of their energy savings potential, given the uncertainty about future market developments. Moreover, for fast-moving product sectors such as mobile phones, questions have arisen as to the suitability of the ecodesign process for establishing minimum energy and resource efficiency criteria, because, as this process takes on average around four years, the risk is that requirements would be updated by the time they enter into force. The Commission has started this assessment, for example with a study that looks specifically at the material efficiency aspect of smart phones. Based on the outcomes of this assessment, the Commission will determine the best policy approach for improving the energy efficiency and wider circular economy aspects of mobile phones and other ICT products. I will conclude by saying that I look forward to continue working with the European Parliament to improve the implementation of this policy framework.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mrs Ries, you have already used your six minutes at the beginning of the debate, but I decided to give you another 30 seconds to conclude the debate. Please.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, I shall be very brief. I would like to thank the Commissioner for taking into account the two projects that have been discussed here, namely the issue of theatre lighting. Member States will vote in October. I think that, politically, the Commission could go along with the remarks that have been made. It should also tackle the huge mobile phone site. One billion mobile phones sleep in drawers in Europe, that is to say the scale of this project. For the rest, I believe our discussions have shown how to take environmental impacts into account throughout the life cycle of products is to meet our needs of the present, without compromising the ability of our children to meet their needs of tomorrow. That is to say how essential our work is, and also the involvement of the citizens of Europe.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 31 May 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: in writing. — (NL) Ecodesign and energy labelling are very much appreciated by Eurosceptics as 'absurd, pointless European interference'. “Europe should not deal with which vacuum cleaner we buy!” But these two regulations will allow us to achieve half of our energy saving target by 2020, reduce CO2 emissions by 320 million tonnes each year and every European family's accounts by EUR 500, generate EUR 55 billion for our industry and create 800 000 new jobs. It is clear, therefore, that Europe must be concerned about this. And with priority. Ecodesign should include more products and more criteria. The focus is now on energy consumption alone. We want to extend this to include sustainability aspects such as recyclability, use of recycled materials, recoverability, easy dismantling, availability of spare parts and regulations on rare or harmful raw materials. The minimum service life of products and warranty periods must also be in height. But the first step is to correctly apply the rules, and there again the shoe is wringing. The non-compliance is currently estimated at 10 to 25% of the products on the market. As a result, 10% of the possible savings are lost. This corresponds to the entire energy production of the Belgian nuclear park. We can no longer let this go unpunished.
